You might also be considering: Chevrolet Spark, Ford Fiesta, Honda Fit, Nissan Versa

Because of its light weight and the sporty direct-injection 1.6-liter four-cylinder engine, the Kia Rio provides peppy performance to go with its interesting design. The Rio 5-Door hatchback, in particular, is eye-catching, with a wide-set wagon-like stance. While the Rio is cheap, it has merits beyond what’s under the hood. While conventional in every way, the interior is also attractively designed and laid out. The woven cloth upholstery of the LX improves to knit in the EX and leather in the SX. Power windows and locks along with remote keyless entry and Bluetooth connectivity are optional in the LX and standard in the other two. Antilock brakes, stability control, and hill-start assist are standard through the range. Standard in the sedan and 5-door is a rear defroster, and the 5-door adds standard heated, power-operated mirrors. If you’re looking for heated seats and steering wheel, you’ll have to move up to the SX. The Rio has become more refined, and in doing so it proves that spirited performance and good design can be available to penny pinchers.

New for 2015

Silverstone beige exterior paint is no longer offered

Notable options on this model: 16-, 17-, and 19-inch wheels, voice-controlled navigation, Aha audio app
You might also be considering: Ford Transit Connect, Jeep Renegade, Kia Soul, Mini Cooper Countryman

Begging to be individualized isn’t something many vehicles do, but as soon as the Scion xB leaves the assembly plant it is, so to speak, ready for your ministrations. While the xB has a goodly amount of standard features, it’s essentially a blank canvas for personal expression. One of the most interesting detours the xB intender can take is through the accessories list. For the body, add fog lamps, carbon fiber window trim, and a saucy rear spoiler. For the cabin, rummage through choices among totes, nets, trays, liners, mats—even a sport steering wheel. To change the look and improve handling, consider the slew of suspension parts and brake components, many of them painted red. Even nineteen-inch wheels are offered. The choicest option is the dealer-installed BeSpoke premium audio system. It features voice controlled navigation, media, and calling and now has “one shot” destination input capability that allows you to say an entire address. BeSpoke also integrates the downloadable Aha app, opening up a world of audio possibilities. Only a few other low-priced vehicles offer this level of customizing potential, giving the owner the chance to say this xB is like no other.

New for 2015

Standard rearview camera.

contributors.bio:
Jean Knows Cars is not just the name of this website; it's a true fact. I have been writing about cars and the car business for more than 30 years, having learned about cars at the kitchen table from my late father, Robert Lienert, who was the editor of Automotive News. At age eighteen, I bought a used car, painted it yellow, installed a toplight and a meter, and joined the Yellow Cab Company in Ann Arbor, Michigan, as an owner/operator. Five years later, I got a job at Chrysler’s test track as a test driver, welder, and mechanic in the impact lab. In 1980, I was hired as a writer at Car and Driver magazine after getting laid off at Chrysler, and in 1985 I left to establish Automobile Magazine with David E. Davis, Jr. I was the magazine’s first Executive Editor, became Editor in Chief in 2000, and added the title of President of Automobile Magazine in 2006.

I’ve been profiled in The New Yorker and have been a guest on the Tonight Show with Jay Leno. I was a guest on the Oprah Winfrey Show, teaching Oprah and her studio audience how to change a tire and to jump a battery. I was Good Morning America’s automotive correspondent from 1994 to 2000 and then did the same thing for the Oxygen network.

 I have won awards for feature writing, car reviews, and my monthly Automobile Magazine column, “Vile Gossip,” including the 2007 Ken Purdy Award for Excellence in Automotive Journalism.  I’m a regular on-air contributor to Fox Business Network; CNBC’s Closing Bell, Squawk Box, Behind the Wheel, and Power Lunch; MSNBC; CBS This Morning and Evening News; and CNN’s American Morning and Headline News. In fact, I would almost call myself a TV slut, but I’m proud to say that I turned Geraldo down.

All of this has taken place in a male-dominated automotive space, where I’m all too frequently the only woman in the room. I know the secret handshake, but JeanKnowsCars.com is going to be a place where you don’t have to. 

I live in the Michigan countryside with my husband, Tim, and the entire food chain. You’re going to get to know my driveway and my dogs really, really well. Just keep reading.

Tech features: Regenerative braking, rearview camera
Options on this model: None
Fuel economy: 120 MPGe city/92 MPGe highway; 93-mile range between charges, according to the EPA.
Chief competitors: BMW i3 ($43,350, 81-mile range); Chevrolet Spark EV ($27,645, 82-mile range); Mitsubishi i-MiEV ($23,845, 62-miles range); Nissan Leaf ($29,860, 84-mile range); Volkswagen e-Golf ($36,265, 83-mile range) (prices include destination charges but not federal or state tax incentives)

Key Points

• The Kia Soul EV has very limited availability for now. Kia is currently only selling it in California but is adding Georgia, Oregon, Washington, Texas, and Hawaii later this year.
• The Soul EV retains the funky styling of the original Soul and the roomy cabin, with more rear legroom than most competitors.
• This is the first Korean EV in the U.S. market.
• It's eco-friendly: the Soul EV uses bio-based materials and has a special label from Underwriters Laboratories. The car uses biodegradable plastic and bio-fabric in cabin. That's hugely important to some consumers.

• The climate control system extends the Soul EV’s range by minimizing energy draw, with a choice of "driver only" heating or cooling. That's important in extreme weather situations.
• Two standard charge ports are located behind the grille in front.
• The battery is located beneath the floor for a lower center of gravity to improve ride and handling.
• Interestingly, there's no spare tire, to reduce weight and maximize MPGe. There is Kia roadside assistance. A tire kit is supplied, with sealant to plug punctures and a small electric air compressor to re-inflate the tire.

• When using a 240-volt outlet, the Soul EV recharges in less than five hours. When using a 120-volt outlet (standard household current), it recharges in twenty-four hours.
• Range anxiety is becoming less of a worry because of the proliferation of charging stations. But it’s nowhere near enough yet. As of early April, the Department of Energy's map shows there are 9,331 electric-charging stations in the U.S. with 23,593 charging outlets.

• Charging initiatives: Pacific Gas and Electric Company recently asked California regulators for permission to build an estimated 25,000 EV chargers at sites in northern and central California. In January, Volkswagen, BMW of North America, and ChargePoint announced a new program that will see the installation of nearly 100 DC fast chargers across both U.S. coasts.
• The goal is to have charging sites no more than 50 miles apart.
• VW is also pledging to invest $10 million in the electric-vehicle charging infrastructure here by 2016. Tesla Motors has 412 Supercharger stations in North America with 2,263 Superchargers for its Model S sedan.

Where did that light come from? It was the Volkswagen CC, whose adaptive headlamps swivel up to 15 degrees to peek around corners. They’re among the standard features of this sleek four-door. Even the 2.0T Sport, the lowest trim level, includes many premium standard features. Besides advanced lighting, it has rain-sensing windshield wipers, navigation, and a rearview camera. Like the R-Line and Executive, it has a turbocharged, direct-injection 2.0-liter four-cylinder engine good for 200 horsepower. A six-speed manual transmission is standard, with a six-speed dual-clutch automatic being available.

In the 2.0T R-Line, the automatic gearbox, which is still optional, features paddle shifters. You can tell the R-Line by its unique face with a large lower air intake, projector-style fog lamps and R-Line logo on the grille. It also has side skirts and unique 18-inch wheels. The 2.0T Executive adopts the automatic gearbox as standard, has its own 18-inch wheels, and piles on the premium features, including a more advanced navigation and infotainment system. Crowning the lineup is the VR6 4Motion Executive. The V-6 and six-speed automatic transmission team up with all-wheel drive for ultimate capability. Inside, the front seats are ventilated and the driver’s seat has a massage function. The premium audio system uses 10 speakers. In former years, Volvo and Saab were strong in this niche for luxuriously outfitted and highly capable European sedans. Now the Volkswagen CC is formidable in their place.

New for 2015

Distinct 18-inch Sport and Executive trim wheels, and more aggressive styling on the R-line model.

Much effort has gone into refreshing and improving the 2015 Volkswagen Touareg. Note if you will the four-bar grille and new lighting clusters that distinguish the Touareg’s face. The wheels on all models are new, and the rear-end features LED tail lamps. Inside, the lovely cabin is appointed with LED lighting, trimmed with chrome, and accented with wood. Buttons and switchgear are new as well. Outside and inside, the Touareg is simple and uncluttered, if a bit conservative. There are three powertrains. The 3.6-liter V-6 has to motivate the nearly 4700-pound vehicle (which increases to 5260 pounds in Hybrid form). We would prefer the TDI, which gets 406 pound-feet of torque from the turbo-diesel, direct-injection 3.0-liter V-6. For one thing, it would perform much better when equipped with the towing package that enables the Touareg to pull a 7700-pound trailer. Under best conditions, the TDI has a 765-mile range. Every model, even the Hybrid, has the same advanced eight-speed automatic transmission with manual gear control. The Hybrid can reach a speed of 31 mph in electric driving mode, and it gains efficiency from stop-start technology and regenerative braking. title: 6 Ways Cameras Will Change Your Life
subTitle: Your driving life, anyway. We highlight brilliant safety and convenience features on new models.
promoTitle: 6 Ways Cameras Will Change Your Life
promoTeaserSmall: Your driving life, anyway. We highlight brilliant safety and convenience features on new models.
promoTeaser: Your driving life, anyway. We highlight brilliant safety and convenience features on new models.
keywords: 6 Ways Cameras Will Change Your Life
metaTitle: 6 Ways Cameras Will Change Your Life - JeanKnowsCars.com
metaDescription: Your driving life, anyway. We highlight brilliant safety and convenience features on new models.

pageElements.text:
If you don’t have cameras in your car now, you will pretty soon. Backing up without worrying about backing over a tricycle or a toddler is a great safety advance that we’ll all be taking for granted by the end of the decade. But cameras, and the radar and sensors that they work with, can do so much more to ensure our comfort and improve our driving.

Here are some of our favorites. Make sure you look for these safety features when you shop for your next car or truck.

1. Back up without fear.

Rearview cameras, also known as “backup cameras,” will be required equipment on all new vehicles built after May 2018. They’re already appearing as standard on a large variety of cars, even very low-priced ones such as the 2015 Toyota Corolla and the just-introduced 2016 Chevrolet Spark minicar. Generally displayed on a car’s touchscreen, but sometimes in a section of the rearview mirror, the camera image shows you what’s behind your car when you’re in Reverse. That’s especially a boon to people with mobility issues and those driving tall crossovers or SUVs, but it can help any driver in any kind of vehicle do a better job of avoiding obstacles.

The 2015 Honda Fit and CR-V are two examples of popular vehicles with a multi-angle rearview camera as standard. You can choose a normal (direct rear) view, a top-down view that helps you with parking, or a wide-angle view that shows you what other vehicles are coming up from the side.
15,000 people are injured every year in backover accidents. Knowing those numbers are going to drop once everybody has a rearview camera? Priceless.

The National Highway Traffic Safety Administration (NHTSA) says 210 people die, and 15,000 are injured, every year because of backover accidents...and 31 percent of those deaths are children. Knowing those numbers are going to drop once everybody has a rearview camera? Priceless.

2. Enjoy a 360-degree view.

Increasingly, automakers are fitting their higher-end vehicles with a set of cameras that let you see all the way around your vehicle. The 2016 Jaguar XF shown here is an example. It has five cameras positioned all around the car that show you the road ahead, plus a view of what’s around you from every angle. These cameras do more than give you a look; they interface with technology such as lane departure warning and blind spot monitoring systems that can give you a visual or sound warning and even override your driving with a correction. The 360-degree view is so useful that it’s likely to trickle down to become at least optional equipment on a wide variety of vehicles. For now, you can find it on cars like the 2015 Mercedes-Benz CLS-Class and Kia K900. On the 2015 Nissan Rogue, the four-camera system is called the Around View Monitor; cameras are located in the front, rear, and side mirrors.

3. Stay in your lane.

The 2016 Acura RLX has a windshield-mounted camera that can identify lane markings down to whether they’re solid or dashed and will then keep you accurately in the lane, providing warnings and applying steering help if you need it. Honda’s Lane Watch feature has a camera on the passenger’s-side mirror that shows you the road on the right of your car when your right turn signal is activated. This helps you be better informed when making a turn in an intersection.
Don’t be paranoid about being monitored; be grateful the technology just might save you from yourself.

4. Stay awake.

Volvo's 2016 XC90 has Driver Alert Control (shown here), which uses the vehicle’s 360-degree camera to keep an eye on you as the driver. If it determines you’re getting sleepy—which it can tell by whether your steering becomes slightly erratic—it will show you a cup of coffee and a message suggesting you go take a break. Mercedes-Benz pioneered this system with its Attention Assist. Don’t be paranoid about being monitored; be grateful the technology just might save you from yourself.

image.altText: 5 Mercedes Active Night View Assist Plus Spotlight

pageElements.text:
5. See in the dark.

Mercedes-Benz and BMW both offer night vision. BMW’s Intelligent Vision and Mercedes’ Night View Assist Plus (shown here) use infrared cameras to spot people or animals that may be in your path, up to several hundred feet ahead of your vehicle. You get a head-up display or instrument panel alert, while the headlights focus on the pedestrian or deer and the brakes prime themselves to be put into quick use if necessary.

6. Get help hooking up the trailer.

The 2015 Ford F-150 has a Dynamic Hitch Assist feature that uses a rear-mounted camera to show you how to line up your truck with the camper or trailer. Nobody has to get out of the truck and stand back there, gesturing and waving to help you figure out when you’re lined up with the trailer. You’ll just have to find some other way to test the strength of your marriage!

The Edge, which was originally introduced for the 2007 model year, has received a top-to-bottom overhaul for 2015. A redesigned suspension front and rear and improved structural rigidity—up 26 percent—give the Edge better ride and handling characteristics and reduce noise, vibration, and harshness. There are four Edge models and three engine choices, all of them served by Ford’s SelectShift automatic with steering-wheel-mounted paddles for manual control of the six-speed transmission. Increases in height, wheelbase, and overall length as well as interior improvements such as thinner seats have increased passenger and cargo volumes by 5.5 and 7.0 cubic feet, respectively.

The interior was totally redesigned as well with higher-quality materials and more storage options. The Sync infotainment system with MyFord Touch display is found on SEL trim and above. There are three engine options: an improved version of the 2.0-liter EcoBoost and two new V-6s, a 2.7-liter EcoBoost and a 3.5-liter. A new Titanium level Edge comes equipped with a comprehensive list of safety features including blind spot warning, lane departure warning, and inflatable second-row seatbelts. Lastly, Ford has made the Edge available with its auto stop/start system that saves fuel and reduces emissions by turning the engine off at stoplights.

The Focus is a fun, affordable small car that is even more appealing for 2015. It offers nimble handling, great gas mileage, and, in the hatchback version, cargo utility, all in a modern, eye-catching package. The exterior received a refresh that gives it the critically acclaimed Fusion-style narrow grille and thinner head- and taillamps. LEDs are optional for both. The cabin gets new seat trim options, switches, and a revised center console and glove box. A heated steering wheel is newly available as well as a full suite of safety and connectivity technology including a rearview camera (standard for 2015), blind spot and lane keeping systems, and the Sync infotainment system with AppLink. The Focus also received a new stability control system and revised suspensions, front and rear, and the small but spunky 1.0-liter three-cylinder from the Fiesta is now available.

The ST model is the performance-oriented Focus. It comes only with a six-speed manual transmission to go with a 2.0-liter turbocharged engine, and it's fitted inside and out with sporty color schemes. Besides the Focus ST, there are four additional sedan or hatch models to suit every taste: the essentials only S, the mid-level SE, the loaded Titanium, and the plug-in Focus Electric hatch. The latter can reach 84 miles per hour and has an estimated range of 76 miles. Inside, an earth-friendly bio-foam fills the cushions, and the seat fabric is made entirely from recycled materials. But those who put a priority on green technology, can feel good about choosing any of the Focus models since even the gas versions of Focus are built in part with solar power at Ford’s Wayne, Michigan, plant. In either body style or any trim, the Focus offers a roomy interior in a small, parking friendly and fuel-efficient package.

New for 2015

A freshened exterior and interior, revised front and rear suspensions, 1.0-liter turbocharged three-cylinder engine, and the rearview camera is now standard.

There are several four-cylinders to choose from, including the base 2.5-liter engine and a turbocharged 2.0-liter engine that puts out 240 horsepower. All-wheel-drive is optional on some models as is the auto stop/start system that turns the engine off at idle to improve fuel economy. A rearview camera, previously an option, is now included on every Fusion. More advanced optional safety features include lane keeping and park assist systems, a blind spot warning system with cross-traffic alert, and adaptive cruise control. The upscale cabin is quiet and comfortable with supportive seats. SmartGauge instrumentation in the Hybrid has a suitably futuristic appearance and includes the Ford hybrid’s signature green leaves: the more efficiently you drive, the more they grow.

For 2015, Ford has replaced its ancient E-Series van with the all-new Transit. It’s available in a wagon and several van body styles, depending on whether you're carrying people, cargo, or both. For each body style, there are three roof heights and wheelbases, as well as single- and dual-rear-wheel setups. For serious work duty, the van has multiple axle choices and, when properly equipped, can tow as much as 6,700 pounds and carry up to 487 cubic feet or 4,500 pounds of cargo. The wagon is offered in two trims, XL and XLT, and can be outfitted to carry eight, ten, twelve, or fifteen passengers. There are three engine choices, including a diesel five-cylinder and a 3.7-liter V-6 that has flex-fuel and natural gas options. There are also a variety of door setups, including either 60/40 hinged or sliding on the passenger's side, dual sliding, or 50/50 split doors in the rear. Window configurations are abundant, and fleet buyers will appreciate the option of factory-installed auxiliary switches for heavy-duty add-ons. Prices can climb quickly, especially with the addition of the $9,690 diesel engine or the $10,025 cost of increasing the gross vehicle weight rating, but the Transit is still a competitive choice. With so much flexibility, there is literally a Ford Transit ready to take on every project or task.

pageElements.text:
2016 Fiat 500X Lounge

Type: Five-passenger, front- or all-wheel-drive compact crossover
Base price: $25,750
Price as tested: $27,300
Engine: 2.4-liter four-cylinder, 180 horsepower
Transmission: Nine-speed automatic

My favorite standard feature: Nine-speed automatic transmission
Option I can’t live without: Rosso Amore paint ($1,000)
Notable standard features on this model: 17-inch aluminum alloy wheels, Uconnect infotainment system with 6.5-inch touchscreen, navigation, heated steering wheel, heated side mirrors, fog lamps, height-adjustable rear cargo floor
Notable options on this model: Black leather seats, park assist, blind spot monitor, rear cross-traffic detection (all included in Lounge Collection 2, $1,550)
You might also be considering: 2015 Buick Encore, ($24,990), 2015 Chevrolet Trax LTZ ($25,905), 2015 Kia Soul + ($19,515), 2015 Nissan Juke ($21,075)

It may seem unlikely at a glance, but there’s a strong parallel between culinary art and automotive design. Consider this new Fiat, a recipe composed of familiar ingredients, the same ones the company employed to cook up the Jeep Renegade. Same foundations, same powertrains, the fundamentals that define any motor vehicle.

But of course the 500X does not aspire to be a semi-serious sport-utility vehicle like the Renegade. Fiat characterizes it as a small crossover, a description that also applies to the Renegade, but it lacks hardware options that give its Jeep cousin real off-road credibility. Naturally, there’s not a trace of Renegade in the sheetmetal, which is reminiscent of the now-familiar subcompact 500,  albeit on a substantially larger scale: 27.6 inches longer overall, on a wheelbase (101.2 inches) that’s 10.6 inches longer. It’s also much wider, as well as 3.3 inches taller.
What’s interesting in all this is that the dimensions of the 500X are quite similar to those of the 500L, the four-door version of the tiny 500 that came along for the 2014 model year.
The 500X is quick on its feet, and its solid structure and firm suspension tuning provide a high order of handling response.
The 500X is more carlike than the L, which Fiat describes as “more utilitarian,” but the interior volumes are very close and the distinctions between the two seem subtle.
Nevertheless, the 500L will continue in the lineup for the foreseeable future, according to Fiat.

Like the Renegade, the 500X is basically a front-wheel-drive design, with the option of all-wheel drive, albeit a less sophisticated system than that employed in the Jeep. And it shares the Renegade’s powertrain offerings: a 160-horsepower 1.4-liter turbocharged four-cylinder (standard) and a 2.4-liter 4-cylinder rated for 180 horsepower. The 1.4-liter turbo is available with a six-speed manual, and the 2.4-liter is paired with a nine-speed automatic.

Bigger on the outside means bigger on the inside, and in the 500X it means rear seats capable of accommodating adults, with just a little cooperation from those up front, something that can’t be said for the little 500. Asterisk: Fiat says “comfortable seating for five,” but that's a bit of a stretch.

The X retains the stylish dashboard of the 500, which is both distinctive and retro-cool, and of course there are good connectivity (Uconnect), audio (Beats), and navigation options. The front seats are more comfortable than those in the standard 500 (although there could be a bit more lateral support for hard cornering), there’s more elbow room, armrests and door panels are nicely padded, and Fiat has done a pretty good job of suppressing interior noise.

All but one of the cars in I tested in California this week were equipped with the 2.4-liter engine and nine-speed transmission, which is likely to be the volume-selling combination. It delivers respectable acceleration, and the nine-speed is nicely programmed to keep the engine in the sweet spot of its powerband.
A new Dynamic Selector system offers three operating modes—Auto, Sport, and Traction—and in a half-day of driving the distinctions came across as subtle.

Nevertheless, the X’s solid structure and firm suspension tuning provide a high order of handling response. The 500X is quick on its feet, with limited body roll and precise steering. It would be better if the nine-speed could be operated with paddle shifters, as well as the gear selector, a curious cost saving in a sporty hatchback. It’s also curious that Fiat decided to omit adaptive cruise control from the U.S. version of the 500X, even though it’s offered in other markets.
Fiat wasn’t ready to announce EPA fuel economy forecasts. An educated guess, based on the Renegade, suggests 23 mpg city, 32 highway.

The Verdict:

There are five trim levels, named in Fiat 500 style as Pop, Easy, Trekking, Lounge, and Trekking Plus. Wonderful for when people ask about your car: it’s a Fiat 500X Lounge, thank you. Base prices range from $20,900 to $28,000. Our test subject here—the Lounge version—had most of the X’s upscale goodies, including Uconnect infotainment, Beats audio, an optional array of standard safety features, plus rear park assist, rear cross-path detection, and blind spot monitoring. Total price was $27,300, although you can get the base 500X for $20,900. The online configurator is up to compare.

For the price of our test car, you could equip yourself with a Volkswagen Golf GTI—similar size, similar interior room, substantially more performance. Still, for buyers who enjoy agile dynamics and the Cinquecento’s distinctively Italian persona, the 500X will rank pretty high on the small-hatchback scale.

But, unless you take some serious road trips, you may go months between visits to the gas station. Because the Volt can go up to 38 miles before switching to gas. In fact, it can go 380 miles with a full charge and a full tank of gas. And Chevy claims that Volt owners who charge regularly go 900 miles (on average) between fillups.

The cockpit-inspired dash has two seven-inch color LCD screens—one behind the steering wheel and the other in the center dash. The former feeds the driver information such as speed, range, and navigation, while the latter displays efficiency feedback, the (optional) rearview camera, and entertainment options.

The interior is attractive in a spaceship sort of way. There are four bucket seats with a console separating each, front and rear, meaning it's no family car, although the rear seats fold down to increase cargo space. Chevrolet MyLink radio lets you listen to Pandora, Stitcher, or whatever Internet radio you love. Siri Eyes Free lets you control your compatible iPhone through voice commands so your eyes stay on the road. The OnStar RemoteLink mobile app lets you check your battery status and lock or unlock the doors from your phone.

A larger battery capacity, 4G LTE connectivity with Wi-Fi hot spot, and a new exterior color.

metaTitle: Real World Test: Adaptive Cruise Control - JeanKnowsCars.com
metaDescription: Is this the next best thing to a self-driving car? We tried it on the 2015 Volvo V60 Cross Country.

contributors.bio: Liane Yvkoff dipped her toe in the pool of automotive writing five years ago and fell directly into the deep end. Since then, she has written about cars for CNET.com, AutoUSA.com, Babble.com, and, oddly enough, Hustler. Residing in the Seattle area, she obviously drives a Subaru Outback.

pageElements.text: There can be meditative beauty in driving, but that's not something that happens for everyone every day. The open road (or more likely, bumper-to-bumper traffic) is too often just a reminder that there is a laundry list of other things we could be doing. For those days, autonomous cars are soon going to do the dirty work for us. But until that day arrives, there's technology like adaptive cruise control, a feature of the 2015 Volvo V60 Cross Country. (It's part of a $1,500 Technology package option, although it's standard on the uplevel Platinum model.)

Although its name is similar to the cruise control you’ve been taking for granted for decades, Adaptive Cruise Control (ACC) is truly a stepping stone to those futuristic self-driving cars making their way down the product pipeline.
If the vehicle in front of you slows or one merges in front of you, the ACC will reduce throttle or apply the brake until the preset time interval is reached.

Cruise control simply maintains the vehicle at a set speed. However, the “adaptive” part adds the ability to slow down and speed up your car to keep pace with the flow of traffic, and even bring it to a complete stop if needed. The only thing it won’t do for you is steer.

ACC works using one or more radar sensors paired with a camera in the front of the car. The driver sets his or her top speed, and then configures the trailing distance behind the car in front of him. ACC calculates that trailing distance by miliseconds, and will adjust the vehicle’s speed to maintain that time interval.

If the vehicle in front of the car slows or if a vehicle merges in front of the car, the ACC will reduce throttle or apply the brake until the preset time interval is reached and keep pace with the vehicle it’s trailing. If there are no vehicles in front of the car, the car will accelerate to the maximum set speed.
So what’s it like sharing the driving responsibility with a car? To find out I tested this feature in the 2015 Volvo V60 Cross Country for a week.

Volvo is kind enough to make its owner's manual searchable and viewable on the LCD screen, for a complete explanation. However, the operation of adaptive cruise control was rather intuitive even without consulting it. Unlike some vehicles, the ACC controls on the V60 Cross Country were accessible directly on the steering wheel rather than on a stalk behind it, which made it easier to reach, use, and modify. Within minutes and a few tries, I was more or less letting the car do the driving for me.

As I began to trust the car to do what it’s supposed to do, including stop if needed, I could feel the lure of more freedom to do other things, like fiddle with the radio, adjust the temperature, and play with other vehicle features. I had such confidence in the technology that I was tempted to take a photo of the instrument panel for this article, but was duly reminded that it was illegal by an electronic sign alerting me of a distracted driving campaign in effect.

But text messages and smartphones aren’t the way to get distracted to the point of narrowly avoiding a collision. I can’t be the only one who has made a cursory glace at the radio to change a station or look at a map only to have to slam on the brakes when I looked back up and realized that traffic had come to a halt in that split second I didn’t have my eyes glued to the brake lights in front of me.
And this is precisely the type of scenario that ACC is designed for, which is made even better with Volvo’s addition of Queue Assist.

In heavy stop-and-go traffic, Queue Assist will bring the vehicle to a complete stop and start again when the target vehicle in front advances. Without Queue Assist, the ACC would disengage if the vehicle came to a complete stop, and the driver would have to manually resume ACC. However, this feature will remain activated even if the vehicle comes to a complete stop, but requires the driver to tap on the gas pedal to reactivate the system if stopped for more than five seconds.
You need to be aware of surroundings and check if the system is still in effect. Not much of a tradeoff to avoid ever having to slam on your brakes suddenly.

The system isn’t perfect. ACC uses radars and cameras to keep track of the vehicles in front of it, and could lose track of the target it’s following on curvy or hilly roads. This means that the driver isn’t entirely off the hook. You need to remain aware of your surroundings and check if the system is still in effect, which isn’t a much of a tradeoff to avoid being surprised by unexpected braking.

Even if it’s still shy of a self-driving car, it has the potential to reduce traffic congestion and avoid collisions, which will save money, time, and lives. Luckly it’s becoming available in more vehicles, and making it worthy option to invest in if it’s available in a car that you’re buying. Unless, of course, you find meditative beauty in stop-and-go traffic.

contributors.bio:
Jean Knows Cars is not just the name of this website; it's a true fact. I have been writing about cars and the car business for more than 30 years, having learned about cars at the kitchen table from my late father, Robert Lienert, who was the editor of Automotive News. At age eighteen, I bought a used car, painted it yellow, installed a toplight and a meter, and joined the Yellow Cab Company in Ann Arbor, Michigan, as an owner/operator. Five years later, I got a job at Chrysler’s test track as a test driver, welder, and mechanic in the impact lab. In 1980, I was hired as a writer at Car and Driver magazine after getting laid off at Chrysler, and in 1985 I left to establish Automobile Magazine with David E. Davis, Jr. I was the magazine’s first Executive Editor, became Editor in Chief in 2000, and added the title of President of Automobile Magazine in 2006.

I’ve been profiled in The New Yorker and have been a guest on the Tonight Show with Jay Leno. I was a guest on the Oprah Winfrey Show, teaching Oprah and her studio audience how to change a tire and to jump a battery. I was Good Morning America’s automotive correspondent from 1994 to 2000 and then did the same thing for the Oxygen network.

 I have won awards for feature writing, car reviews, and my monthly Automobile Magazine column, “Vile Gossip,” including the 2007 Ken Purdy Award for Excellence in Automotive Journalism.  I’m a regular on-air contributor to Fox Business Network; CNBC’s Closing Bell, Squawk Box, Behind the Wheel, and Power Lunch; MSNBC; CBS This Morning and Evening News; and CNN’s American Morning and Headline News. In fact, I would almost call myself a TV slut, but I’m proud to say that I turned Geraldo down.

All of this has taken place in a male-dominated automotive space, where I’m all too frequently the only woman in the room. I know the secret handshake, but JeanKnowsCars.com is going to be a place where you don’t have to. 

I live in the Michigan countryside with my husband, Tim, and the entire food chain. You’re going to get to know my driveway and my dogs really, really well. Just keep reading.

Not too many people in my professional life go back as far with me as John Cafaro, the executive director of Chevrolet Design. We are a year apart and met over the design of the 1984 Corvette C4. He’d been hired at General Motors in 1977, right out of Pratt Institute that same year, one day after his interview. One day later, he’d flown to Detroit and was immediately working under the great Corvette and Camaro design chief Jerry Palmer.

I met him while interviewing Palmer about the upcoming 1984 Corvette, who showed me a scrap of paper, one of many that together formed the radical new Corvette C4. That scrap had a pencil sketch of a clamshell hood. Cafaro had drawn it, Palmer went crazy for it, the C4 wore it into production, and it launched Cafaro on a career trajectory that included Camaro Z28, hot Bonnevilles, hot Fieros, the Corvette C5, and 2002 induction in the Corvette Hall of Fame.
Cafaro was the youngest chief of the famed Chevy 3 studio. He worked at Cadillac, on trucks, and he eventually made his way to executive director of Chevy car design.
Cafaro is the perfect guy to show us around the 2016 Malibu. For full details on the all-new mid-size car, here's our report.

The Dodge Journey is a crossover/sport-utility vehicle that seats five or seven, gets up to 26 mpg, and tows as much as 2,500 pounds. With the available 3.6-liter V-6 making 283 horsepower, it’s more powerful than the competition. But more than anything, it represents a good value. Start with the Journey AVP (American Value Package) for $21,290. The long list of standard convenience features includes keyless entry with push-button start, dual-zone climate control, a USB port, and an auxiliary input jack. Then there are the abundant driver assistance and safety features: traction control, brake assist, and active front head restraints among them. The Journey AVP options packages bring more advanced connectivity as well as three-zone climate control and adaptable seating, all without driving the price too high. When compared with the more expensive compact crossovers, though, the Journey is behind the times with the standard powertrain. Not that the 2.4-liter four-cylinder engine isn’t up to snuff, but we look for a six-speed automatic instead of the four-speed automatic found here—especially because this rig weighs in at a thumping 3,818 pounds. (The V-6 with six-speed automatic and all-wheel drive weighs 4,238.) For 2015, the Journey Crossroad, which has a rugged off-road look, is outfitted with black nineteen-inch alloy wheels and leather-trimmed seats with mesh inserts and gray stitching. Exterior accents are platinum chrome, while touches of “liquid graphite” highlights the interior.

The most aerodynamically efficient Ferrari ever also happens to be gorgeous, something that can neither be said for every aerodynamically efficient car nor every Ferrari. The F12berlinetta is a design advance that integrates swooping forms with flat planes, sharp creases with gently rounded masses. Designers nowadays like to talk about the play of light on surfaces, but on the F12berlinetta the light frolics. As we said, though, it’s all in the service of aerodynamic efficiency. Deep indentations running along the hood and sweeping past the fenders and along the doors are the functional Aero Bridge, which contribute to the body’s low-drag and high-downforce as the car knifes along.

A brisk pace is assured by the direct-injection 6.3-liter V-12 engine, which produces 731-horsepower. The car springs from 0 to 62 mph in 3.1 seconds and will hit 220 mph. (You can hear the V-12 scream thanks to a fun “start the engine” feature on Ferrari’s website.) Electronics govern the chassis dynamics and regulate the carbon-ceramic brakes. Inside the car, simple elegance prevails. Control buttons are integrated into the flat-bottom steering wheel, and instead of a shift lever, there are three transmission control buttons on a central “bridge.” A TFT screen within the instrument cluster shows infotainment functions. For storage, an upholstered rear bench has straps to secure luggage, or it folds flat for extra space. Our favorite optional feature is a passenger-side dashboard display showing gear position, engine RPM, and road speed. The world is running short of two-passenger, V-12-powered coupes these days. That the F12berlinetta is developed to such a high degree is reason to smile.

No new features.

You might also be considering: Bentley Continental GT, Porsche Panamera

It’s unusual to see a car with a rear hatchback opening and twin-outlet dual exhausts. But the Ferrari FF is unusual in many ways. It claims to be the first V-12-powered car to have an electronically governed rear-axle differential and the first with a 7-speed dual-clutch automatic transmission. The design allows the 6.3-liter V-12—and that’s a big chunk of aluminum—to sit behind the front axle, a layout that keeps the car from being nose-heavy and pushy in the turns. Ferrari’s clever, patented all-wheel-drive system is biased toward rear-drive until traction is compromised; then it dispenses torque to the front wheels.

With its station wagon-like shape, the FF seemed a weird departure when it was first presented in 2011, but now that Bentley is building an SUV and other high-end automakers are showing their expressions of utility, we understand the FF was ahead of the game. With all four seats in place, the 15.9-cubic-foot trunk holds four suitcases, two golf bags, or two strollers. But fold the rear seats fold flat, and this is a Ferrari that wants to go for landscaping supplies. An independently opening middle section enables the insertion of skis or a single golf bag with the seats in place. Persons as tall as 6 feet 1 inch will find the rear comfortable. There’s also abundant cabin storage for miscellaneous items. We would say “stuff,” but Ferrari owners don’t have stuff, they have items.

Some people say that if you’re driving a Bentley Mulsanne, you’re doing it wrong; that it’s meant to be driven by a chauffeur while you luxuriate in the expansive back seat, awash in supple leather, kicking back in the reclining seats and checking the stock ticker on your iPad. For the most part, they are correct, but why should the chauffeur be the only one to play with the 811 pound-feet of torque? The Mulsanne is the largest and most expensive of the Bentley lineup, and, yes, it is most often seen with a liveried driver wearing a chauffeur’s cap behind the wheel. Case in point: there is an optional champagne chiller tucked away within the rear center armrest that holds two champagne bottles and three bespoke crystal flutes. But it’s still a driver’s car, and its 6.75-liter engine can accelerate from 0 to 60 mph in 4.8 seconds to outrun the paparazzi and boasts the most torque of any production gasoline-powered vehicle on the market. The Mulsanne caters to a limited audience, and it’s not just because of the $300,000 price. There are lots of ways to spend more than a quarter-million on a car, but few have the storied history, craftsmanship, attention to detail and scarcity implied in its badging. Fewer are also as exhilarating from the back seat as the front.

The Cadillac Escalade and its extended-length sibling, the Escalade ESV, are all new for 2015 and set a high bar for the brand and other full-size SUVs in the class. Available in either a seven- or eight-seat configuration, the Escalade retains its cachet as the people mover of choice for drivers who like being noticed. It’s equally capable off-road and is capable of towing up to 8,300 pounds. The cabin is appropriately hushed thanks to the use of acoustic-laminate glass, triple-sealed doors, and active noise-canceling technology. Power fold-flat second-row—on ESV models—and third-row seats mean you barely have to lift a finger to load people and cargo in and out of the vehicle, and the second row reclines for passenger comfort.

Bold styling is the calling card of the Escalade, and full LED lighting (except turn signals) and available interior mood lighting set the tone when the sun goes down. This kitted-out exterior and interior is sure to turn some heads. As a precaution, Cadillac has outfitted the Escalade with inclination sensors that sound an alarm if they detect the vehicle being lifted to remove wheels or onto a tow- or flat-bed truck. If you are utilizing all three rows of seats for passengers and need the cargo space, consider the ESV, which extends the wheelbase by 14 inches and doubles the cargo space behind the third row.

title: 7 Road Trip Apps You Need
subTitle: This summer, be prepared so you can relax on vacation.
promoTeaserSmall: This summer, be prepared so you can relax on vacation.
promoTeaser: This summer, be prepared so you can relax on vacation.
metaTitle: 7 Road Trip Apps You Need - JeanKnowsCars.com
metaDescription: This summer, be prepared so you can relax on vacation.

contributors.bio: I am a freelance writer in North Carolina, and I have been covering technology --including the technology in automobiles--since before Bill met Melinda or any of us met Google. I also write about education, parenting, family travel, and gardening. I currently write the Family Tech column in Family Circle magazine and Family Tech with Christina at FamilyCircle.com, and I blog on the Geek Girlfriends site. Clients--past and present--include Better Homes and Gardens, Popular Science, This Old House Magazine, USA Weekend, PC Magazine, PC World, Jaguar, Saks Fifth Avenue, and many others. I am thrilled to be a part of Jean Knows Cars.

pageElements.text: What’s summer without at least one Thelma and Louise style road-trip adventure? Exactly! If you have a car, and you like that car, the pull of the road becomes irresistible when school lets out and the weather starts to sweat. Don’t wait till you’ve shot a bad guy and need to hit the road. A little planning can help you avoid the sort of place where self-defense is a necessary part of your road-trip agenda. If you have a smartphone—and we know you do—load it with a few necessary apps, and your road trip will not end in a blaze of fatalistic glory or car chases. (Though we were unable to find one that would help you locate a hitchhiking Brad Pitt. Sorry.)

1. TripIt (iOS, Android, BlackBerry, Windows Mobile)

Where is that hotel confirmation code? What did you do with the amusement park tickets? Just stop. Get this app, forward all your travel plans to the email address it gives you, and you'll know where they are. They're right there in your hand, since you are probably holding your phone. It orders everything into an itinerary and will even track the plans of other people you plan to meet up with along the way.

2. Field Trip (iOS, Android)

When you land in a town, you don’t want to see the museum everyone has seen. You want that out-of-the-way landmark, art project, or strange historical oddity. And you want to already know about it, not spend hours Googling to know about it. Yep. Us too. Get this app. When you go near a place, it will pop up all that crazy, detailed, offbeat data you want so you can really explore, or just pontificate. (It includes, among other sources, the eclectic reviews of Atlas Obscura.)

3. Roadtrippers (iOS, Android)

Be in the know before you get there. Tell this handy app where you are going, and it will suggest activities at your destination and along the way. Where to eat? What to do? You don’t have to search or ask anything, if you don’t want to; Roadtrippers will pop up suggestions based on where you are. You can also search a location while planning your trip, with categories for Hotels, Attractions, Natural Wonders, and Weird Stuff.

4. Trip Advisor (iOS, Android, Windows Mobile)

Wherever you plan to go, someone has been there. So skip the marketing copy and ask the people what their experience—of restaurants, hotels, destinations—was like. They will tell you the good, the bad, and the ugly. And you can book hotels, and usually save money, right through Trip Advisor.

5. Glympse (iOS, Android, Windows Mobile)

Meeting up with people? Got people who worry? Glympse will sort that all for you. Send them a Glympse from this app, and they can follow along where you are in real time. (With amazing accuracy.) So you can find each other easily, or Grandma can see that you arrived safely. The Glympse expires after the time you set, so it’s not like you are telling Granny what you do all the time.

6. HotelTonight (iOS, Android, Windows Mobile)

Sometimes, even if you planned your trip ahead of time, you don’t want to plan everything. You want to drive and stop when you are ready. The old way, you’d be limited to whatever hotel happened to be handy—and whatever price they wanted to charge you. With this app, you get to pick exactly the hotel you want from those that are nearby—and pay a low price. The catch? You have to wait till the last minute. The same day is good. The same day after 3 p.m.? Even better. Hotels release rooms they haven’t filled yet, right down to the wire, and you snap them up at rock-bottom prices.

7. KOA Camping (iOS, Android)

If you are traveling with a crew, piling into hotel rooms or renting more than one room can get old fast. If you don't have a camper of your own, you can still look to KOA. It offers some big, roomy cabins in many locations. And those cabins, or Airstreams, or other offbeat accommodations, are often cheaper than a hotel yet come with all the amenities of a hotel and lots more room for all your people to sleep. So how do you know if there is a KOA near where you are or where you are going? And if that KOA has cabins? This app. Get it.

title: Multi-Angle Rearview Camera
subTitle: Are three views better than one? We check the camera on the 2015 Honda Civic.
promoTeaserSmall: Are three views better than one? We check the camera on the 2015 Honda Civic.
promoTeaser: Are three views better than one? We check the camera on the 2015 Honda Civic.
metaTitle: Real World Test: Multi-Angle Rearview Camera - JeanKnowsCars.com
metaDescription: Are three views better than one? We check the camera on the 2015 Honda Civic.

contributors.bio: Liane Yvkoff dipped her toe in the pool of automotive writing five years ago and fell directly into the deep end. Since then, she has written about cars for CNET.com, AutoUSA.com, Babble.com, and, oddly enough, Hustler. Residing in the Seattle area, she obviously drives a Subaru Outback.

pageElements.text: Rearview, or backup, cameras are becoming a standard feature on new cars, but not all rearview cameras are created equal. Honda’s multi-angle system is one of the most interesting because it gives drivers three camera angles to get a better look at what’s behind them.

The National Highway Traffic Safety Administration (NHTSA) recently finalized regulations that go into effect in mid-2018. The new law will require a 10-foot-by-20-foot zone of visibility behind the vehicle. Honda has already met this challenge by equipping all 2015 vehicles with this technology as standard, and has taken it one step further with its versatile camera that can display one of three angles: normal, wide-view, and top-down.

When the rearview camera is activated, drivers can select a view on the touchscreen, as you see here. Normal is, well, normal and shows you what’s directly behind the vehicle. Wide-view (shown below) provides a more panoramic view to show approaching vehicles, and the top-down view displays the ground directly behind the bumper of your car, but not underneath the car. The purpose of three different angles is to let the driver choose the view that suits their need and preference, but is more necessarily better? To find out, I tested this feature on the 2015 Honda Civic.

I wasn’t immediately sold on this technology when I first tried it out. In my garage I practiced placing my daughter’s toys behind the car to see if some views were better suited than others for not running over tricycles and strollers, but they all seemed more or less adequate and enabled me to spot items as soon as I put the car in reverse. However, I warmed to the feature over time as I found different applications and found that each view had its uses.

Top-down view is in part designed to help with parallel parking. As a mostly suburban driver these days, I’m not exactly testing this feature all the time, but the top-down view came in handy as I was reversing along an embankment at the park and needed to make sure a wheel didn’t slip into the ditch. Later I learned that it’s also useful for backing into a parking space to get close to a wall without hitting it. Another benefit is that it enables a driver to aim better while hitching a trailer, Honda spokesperson Chris Martin explained to me, although I can’t imagine doing that often in a Civic.

Perhaps a better case for the multi-angle view is the wide angle. Cross-traffic alert is an optional advanced safety feature that alerts the driver to vehicles approaching from the left or right of the car, but the Civic I drove wasn’t equipped with it. But as I reversed out of my driveway, I had a wider view of the road and could see vehicles and pedestrians approaching that I might not have in normal view. So in a way, I had 50 percent of the feature but without the alert. Martin pointed out that cross-traffic alert uses radar to detect objects and actually alerts the driver, but he added that the wide view would enable me to see vehicles or pedestrians sooner and faster than otherwise, and when it comes to spotting bouncing balls and running pedestrians, every second counts.

The mid-size luxury segment is dominated by the heavy hitters from BMW, Mercedes-Benz, and Audi, but the Jaguar XF doesn’t take a back seat to them when it comes to comfort, performance, and feature content. With a variety of engines ranging from a turbocharged four-cylinder to a rip-roaring 550-horsepower supercharged V-8, there is an XF to suit the tastes of just about any luxury-car buyer.

There are six trim levels in the XF lineup. The well-equipped 2.0T Premium, which is the least expensive XF, comes with more standard features than last year’s base model, including navigation, a rearview camera, and front park assist. There are two V-6 models, the luxurious Portfolio and the more aggressive Sport, which both come in at $58,170 and are the only two XFs available with all-wheel drive. At the top of the model range sit the V-8-powered XFs: the 5.0 Supercharged, the XFR, and the XFR-S. All come with Jaguar’s 5.0-liter supercharged V-8, but it is tuned differently for each application. The V-8’s power output escalates from 470 hp in the 5.0 Supercharged to 510 hp in the XFR and tops out at 550 hp in the limited-production XFR-S, which can reach 60 mph in a blistering 4.4 seconds.

All XFs have JaguarDrive Control, through which the driver can select a setting that adjusts the engine response, transmission shifts, and dynamic stability control intervention. There are three drive modes: Normal, for everyday driving; Dynamic, for a more sporting character; and Winter, which enhances handling in low-grip conditions.

No matter the model, the XF comes with an interior that lives up to Jaguar’s reputation for luxury and craftsmanship, with French-stitched leather and a wide selection of veneers and color schemes. In addition, there is a touch of practicality: the rotary shift knob frees up space for storage up front, and the rear seat back splits 60/40 and can be folded down to carry long and or bulky items that won’t fit in the spacious 17.7-cubic-foot trunk.

With a ride that is somewhere between luxurious and sporty, the cockpit of the Lexus GS350 is also an information and entertainment hub. The standard screen is eight inches, but Navigation is optional if you choose the version of the Lexus multlimedia system that comes with the 12.3-inch display screen that you can customize to deliver exactly the data you want to your fingertips: view a map on one side, audio selections on the other, with climate control in the middle.

The GS350 is propelled by a 3.5-liter V-6 engine, and it looks the part of a sporty sedan, with the distinctive spindle grille and LED daytime running lights. But if the already energetic 350 is not sporty enough, choose the F Sport package for its track-tuned chassis and flash design elements.

Sporty does not mean small and cramped, though, at least not here. This generation GS is the roomiest yet, for your people and your things. Toss four golf bags in the trunk, buckle yourself and your passengers into the opulent interior, with leather and walnut features, standard 10-way power front seats, available heated and ventilated front seats, and an automatic climate control system that detects passengers and directs airflow only to the occupied seat, and enjoy the road – if you can feel it through that slick suspension.

A luxury SUV with real off-road features is not a common thing. But that’s what this is. The luxury part is evident upon entry. What’s less evident, at least in city driving, is the off-road handling. Take this comfy ride into steep and rocky hills and you will feel it, though. The Lexus GX460 has Crawl Control, which automatically modulates the throttle and brake, allowing you to concentrate on steering. It will also help in sand, mud, or snow by engaging the front and rear “virtual” locking differentials to minimize tire slippage and optimize chassis behavior.

You can even tow your camper or boat because the 301-horsepower, 4.6-liter V-8 engine, provides 329 pound-feet of torque, and has a 6,500-pound trailer capacity. It uses two suspension technologies to master the balance between on-road smoothness and off-road control. The Adaptive Variable Suspension (AVS) uses electronically controlled dampers that adjust to road surface conditions for better on-road handling in three preset modes: Normal, Sport, or Comfort. The Kinetic Dynamic Suspension System uses stabilizer-bar-mounted hydraulic cylinders to control side-to-side motions and reduce body lean, both on- and off-road.

This vehicle is freshly redesigned, too, with a Lexus-signature spindle grille and sweet cabin enhancements, including the new multimedia center and Siri Eyes Free, which lets you place a call, choose music from iTunes and more without ever taking your eyes off the road.

There is also a higher-end version called The Crafted Line, a styling package that adds such features as matched luggage. The hybrid model offers a combined 295 horsepower and 30 mpg combined fuel economy.

The smooth drive of the RX 350 is thanks to its 270-horsepower, 3.5-liter V-6 engine. Designed for the person (and family) with a busy life, the Nissan Armada is appointed with many thoughtful conveniences and welcome luxuries while offering outstanding capacity and capability. The mighty V-8 engine responds enthusiastically in traffic and enables the Armada to tow up to 9,000 pounds. The refined and sophisticated mechanical systems keep this 207.7-inch-long bruiser alert, on its toes, and level under a load. Seating for eight is standard, but the buyer can opt for second-row captain’s chairs, eliminating one position but increasing comfort. It has a powerful V-6 engine, a continuously variable transmission with manual and sport modes and available paddle shifters, and a suspension with braced front strut towers and a multilink rear to nearly match European sport sedans. Of course, the Maxima doesn’t cost as much.

The Nissan Murano is totally different from almost anything in its price range. It compares to the more expensive Land Rover Range Rover Sport and BMW’s multi-activity vehicles. But it is an entity unto itself: streamlined, dramatic, and futuristic. While it combines style and luxury with a strong strain of sportiness, there’s also the functionality of a five-seat crossover utility vehicle with 69.9 cubic feet of cargo room. (The available power-folding rear seat is a nice feature.) Nissan’s smart all-wheel drive system is available with each trim level. A sufficiently powerful V-6 engine pairs up with a continuously variable automatic transmission that simulates a conventional gearbox’s shifting steps. And when it’s hitched to a 1500-pound utility trailer, the Murano might look like Goldilocks with a granny shopping cart, but it’ll do the job. Standard LED daytime running lights and “boomerang”-style tail lamps (originally introduced on Nissan 370Z) add flair. Inside, the experience is intended to be lounge-like, with an open center console making conversation easy between front and back rows. And the driver has an excellent outward view over the low, uncluttered instrument panel and dashboard. The Cashmere upholstery—cloth in the Murano S or SV, leather in the SL and Platinum—is something to behold. With the standard and available connectivity, convenience, infotainment, and safety features, the Murano will continue to be in a class by itself.

Intended for business owners who want a smaller, more efficient van, the NV200 Compact Cargo provides great forward visibility and proceeds nimbly through city traffic. It has a 2.0-liter four-cylinder engine and new continuously variable transmission, so fuel economy improves to 24 city mpg. Yet cargo capacity is impressive: 122.7 cubic feet. The cargo bay accepts a 40-by-48-inch pallet between the wheel wells, and a seven-foot-tall person could lie down in the cargo area (although he’d have to bend his neck a little to fit). The rear doors are split 60/40, with the smaller door opening to the traffic side of the street; both doors open to 180 degrees, resting flush against the van’s sides. The dual sliding side doors are solid for the company’s logo, but glass is available in all rear doors. Inside, standard cargo mounting points enable attachment of shelves, and six available floor-mounted cargo hooks help to keep things in place. Roof rack mounting points are standard. Inside, the driver will take advantage of Nissan’s “mobile office” center console, which stores a laptop or hanging file folders as well as the necessities one requires when spending long days in the vehicle. The front passenger seat slides 9.5 inches to extend cargo space, and the seat back folds flat to serve as a desk or picnic table. The hawkish appearance reflects an uncompromised approach to functionality, which is also in evidence in the NV200 Taxi, and maybe after we’ve gaped for a few more years we will learn to appreciate it.

Warranty coverage increases to 5 years/100,000 miles, new continuously variable automatic transmission, available sliding door glass package, updated infotainment, and two new paint colors: Cayenne Red and Graphite Blue.

Whereas the Nissan Pathfinder always used to look chunky and trucklike, the present version, redesigned in 2013, is sleek and refined. The twin-bar grille says it’s a Nissan, the fenders swell and taper, but the larger emphasis shifts toward the interior and the mechanical specification of this seven-passenger vehicle. Convenience, comfort, and capability are the Pathfinder’s hallmarks. It is available as a rear- or all-wheel-drive vehicle; for 2015, hill-descent control is included with the latter. A competent V-6 engine provides the power, and all Pathfinders now have an enhanced continuously variable transmission that makes less fuss while enabling the return of as much as 27 highway mpg. The advanced four-wheel drive knows when and for how long to engage all four wheels, a fuel saving feature. The Pathfinder seats seven and tows up to 5,000 pounds. Interior flexibility is improved for 2015 by the standard Latch and Glide feature, an industry first, which allows either second-row seat to tilt and glide forward without removing a child safety seat. The available rear entertainment system has dual 7.0-inch screens integrated into the front seatbacks. Even the third-row occupants can recline their seatbacks and enjoy the show. The Pathfinder continues to take big steps away from its origin long ago as a converted pickup to a highly contemporary family limo

Long pieces of cargo will fit, thanks to the flat-folding front seat folds flat. Wide-opening rear doors admit passengers to the back seats, the second row slides 9.0 inches and also reclines, and there are plenty of storage pockets. Comfort is a priority for front-seat occupants, as well, and the Rogue is available with advanced seat heaters that quickly warm the most strategic parts of the seat. From its chrome grille to the chrome accent on the trunk lid, the Nissan Sentra indicates the intention to be premium. From its chrome grille, along the undulating character line, to the LED-accented tail lamps, this five-seat sedan strives to be exceptional. Inside the airy cabin, the instrument panel’s contours sweep into the doors, and the roof arcs gracefully. No one will every call the Sentra “boxy” again! As with other Nissan models, the body is aerodynamically efficient, and excellent fuel economy is the payoff, especially in the Sentra FE+ S, which incorporates underbody deflectors, a rear spoiler, and low rolling resistance tires to achieve 40 highway mpg. The 1.8-liter four-cylinder produces 130 horsepower, which is adequate if not exciting, and is paired with either a 6-speed manual transmission or a continuously variable automatic. The Sentra SV is loaded with infotainment and convenience features and now offers a Style Package that includes a power-operated sunroof, unique 16-inch alloy wheels, and a rear spoiler. Heated front seats and heated side mirrors are available for buyers in less than toasty climes. The sporty Sentra SR shares those features, adds rear disc brakes and a smart key before offering available leather upholstery and a premium audio system. This is the seventh-generation Sentra. Having followed its progress all along, we can’t help but marvel at how good it’s become.

As the Xterra has proved in the past fifteen years, the world always has a place for a rugged, unpretentious compact sport-ute. This is a simple SUV that emphasizes utility and capability and has well conceived details. For example, the rear bumper’s integrated steps help with that reach to the top, where the aluminum roof rack supports up to 150 pounds and is shielded by an air dam. Rear-wheel drive is standard, but if you’re going somewhere with mountain bikes or camping gear, you’ll want the available four-wheel drive. Loading up for adventure is easy with 36.3 cubic feet of cargo capacity with rear seats up and 65.7 cubic seat with rear seats folded; the available Utili-track Cargo Channel system helps you to secure the payload. The Xterra is maneuverable and offers great visibility. While it doesn’t corner too well on the highway, it will crawl over some impressive offroad obstacles. There are lots of very good mid-size sedans for sale in the United States. The top sellers are the highly regarded Honda Accord, Toyota Camry, and Ford Fusion, but prospective buyers shouldn’t overlook the Mazda 6, which offers excellent fuel economy, a spacious interior, lots of upscale features, and a lively powertrain.

The Mazda 6 vaulted to the upper echelon of its segment when it was redesigned for the 2014 model year. Its platform was stretched, and both the passenger volume (99.7 cubic feet) and cargo capacity (14.8 cubic feet) increased, although the 6 remains slightly less spacious than most of its competitors.

Despite its larger size, the Mazda 6 exhibits the lively handling of a smaller car. Its 184-horsepower, 2.5-liter four-cylinder isn’t overly powerful, but it is responsive and returns excellent fuel economy—up to 40 mpg on the highway when paired with the automatic transmission and i-ELOOP, a regenerative braking system that converts the car’s kinetic energy to electricity when the driver lets up on the accelerator. The engine can be paired with either a six-speed automatic transmission or a six-speed manual. The downside of this sportier handling is that the Mazda 6’s ride isn’t quite as plush as that of some of its competitors, but we think the compromise is worth it.

Even the base (Sport) model comes well equipped, with seventeen-inch wheels, a tilt-and-telescope steering wheel, cruise control, and power accessories. The Grand Touring gets all of the above plus unique nineteen-inch wheels, leather, an eight-way heated power driver’s seat with lumbar adjustment, and LED running lights. In any iteration, the Mazda 6 is worth a look if you value performance, fuel economy, and a wide selection of convenience features.

title: Requiem for a 1991 Volvo 740
subTitle: A fond farewell to Nigel, a real brick of a car.
promoTeaserSmall: A fond farewell to Nigel, a real brick of a car.
promoTeaser: A fond farewell to Nigel, a real brick of a car.
metaDescription: A fond farewell to Nigel, a real brick of a car.

contributors.bio: I am a car geek dating back to my childhood, when I took notice of the various sizes, shapes, and designs of cars. I named all of our family cars and cried when they reached the end of their useful life. I’ve been mentally composing automotive reviews for years, but it wasn’t until some years ago, when I read one of Jean Jennings's columns while waiting for an appointment, that I realized that it was possible. And here I am… grateful and enjoying every second. My next goal in life is to learn to drive a manual.

pageElements.text: It’s funny how certain cars will work their way into our hearts when we’re not looking. In my case, the culprit was a goofy, temperamental used 1991 Volvo 740 sedan that I named Nigel. A true brick of a car, Nigel came equipped with simple architecture for easy tinkering and a bomb-proof Volvo B230F in-line four-cylinder engine.
Nigel was in fine shape, with blue cloth upholstery that was like new, and that dorky, boxy charm that old Volvos have. He was the perfect sidekick.

The recession had hit, taking my job and savings with it. Money was tight. My previous car had been totaled by an errant teen driver, and I needed wheels. Nigel was in fine shape, with blue cloth upholstery that was like new, and that dorky, boxy charm that old Volvos have. He was well maintained.  All of his power amenities worked. This car was the perfect sidekick for my new adventures as an adult college student/part-time job warrior.

On a brilliant sunny morning this past March, I drove Nigel for the very last time.
He failed the tough California emissions test, and the repair costs would be astronomical. After exhausting every other option and getting a second opinion, I had to retire him to a salvage yard.

This was the car that had ferried friends and loved ones to outings and appointments, and shuttled me between campus an hour away and my two part-time jobs. I also experienced every human emotion at one time or another while driving Nigel: everything from deep sobs on the trip home from my best friend’s funeral four years ago to the mind-blowing joy of graduation day.

Over the past two years, Nigel began to fail. Odd electrical and mechanical glitches developed that stumped even my highly skilled Volvo tech and his team. Fuses blew. His heating and A/C went out. Nigel would stall or cut out completely without warning. Pleasure drives along the winding Ortega Highway or Pacific Coast Highway were out of the question.

Running errands or driving to work became a roll of the dice. If I could just nurse the old guy along until next year …but it was his failing emissions system and his overall age that got him in the end.
I washed Nigel the day before his final drive. I wanted the old guy to have some dignity, California drought restrictions be damned.

I washed Nigel the day before his final drive. I wanted the old guy to have some dignity, California drought restrictions be damned. Nigel had been my economic and social lifeline for the past seven years in a part of the country where public transit is an ineffective afterthought. I owed him this final act of tender loving care before relinquishing him to the salvage yard.
The place was hot, dusty, and noisy. There were piles of smashed and twisted remnants of cars. It was more of a vehicle slaughterhouse than a parts recycler.
They whisked him away while I was signing over the title. I turned back around seconds later to find him gone. Just like that. I didn’t even hear the engine start.
I burst into tears. The window clerk threw me a sideways glance. I must have looked pathetic. My lifeline was gone, along with so many memories.
Rest well, Nigel. You had a damn fine run. You will be missed.

contributors.bio:
Jean Knows Cars is not just the name of this website; it's a true fact. I have been writing about cars and the car business for more than 30 years, having learned about cars at the kitchen table from my late father, Robert Lienert, who was the editor of Automotive News. At age eighteen, I bought a used car, painted it yellow, installed a toplight and a meter, and joined the Yellow Cab Company in Ann Arbor, Michigan, as an owner/operator. Five years later, I got a job at Chrysler’s test track as a test driver, welder, and mechanic in the impact lab. In 1980, I was hired as a writer at Car and Driver magazine after getting laid off at Chrysler, and in 1985 I left to establish Automobile Magazine with David E. Davis, Jr. I was the magazine’s first Executive Editor, became Editor in Chief in 2000, and added the title of President of Automobile Magazine in 2006.

I’ve been profiled in The New Yorker and have been a guest on the Tonight Show with Jay Leno. I was a guest on the Oprah Winfrey Show, teaching Oprah and her studio audience how to change a tire and to jump a battery. I was Good Morning America’s automotive correspondent from 1994 to 2000 and then did the same thing for the Oxygen network.

 I have won awards for feature writing, car reviews, and my monthly Automobile Magazine column, “Vile Gossip,” including the 2007 Ken Purdy Award for Excellence in Automotive Journalism.  I’m a regular on-air contributor to Fox Business Network; CNBC’s Closing Bell, Squawk Box, Behind the Wheel, and Power Lunch; MSNBC; CBS This Morning and Evening News; and CNN’s American Morning and Headline News. In fact, I would almost call myself a TV slut, but I’m proud to say that I turned Geraldo down.

All of this has taken place in a male-dominated automotive space, where I’m all too frequently the only woman in the room. I know the secret handshake, but JeanKnowsCars.com is going to be a place where you don’t have to. 

I live in the Michigan countryside with my husband, Tim, and the entire food chain. You’re going to get to know my driveway and my dogs really, really well. Just keep reading.
