Some people think of mid-size sedans like the 2016 Mazda 6 and its competitors as boring. Maybe it’s just because you see them everywhere. One in every seven new vehicles sold is a mid-size sedan, and there are actually a lot of great choices: the Toyota Camry, Honda Accord, Ford Fusion, Nissan Altima, Chrysler 200, and Chevrolet Malibu, among others. It’s true, they’re not sports cars, and when you grow up, get married, maybe have some children, you might think you have to settle for something a little more….practical.
Or do you?

Into this group slots the Mazda 6, which is one of the best-kept automotive secrets. (Car and Driver even recently named it one of the 10 Best Cars That Nobody Buys.) Introduced as Mazda’s top-level sedan in 2012, the Mazda 6 has been newly updated and restyled for 2016, and it’s a beauty. In fact, I’d go so far as to say that it’s the mid-size sedan to look at first if you want practicality that still sets your heart aflutter.

Because really, just one look at this sedan tells you that it has been unfairly ignored by the buying public. Mazda only sold 53,224 of them in 2014 in the United States. To compare the big sellers of the segment, Toyota Camry sales in the U.S. in 2014 were 404,484, including fleet and individual sales. Honda Accord sales were 360,089 in the same period.

Why is the Mazda 6 not a big seller? It’s not price: the base model, the Sport, starts at $22,315, undercutting many of its rivals by several hundred dollars. Even the top-of-the-line 2016 Mazda 6 Grand Touring starts at a reasonable $31,015. (All prices include destination charge.) The one we tried was the mid-level Touring, which came with only three minor options: the Soul Red paint color ($300), cargo mats ($75), and door-sill trim plates ($125). For its as-tested price just over $25,000, you get such high-end amenities as a seven-inch touchscreen display, a leather-wrapped steering wheel, LED taillights, a rearview camera, blind spot monitoring, and rear cross-traffic alert, all standard.

And then there’s the design. This new model made its debut at the Los Angeles Auto Show last November, showing the latest version of Mazda’s “Kodo: Soul of Motion” design philosophy. Put simply, “Kodo” refers to the moment that energy turns into motion. Look at the sides of the Mazda 6: do you see that dynamic crossing sweep of lines, feeding from the rear haunches into the arching front fenders? Where many other sedans are competent, even attractive, this one has a beautiful, balanced energy.

On a more practical level, the Mazda 6 suffers a little from a lack of power. Carried over from the 2015 model year, its 2.5-liter four-cylinder makes 184 horsepower, decent but not brilliant. Its six-speed automatic transmission is a carry-over, too. But our test car’s six-speed manual allowed us to get the most excitement from the engine in every gear.
Unlike several competitors (Honda Accord, Toyota Camry, Hyundai Sonata, Ford Fusion), Mazda offers no hybrid or plug-in electric version.
Just one look at this sedan tells you that it has been unfairly ignored by the buying public.

What the numbers don’t show is how well Mazda’s Skyactiv technology makes every system in the car work together to get the most out of them all. The result is a wonderful balance that you feel when you drive this car. I drove hundreds of miles in the Mazda 6 in one sitting and could have driven hundreds more.

You feel that great balance when you sit inside, too. Updates to the cabin for 2016 included better sound insulation for a quieter ride, a dashboard that’s totally new and opens up space in the cabin, an electric parking brake to replace the old manual hand brake—a first for a Mazda—and even a new off-white leather option as an alternative to an attractive but more commonplace-looking black interior.
The exterior includes a new grille and a set of nineteen-inch aluminum wheels with a darker high-gloss paint.

Standard safety features are carried over from the 2015 model year. On the 2016 Touring model, these include six airbags, a rearview camera, anti-lock brakes, dynamic stability control, traction control, rear cross-traffic alert, and a blind spot monitoring system. On the Grand Touring model, there’s an optional Technology package ($1,675). It includes Smart Brake Support, which helps to avoid frontal collisions at medium to high speeds, and adaptive headlights. The Technology package also includes fuel-saving i-Eloop regenerative engine braking, which boosts fuel economy to 28 mpg city/40 mpg highway. It’s worthwhile, but it also requires you to select the moonroof/Bose audio/satellite radio package at an added $1,325, taking this car up to a loftier price point.

Infotainment and connectivity are important to anyone buying a new car these days. The ability to use infotainment without distraction is essential, and Mazda Connect offers that. The Mazda 6’s seven-inch touchscreen stands up above the dash, with bright and easy-to-use icons across the bottom of the screen for the passenger (or parked driver) to access. Steering-wheel-mounted controls let you manage the radio, smartphone, and navigation functions while you’re driving. Navigation, though, is standard only on the top Grand Touring model.

But the bottom line is, what are you looking for in a sedan? If you choose one of the really big sellers, nobody would blame you. But if you do that without getting behind the wheel of this one and taking it out for a drive, just to see if it fits you the way it totally fit me, you might end up blaming yourself.

The Equus Signature has as many standard features as a prairie dog town has holes. pageElements.text:
Laura Sky Brown: Staying with the Surface Streets

I am a pretty impatient person (and driver). I know this about myself. So one reason I love to take the back roads is that it's therapeutic for my personality type. That's especially true when I'm driving somewhere more than fifteen minutes but less than an hour away. This may have started during a youthful stint at Automobile Magazine in the 1980s, when I lived out in the countryside and used the half-hour's drive on state roads to unwind from my day and get home to my garden relaxed. I still like to seek out a less popular way to get where I'm going and have more road to myself.

There's so much to recommend taking the back roads when you can. There's less traffic, there's more variation in road types, and there's more to look at. What better way to appreciate driving a car than out there on the back roads, rather than striding alongside a bunch of trucks? I admit there is sometimes a bottleneck, or some slowpoke up ahead, but unlike the freeway, where you're trapped in case of a traffic jam, there is virtually always an alternate route or shortcut.
What better way to appreciate driving a car than out there on the back roads, rather than striding alongside a bunch of trucks?

And then there's winter, which lasts four to six months here. I'd so much rather be on the two-lane country road sliding around in company with only a few other vehicles than with the maniacs on the freeway who follow too closely and think their SUVs (and themselves) are immortal.

Molly Jean and I have a running disagreement about this, because we both commute to our office in rural Chelsea, Michigan, a distance of about fourteen miles each way from our homes. She gets on the highway because it's faster. She is missing out. I get to enjoy farm fields, cows, winding roads, an A&W stand, bridges, and silos on my way to the office. Yes, it takes longer than the straight stretch of I-94 that she drives on. I can't think of a single other attribute of the highway drive that is preferable.

Molly Jean: Heading for the Interstate

The Interstate system was created to make it safer to get from point A to point B, and that is precisely what I am trying to do when I drive to work each day. I am always running late and do not have time to enjoy a leisurely, bucolic drive to work. The alternative country drive is enticing. It is a lovely drive through a charming town and livestock-dotted farmland. But I consider this a business transaction, and I need to keep emotions out of the equation.

The simple truth is that highway driving is safer. According to the Federal Highway Administration, “The Interstate System is the safest road system in the country, with a fatality rate of 0.8 per 100 million vehicle miles, compared with 1.46 for all roads in 2004.” This is a dramatic reduction from the 6.05 national fatality rate when the Interstate Construction Program began in 1956.

When you are on the highway, you don't have to worry about intersections, bicycles, pedestrians, or oncoming drivers distracted by texting and making their next viral GoPro video. But the very best argument is that all the traffic is headed in the same direction, so a head-on accident is much less likely. Adding to my arsenal of safety, Michigan has invested heavily in median cable guardrails to help eliminate cross-median crashes.
I consider this a business transaction, and I need to keep emotions out of the equation. The simple truth is that highway driving is safer.

Both route options, Laura's and mine, add up to about the same mileage, but the stop-and-go nature of the rural route makes me steer toward the Interstate for my daily drive. This stretch of highway is not crowded at any time of the day, and I must admit that I push my speedometer north of legal on my commute. Honestly, I just want to get home and see my daughter, husband, and puppy. On days when I have a little extra time, I meander through the back roads. Then I am not as frustrated when I am stuck behind a Sunday driver, or worse, a distracted driver.
Also, I think everyone who is afraid of the highway is creeping along on the side streets of America. Not that I'm suggesting Laura is afraid, or creeping....just on the losing side of this argument.

contributors.bio:
Jean Knows Cars is not just the name of this website; it's a true fact. I have been writing about cars and the car business for more than 30 years, having learned about cars at the kitchen table from my late father, Robert Lienert, who was the editor of Automotive News. At age eighteen, I bought a used car, painted it yellow, installed a toplight and a meter, and joined the Yellow Cab Company in Ann Arbor, Michigan, as an owner/operator. Five years later, I got a job at Chrysler’s test track as a test driver, welder, and mechanic in the impact lab. In 1980, I was hired as a writer at Car and Driver magazine after getting laid off at Chrysler, and in 1985 I left to establish Automobile Magazine with David E. Davis, Jr. I was the magazine’s first Executive Editor, became Editor in Chief in 2000, and added the title of President of Automobile Magazine in 2006.

I’ve been profiled in The New Yorker and have been a guest on the Tonight Show with Jay Leno. I was a guest on the Oprah Winfrey Show, teaching Oprah and her studio audience how to change a tire and to jump a battery. I was Good Morning America’s automotive correspondent from 1994 to 2000 and then did the same thing for the Oxygen network.

 I have won awards for feature writing, car reviews, and my monthly Automobile Magazine column, “Vile Gossip,” including the 2007 Ken Purdy Award for Excellence in Automotive Journalism.  I’m a regular on-air contributor to Fox Business Network; CNBC’s Closing Bell, Squawk Box, Behind the Wheel, and Power Lunch; MSNBC; CBS This Morning and Evening News; and CNN’s American Morning and Headline News. In fact, I would almost call myself a TV slut, but I’m proud to say that I turned Geraldo down.

All of this has taken place in a male-dominated automotive space, where I’m all too frequently the only woman in the room. I know the secret handshake, but JeanKnowsCars.com is going to be a place where you don’t have to. 

I live in the Michigan countryside with my husband, Tim, and the entire food chain. You’re going to get to know my driveway and my dogs really, really well. Just keep reading.

Fun-O-Meter: 7.5
Swedishness has always been an important part of Volvo’s charm. In the 1980s I tried hard to become an honorary Swede during my visits to test drive cars in the homeland.

It’s kind of exciting for me to be sliding in behind the wheel of Volvo’s new XC90. Volvo and I go back a long long way to one of my very first European press trips, decades ago, where I learned that the name Volvo means “I Roll” in Latin, and that the Swedish car company had been in existence since 1927.

Let’s face it, Swedishness has always been an important part of Volvo’s charm. Back in the 1980s, I tried very hard to become an honorary Swede during my visits to test drive cars in the homeland. I drank Linie brand Acquavit (sent by ship around the world in Spanish olorosa sherry casks, crossing the Equator twice to mature the liquor to barely drinkable status) and bravely sipped the brutal, absinthe-based and dirty-sock-stinking Bäska Droppar (Yuck! Gack! Thwtt!), and in the process, learned the formal protocol of holding my drink mid-chest whilst toasting my drinking companions, never breaking eye contact while throwing back the entire shot and coming back to center, lest one of them knife me in mid Skol! (which means skull, as in that of the king they’d just knifed, and then decapitated so they’d have something to hold their victory Bäska Droppar).

And then we would all sing “Helan Går!” (similar to that old midwest college favorite, “Drink, chug-a-lug, chug-a-lug, chug-a-lug!”). I loved everything Swedish back then. Yes indeed, I also rolled!

But I digress.

The introduction of the 2016 Volvo XC90 AWD seven-passenger mid-size sport utility vehicle is momentous. It replaces a car that has been sold here since 2002. Seriously! It boggles the mind to think of the churn the automotive universe has experienced in those ensuing thirteen years.

After eleven years of ownership, Ford sold Volvo in 2010 at a staggering $4 billion loss—shockingly—to Chinese company Geely. The British head of Volvo Design, Peter Horbury, stayed on, becoming senior vice-president of design for Geely Group, which gave Volvo a degree of design continuity.

This second-generation XC90 becomes the first all-new model from the new Volvo (designed under the direction of Thomas Ingenlath). It is made entirely in Sweden.
And somewhere along the line, the new XC90 left its sensible shoes behind and put on its best party clothes. The XC90 is now one of the most luxurious, most opulently outfitted and exquisitely detailed mid-sized utes you can buy.

The face of the 2016 XC90 is immediately recognizable by its logo, a circle with a diagonal upward arrow—the Roman symbol for the planet Mars and, yes, the universal symbol of maleness. The new Volvo logo is modernized, beautifully integrating the arrow into Volvo’s traditional diagonal chrome grille slash as it was in 1927. “Thor’s hammer” running lights finish the strong front face with a bold T pattern, the coolest look since BMW’s “angel eyes” headlamp rings.

Volvo’s interior design chief Tisha Johnson refers to the XC90’s overall cabin vibe as Scandinavian Sanctuary, invoking several classic artisanal references, from the simple organic warmth of Danish Modern chairs to the stark yet curvaceous beauty of an Iitala glass vase. It is all there: thin, supportive seats covered in gorgeous Nappa leather (part of our test car’s $5,600 Inscription package), and light open-pore wood trim (the Inscription package sported walnut inlays). Just south of the shifter lies the engine’s tidy metal on-off knob, knurled in a diamond pattern, and below that, a roller switch that allows you to choose between four drive modes—Eco, Comfort, Off-Road, and Dynamic.

A very responsive nine-inch touchscreen screen with natural-speech voice control is vertically situated at mid-dash, and its controls line the left edge of the home page for ease of operation by the driver. The location of the touch buttons can be moved. An infrared layer allows gloved fingers to operate the controls.

The attention to seat design and packaging pays off. The XC90 is a true seven-passenger. The second row can be fitted with Volvo’s superb two-stage integrated child booster seat (celebrating its twenty-fifth anniversary) in the center position for an extra $250. The third row boasts what Volvo calls “class leading” third-row legroom. You want to be under 5’7” to feel really comfy back there, though. Both second and third rows are tiered for better forward visibility, and all seven seats use the same three-point safety belts with pretensioners, and the same headrests. Surprising standard features like a panoramic moonroof with motorized sunshade, heated front seats, hands-free power liftgate, and a rearview camera make the XC90’s $49,895 base price seem like a bargain.
Volvo is convinced Americans don’t really need big engines. “We have moved the saved money into the cabin,” says Michael Fleiss, vice-president of powertrain engineering.

Before my three-hour Southern California test drive from urban Santa Monica to rugged Ojai, I learned that Volvo will only be using four-cylinder engines in the XC, and of no greater than 2.0 liters’ displacement. Say what? Right. Volvo moves from using eight different engines across its line to only two—one gasoline and one diesel—sharing 50 percent of their parts. The XC90 does not get the diesel in the U.S., but its gasoline engine (mated to an eight-speed automatic transmission) produces a highly adequate 316 horsepower and 295 pound-feet of torque, wants premium fuel, and delivers 20 mpg in city driving and 25 mpg on the highway. The gasoline engine is both supercharged and turbocharged, taking care of moving the fairly heavy (4,627 pounds) all-wheel-drive XC90 off the line from a stop, and giving you reasonable passing power. Nothing crazy here, other than that Volvo is convinced we Americans (who, it says, spend an average of 23 days a year commuting) don’t really need big engines. “We have moved the saved money into the cabin,” says Michael Fleiss, vice-president of powertrain engineering, late of Bentley and Volkswagen.

Can you say “Autonomous cars”? Coming. Believe it. Right here, right now, the XC90 has Queue Assist which, using adaptative cruise control, can follow the car in front of you during slow stop-and-go traffic. It goes, it stops, it turns. You give yourself a manicure. I couldn’t bring myself to test it.

This leads us directly to Volvo’s unchanged commitment to safety. Now, there’s commitment and then there’s Volvo’s stated goal that, by the year 2020, no one will be killed or seriously injured in a new Volvo vehicle. To that end, the XC90 has more safety features than any vehicle you can name, most of which are standard, and two of which are new world-firsts. Volvo already boasts auto braking functions to prevent collisions with cars, bikes, and pedestrians. It now adds auto braking at intersections when the driver turns in front of an oncoming car. Sound like a familiar scenario? I actually experienced those autobrakes when my XC90 determined I was being a little too aggressive in the intersection while preparing for a left turn and those voodoo brakes stopped me cold. It got my attention, believe me. You can see the merit.

The second world-first feature in the XC90 is called Safe Positioning, developed to prevent deaths and injuries resulting from cars running off the road. Half of all traffic fatalities in the U.S. are from road departure accidents. Volvo’s response is twofold. First, the car recognizes when you’re heading off road, and the front safety belts are immediately tightened to keep the occupants squared up and held tightly in their seats until the car isn’t moving. The second piece is an extra layer of energy-absorbing material between the seats and their frames to help cushion against spinal injuries from the extreme vertical forces that can happen in a hard landing.

Speaking of hard landings, our test car had all of this, plus another $16,810 of optional equipment. The $5,600 Inscription package ramps up the base Momentum to mid-level luxury, notable for the Nappa leather and walnut trim. The Vision package ($1,600) brings in the amazing 360-degree surround-view camera. Using it to locate yourself precisely in a tight space is like an out-of-body experience. Add the Convenience package ($1,800), and you can let the XC90 park itself in both parallel and perpendicular slots. This is also where you find the adaptive cruise control with Queue Assist, if you want even more time at the wheel without actually touching it.

I’m not so sure the Climate package (with head-up display) is worth $1,950, as much as I like a heated steering wheel, and I personally would wait a couple of years before I spent $1,800 on the four-corner air suspension. But I am all over that $2,500 Bowers & Wilkins sound system. In Swedish terms, it can re-create the sound of the Gothenberg Concert Hall. I can only attest that Pink Floyd’s The Wall worked for me.
The 2016 Volvo XC90 goes on sale shortly, but not before Volvo recalled a couple hundred for a potential air bag problem just this week. It sounds minor, but better safe than sorry.

The pent-up demand in the U.S. for a new XC90 is real. Volvo released a limited run of 568 special-edition XC90s in late 2014. They sold out in forty-seven hours. Pre-orders have topped 30,000, accounting for 15 percent of Volvo’s first-year sales goal for the new SUV. Later in the year, Volvo will release a sport R-Design version of the XC90, and a state of the art Twin Engine Plug-In hybrid ($68,100 plus destination) that it is speaking of as a Tesla beater.

Why the pent-up demand, in a marketplace that is rife with luxury rides? I think it’s because there are actually only a few vehicles out there, particularly in this entry-luxury price range, that do so many things so well and with such elegance and quality. This new Volvo offers the very latest in safety and technology surrounded by the very best in materials, and all without a hint of tackiness. There is no doubt that Volvo’s new XC90 is already a modern classic.

contributors.bio: I'm the auto and motorcycle critic for the Orange County Register. Previously, I  was a staff writer at the Los Angeles Times for fourteen years, writing about motorcycles, cars, green living, and anything else that caught my fancy. Originally from Ann Arbor, Michigan, I currently live in Los Angeles with my ten-year-old son.

pageElements.text:
2016 Hyundai Sonata Plug-in Hybrid Limited

Type: Five-passenger, front-wheel-drive mid-size sedan
Price: Not yet announced
Availability: California, Connecticut, Maine, Maryland, Massachusetts, New Jersey, New York, Oregon, Rhode Island, and Vermont
Engine: 2.0-liter four-cylinder, 202 horsepower, with synchronous electric motor and 9.8-kilowatt-hour lithium-ion battery
Transmission: Six-speed automatic
Fuel economy: 24 miles of range on electric only; 93 MPGe (electric + gasoline mode); 40 mpg combined
Recharge time: Less than three hours (using level 2 charger)
You might also be considering (prices include destination charges): 2015 Honda Accord Plug-In ($40,600); 2016 Ford Fusion Energi ($34,725)
<iframe width="560" height="315" src="https://www.youtube.com/embed/_c3Glbx0SXU" frameborder="0" allowfullscreen></iframe>
Low gas prices have helped pickup trucks wheel off dealer floors almost as fast as automakers can build them. Hybrids? Not so much. Sales have stagnated along with pump prices.

But it isn’t likely to stay that way. When it comes to cars, what falls out of favor eventually returns, meaning Hyundai might actually be perfectly poised when its first-ever plug-in hybrid Sonata hits the market this fall.

The Korean automaker has long offered its mid-size sedan as a regular hybrid that operates a gasoline engine and electric motor in tandem to increase fuel economy. For 2016, that hybrid has been updated with a smaller 2.0-liter gasoline engine paired with a more powerful electric motor that together yield 42 mpg combined.

For 2016, ten states that follow California emissions standards will get another choice. The 2015 plug-in hybrid electric vehicle, or PHEV, version of the Sonata uses the same powertrain but allows it to operate using just its electric motor and lithium-ion batteries for even better mpg. Hyundai estimates that the 2016 Sonata PHEV will yield up to 93 mpg equivalent.

That’s lot of gas money that can be diverted toward groceries among Hyundai’s value-oriented buyership. Pricing hasn’t yet been announced, but the PHEV Sonata will be the most expensive version. For 2015, the gasoline-powered Sonata started at $21,975, its hybrid stablemate $30,325. Industry analysts expect the PHEV to be priced slightly less than its main rivals, the Honda Accord Plug-In and the Ford Fusion Energi.
The Sonata PHEV's larger battery has an economic side benefit: It also yields a bigger federal tax credit from the government ($4,919).

Designed to offer even more bang for the buck than its competition, the Sonata PHEV uses a comparatively large 9.8-kWh lithium-ion battery that enables it to travel up to twenty-four miles as a pure electric vehicle, versus thirteen miles of electric range for the Honda Accord and twenty-one for the Ford Fusion. The larger battery has an economic side benefit: It also yields a bigger federal tax credit from the government ($4,919).

Efficiency being one of the main goals in developing the Sonata PHEV, Hyundai forces it on drivers by running through its electric miles first unless instructed to do otherwise. Among the many buttons in its well-laid-out cockpit are those marked EV and HEV. Press EV, and the car is pleasingly sprightly and surprisingly quiet. Best for city driving, its top EV-only speed is 75 mph. Press HEV, and it will drive as a hybrid to maintain its battery charge level. Best used for monotonous highway driving, HEV saves its EV capacity for when it’s most effective: at lower, city speeds.

Either way, the Sonata PHEV can travel up to 605 miles on a single tank, making it more similar to a diesel in terms of range.
More futuristic-looking than the gas-powered Sonata, the hybrid uses “eco,” or flat-spoke, wheels that allow wind to travel past them without swirling in their spokes.

Part of the reason it’s able to travel so far is aerodynamics. Hyundai boasts that the Sonata PHEV’s aerodynamics are as efficient as the Tesla Model S. More futuristic-looking than the gas-powered Sonata, the hybrid uses so-called “eco,” or flat-spoke, wheels that allow wind to travel past them without swirling in their spokes. The wind also enjoys smooth passage under the car and around the sharp corner edges of its bumpers.

With the exception of its dash and eight-inch touchscreen, the interior is the same as that in the gasoline-powered Sonata. That is to say, it’s more luxurious than one would think for its price. Hyundai has a habit of exceeding expectations, and the Sonata PHEV was no exception.

Granted, I was driving the more opulent of its two trims: the Limited, which adds advanced safety features like blind spot monitoring, lane keeping assistance, and forward collision warning and upgrades the heated and ventilated seats to leather. Those seats were comfortable even after driving 200 miles in a single day, as I did. And they were exceptionally roomy, even in the rear with the front seats pushed all the way back.

The Sonata Hybrid will be available nationwide this summer. The plug-in hybrid version will go on sale in the fall, starting in California and Oregon before being rolled out to Connecticut, Maine, Maryland, Massachusetts, New Jersey, New York, Rhode Island and Vermont. Customers who live in other states can still buy the PHEV. They just need to special order it.

Notable standard features on this model: Daytime running lights, heated power-operated side mirrors with driver’s blind-spot mirror, air conditioning, stain-resistant cloth fabric
Notable options on this model: All-wheel drive, hands-free smart liftgate with automatic opening, dual-zone climate controls, Proximity Key entry with pushbutton start, 19-inch wheels, panoramic sunroof, parking assistance, heated and cooled front seats, heated rear seats, heated steering wheel, 8-inch touchscreen, navigation, rearview camera
You might also be considering: Chevrolet Equinox, Dodge Journey, Kia Sorento

The Hyundai Santa Fe, one of the pioneers among crossover utility vehicles, just keeps getting better: handsomer, more refined, and more loaded with features. This year, improvements to the electrically assisted power steering along with a slightly stiffened suspension enhance the Santa Fe’s drivability. Front- or available all-wheel drive with 5-, 6-, or 7-passenger, three-row configuration are the choices for this crossover. Electronic chassis controls include selectable steering effort, now with a firmer Sport setting, and a smart all-wheel-drive system with active cornering control. The 6-passenger setup has two captain’s chairs instead of the standard 40/20/40 split-folding and reclining middle-row bench; this setup is only offered as part of the Ultimate package, available with either GLS or Limited trim. The Premium package for the Santa Fe GLS adds such conveniences and luxuries as Proximity Key entry with pushbutton start, leather upholstery, and the hands-free power liftgate. Navigation and a heated steering wheel and rear seats, as well as cooled front seats, are included in the GLS Ultimate package. The Limited Ultimate throws in HID headlamps, LED tail lamps, and a killer 12-speaker audio system. Under the hood in all trim levels is the direct-injection 3.3-liter V-6 that produces 290 horsepower. Clamp on a trailer hitch, and the Santa Fe will tow up to 5,000 pounds. Hill start assist and downhill brake control help to manage the load. Stability and traction control are standard. Lane change assist and blind spot detection with rear cross-traffic alert are available, along with rear parking assist. Like every other Hyundai, the Santa Fe has a high surprise and delight factor, delivers great performance, and represents a good value.

New for 2015

Refined steering and suspension systems, daytime running lights, driver’s blind spot mirror, auto up/down front passenger power window, available hands-free power-operated liftgate, Sparkling Silver and Platinum Graphite added to list of available paint colors.

Trim level: RLX, RLX with Navigation, RLX with Technology Package, RLX with Krell Audio Package, RLX with Advance Package, RLX Sport Hybrid (2014 model)
Engine: 3.5-liter V-6, 310 horsepower
Transmission: 6-speed automatic
Fuel economy: 20 mpg city/31 mpg highway
Safety ratings: Insurance Institute for Highway Safety: Top Safety Pick Plus; National Highway Traffic Safety Administration: 5/5 stars
Our favorite standard feature: Navigation system with 3-D view
Notable standard features on this model: Power moonroof, forward-collision warning, lane-departure warning, rearview camera
Notable options on this model: Adaptive cruise control with low-speed follow, fourteen-speaker Krell audio system, heated rear seats
You might also be considering: Audi A6, BMW 5 Series, Cadillac CTS, Mercedes-Benz E-Class

Acura’s top-of-the-line sedan has never been a big seller against such powerhouses as the BMW 5 Series, Mercedes-Benz E-Class, and Audi A6. However, that hasn’t discouraged Honda’s upscale division, which continues to add features to the RLX to elevate its level of technology and sophistication. There are four trim levels/packages—Navigation, Technology, Advance, and Krell Audio—and one powertrain, a 310-horsepower V-6 mated to a six-speed automatic transmission. There is also a Sport Hybrid version, but it is not technically a 2015 model. It continues to be sold in dealerships, but since it came out late in the 2014 model year, it continues with that designation. The hybrid powertrain produces 377 horsepower and gets 30 mpg in combined city/highway driving. A redesigned Sport Hybrid with all-wheel drive is scheduled to go on sale for 2016.

The RLX doesn’t carry the prestige of its European competitors, nor does it have their wider selection of powertrains. Driving the RLX is not a revelation, either, but its V-6 engine powerful enough, and it delivers a smooth ride. Where the RLX excels is with its spacious interior, which has generous legroom for back-seat passengers and features a wide array of high-tech features. Forward-collision and lane-departure warning systems and a multi-view rear camera are standard, and a collision mitigation braking system and lane-keeping assist are available. Also available with the Advance package is an adaptive cruise control system with low-speed follow, which automatically slows the car without any input from the driver when traffic necessitates braking. The RLX is being updated for 2016, so you can probably negotiate a good deal on a 2015 model.

New for 2015

There is no 2015 RLX Hybrid, although the 2014 Hybrid, which came out late in the model year, will continue to be sold.

How do you subtract two, add one, and come up with a larger number than you started with? Here’s how Acura did it: For 2015, the TL and TSX models were shelved and replaced with the TLX. Results? For the first two months of 2015, comparing year-over-year sales, the TLX outsold the other two models combined.

Of course, it helps that the TLX has a lot to recommend it. Positioned between the entry ILX and the flagship RLX, the TLX delivers a mix of sportiness and luxury. There are two available powertrains, a four-cylinder with an eight-speed automatic transmission and a V-6 with a nine-speed auto. All-wheel steering is standard with front-wheel drive models, and all-wheel drive is optional with the V-6 engine. The base TLX comes well equipped, with heated seats and side mirrors, a power moonroof, satellite radio, and LED head- and taillights. For even more features, such as navigation with 3D view and HD Radio, you can upgrade to the Technology and Advance packages

Slightly smaller than the TL, the TLX is built on an all-new platform, and the body is made of rigid, lightweight materials that emphasize driving dynamics and collision safety. In addition, wind, road, and engine noise have been reduced compared with the TL, thanks to triple door seals and extra body sealing and sound-absorbing materials. All TLXs also feature Acura’s Integrated Dynamics System (IDS), which offers four modes – Econ, Normal, Sport, and Sport+ — for drivers to adjust steering firmness, throttle response, and shifting patterns.

New for 2015

The TLX is an all-new model for 2015.

contributors.bio:
Jean Knows Cars is not just the name of this website; it's a true fact. I have been writing about cars and the car business for more than 30 years, having learned about cars at the kitchen table from my late father, Robert Lienert, who was the editor of Automotive News. At age eighteen, I bought a used car, painted it yellow, installed a toplight and a meter, and joined the Yellow Cab Company in Ann Arbor, Michigan, as an owner/operator. Five years later, I got a job at Chrysler’s test track as a test driver, welder, and mechanic in the impact lab. In 1980, I was hired as a writer at Car and Driver magazine after getting laid off at Chrysler, and in 1985 I left to establish Automobile Magazine with David E. Davis, Jr. I was the magazine’s first Executive Editor, became Editor in Chief in 2000, and added the title of President of Automobile Magazine in 2006.

I’ve been profiled in The New Yorker and have been a guest on the Tonight Show with Jay Leno. I was a guest on the Oprah Winfrey Show, teaching Oprah and her studio audience how to change a tire and to jump a battery. I was Good Morning America’s automotive correspondent from 1994 to 2000 and then did the same thing for the Oxygen network.

 I have won awards for feature writing, car reviews, and my monthly Automobile Magazine column, “Vile Gossip,” including the 2007 Ken Purdy Award for Excellence in Automotive Journalism.  I’m a regular on-air contributor to Fox Business Network; CNBC’s Closing Bell, Squawk Box, Behind the Wheel, and Power Lunch; MSNBC; CBS This Morning and Evening News; and CNN’s American Morning and Headline News. In fact, I would almost call myself a TV slut, but I’m proud to say that I turned Geraldo down.

All of this has taken place in a male-dominated automotive space, where I’m all too frequently the only woman in the room. I know the secret handshake, but JeanKnowsCars.com is going to be a place where you don’t have to. 

I live in the Michigan countryside with my husband, Tim, and the entire food chain. You’re going to get to know my driveway and my dogs really, really well. Just keep reading.

pageElements.text: If you have business at Dan Gurney’s All American Racers in Santa Ana, California, and you haven’t been there in a while, you will still find it to be the world’s finest tribute to the life and times of Daniel Sexton Gurney. But it is even more so, having just undergone an almost total renovation. It was most certainly overseen by Evi, the queen of Porsche public relations when Dan met her while racing for Porsche in Europe, and most definitely the queen of his castle ever since their marriage in 1969. One of those love stories for the ages, you can be assured.
My business was lunch, but I thought you might like a little glimpse of what I saw on my way to the dining room...

His story—their story—is everywhere you look. It begins when you step through the front door, over a triple row of bricks, and into the lobby. Because the bricks are from that Brickyard. The wall to the left is covered with a photo of Dan driving his most famous car, the 1967 Eagle Formula 1 car (with a Gurney Weslake engine) that he drove to victory at the 1967 Belgian Grand Prix at Spa-Francorchamps, the only American ever to have won an F1 race in a car of his own manufacture. (Note: This photo was a re-creation of the race, commissioned by Road & Track in 2002 in honor of the thirty-fifth anniversary of Dan’s victory. It is Spa-Francorchamps, it is the real car, Dan is seventy-one years old, and he is driving 161 mph. Gulp.)

Kathy Weida, vice president, and employee here for six years longer than I’ve been in this business, is sitting behind a gleaming counter/display case topped with glass sandwiched carbon fiber, designed by the president and CEO of AAR, Justin Gurney, who also launched the renovation of his parents' business. He was made general manager in 1992 after having worked in various departments while still in high school and college. A bench made of three racing seats stitched with the red AAR logo and the end tables at either end are also Gurney originals, as are most of the desks and cabinets throughout the front offices. Highly covetable, not for sale.

The hallways are floor-to-ceiling photo galleries that will stop you dead in the middle of your first step, built over the years of snapshots of the Gurneys’ long illustrious lives—race moments, cars, podiums, planes, motorcycles, friends, families, and never before seen photos of  prominent motorsports personalities as well  as drivers who fielded Eagle cars through the decades in Formula 1, IndyCar, Trans-Am, and IMSA, among them sixty-six factory team pilots. If you had never heard of Dan Gurney, you would quickly gravitate to his beaming, all-American goodness shining from many photos. Dan at eighty-four is the same Dan seen at age nineteen with a broad smile and big wave next to his 1950 Bonneville C-mod roadster, with friends outside of Ruby’s diner in Riverside, where the family moved after Dan graduated from high school in Long Island in 1948. A huge blowup of the photo hangs out in the shop.

In between the front office and the shop is their pride and joy, a dedicated museum space holding a robust collection of Dan’s most important cars, cars AAR built, campaigned, and fielded for other drivers as well as cars Dan raced himself, including his 1967 Eagle which took second place at Indy, restored and presented to him by his sons on his eighty-fourth birthday this past April. There is the car Dan drove to a win in the 1967 and 1968 Rex Mays 300, a race for Indy cars at the old Riverside track.

Dan’s favorite car here is the 1981 Pepsi Challenger Eagle Chevy that qualified mid-front row at Indy. My favorite might be the 1992-93 Eagle Mk-III GTP car which won twenty-one of twenty-eight races, seventeen of them consecutively. The wins included two 12 hour Sebring victories as well as two IMSA Daytona Prototype Championships. Same car.

Covering the south wall is “Dan Gurney’s Racing Career 1955-1970”—an impressively precise grid of fifteen vertical rows each comprised of six framed photos under a list of Dan’s races and finishing positions for each of fifteen years. Highlights of each race are captioned on the photos, and the seven pictures framed in red denote Dan’s Formula 1 victories.

Dan’s impressive collection of other cool stuff includes a couple old doors from his Gasoline Alley garage at Indy, and the very bottle of champagne that launched an enduring winner’s circle tradition. Yes, it was Dan Gurney, so overcome with joy in delivering America’s first 24 Hours of Le Mans win to Ford in 1967, that he shook the big bottle of winner’s bubbly and let it fly instead of drinking it: “I was so stoked when they handed me the magnum of Moët et Chandon, I shook the bottle and began spraying at the photographers, the drivers, Henry Ford II, Carroll Shelby, and their wives.”

Many of racing history’s most famous shots of Dan in action have also become wall coverings and large poster-sized prints hung throughout AAR’s back shop areas. There is no chance that any visitor—including an alien dropping in from outer space to tap into the vast body of high performance racing and aerospace knowledge contained inside this building—would not recognize the hero of this incredible story.

All American Racers today is more than a museum or a race shop. In the past fifteen years, it has morphed into a high-tech modern carbon-composite establishment. In different buildings on the campus, 165 employees work on manufacturing projects for the aerospace industry like SpaceX, the aviation industry, special order racing cars like the Deltawing as well as design and development of motorcycles and multi-purpose engines.

That’s it for the tour. We had a lot of gossip to catch up on in the year since I’d last visited. There is no lull in any conversation around a table full of Gurneys, and Justin and his younger brother, former racer, twice IMSA Daytona Prototype champion, and AAR senior vice-president, Alex, both of whom I’ve known since they were kids, added to the hubbub and excitement, talking about the upcoming Indianapolis 500. They would be joining their older half-brothers, Jimmy and Danny Gurney, for a historic exhibition drive of four of their dad’s Indy Eagles. They were extra-psyched because their racing gloves had just arrived. Dan’s hearing is old school bad, so I added to the commotion by shouting a lot.
No one seemed to mind, least of all Dan.

Afterword:

Dan and his boys had a great time at Indy. Here is a picture with them (and the car each drove) with a few old buddies. From left: Jimmy Gurney (1968 Indy-winning Eagle), Justin Gurney (Dan’s second-place 1970 Indy Eagle), Arie Luyendyk, Dan, Al Unser, Sr., Johnny Rutherford, Alex Gurney (1973 Indy-winning Eagle), Danny Gurney (1983 Eagle Coors Light silver bullet), and Gil de Ferran.
If you missed it all, you can see Racer.com’s wonderful interview of their very charming, very emotional Pop.

pageElements.text:
Molly Says: Heavy! Taking Everything You Own on a Trip Is a Must

I believe in the Boy Scout motto “Be prepared.” When I leave home in the morning, I want to know the weather so that I can dress appropriately. My backpack is stuffed full of items that I may need: Swiss army knife, batteries, power cords, Band-Aids, etc. It is a tad heavy, but I am ready for whatever life throws at me.

1. Be prepared.

When it comes to packing for a road trip, I follow this same motto. It is difficult to pack for extreme weather fluctuations, and that is the Midwest’s middle name. So even in the summer I am compelled to bring warm clothes, and foul-weather gear is a must. Winter is even worse: heavy boots, heavy coats, layers and layers of clothes. When I am driving and have plenty of room, I bring extra of everything.
When I am driving and have plenty of room, I bring extra of everything.

2. Adventure awaits.

Vacation for me is generally action packed. At least half of my family’s vacations involve camping. Good luck packing light if you are camping. The camping gear (including such items as a cookstove, lamps, pots and pans, bug spray, picnic tablecloth, axe, and saw) alone fills a large Rubbermaid container, and that doesn’t include the tent, sleeping bags, chairs, cots, and all the miscellany of modern car camping. Depending on the season I may need snowshoes, skis, bikes, canoes, kayaks, or golf clubs. I may look like one of the vehicles that the Internet loves to make fun of, but vacations are short and I need to be on the move.

3. Go big or stay home.

I have invested in a car top carrier and a bike rack that fits in a hitch. Even though I bring everything but the kitchen sink, I want to have room to be comfortable in the car, so stowing some of my gear topside is essential. The tech that we take on our trips requires its own bag to organize all of our chargers, tablets, power cords, and cameras. We have another bag for fresh fruit and snacks to minimize our stops. My final ingredients for the perfect road trip are a blanket and pillow to cozy up my area. After all, if my house burns down while I’m gone I could live comfortably with everything I took on my long weekend.

Laura Says: Light! Taking Everything You Own on a Trip Is Soul-Crushing

Molly Jean and I differ on so many things, but perhaps our most fundamental car-related disagreement revolves around packing. Even though Molly is hot for minicars—she has a particular fixation on the Smart Fortwo, which doesn't even have a place for any luggage—she wants to take the entire contents of her house on even the shortest weekend excursion. "In case I might need something," she says. It's crazy talk, in my opinion.

There are three reasons I believe in packing light. None of them have to do with how much luggage capacity there is. I believe in the pack-light credo even if I am in a very large minivan or SUV that has room for all kinds of stuff.

1. Adventure.

Because life is too short, and travel is too special, to spend it obsessing over possessions. Here's my reasoning: You leave home to experience what's out there. If you are sorting and classifying multiple bags full of comfort and fashion items, your focus is removed from the adventure of being away. You can get nearly everything you'd need for an emergency at a pharmacy or grocery store. Other than emergencies, you can live without virtually everything else in your house for a few days. And, I think, you should. It's healthy.
If you are sorting and classifying multiple bags full of comfort and fashion items, your focus is removed from the adventure of being away.

2. Mobility and ease.

Even if you're driving the entire trip, you will presumably stop somewhere at night, and it's so nice to be able to manage your gear easily. Here's what I would do, if other occupants of my vehicle don't stop me: I'd take only one small backpack or overnight bag, and it would have one change of clothes, one change of shoes, and no more than five minimal toiletry products. I'd toss it in the back seat, and off I'd go. No packing up a pile of extra sweaters and coats; no first aid kits or hair dryers or coolers full of snacks. Definitely no "wardrobe choices" for each day. Roughing it is part of the fun of going on a car trip, I think. A couple of hours at a laundromat during a trip (they have great Wi-Fi) beats a couple of front-end hours of planning and filling suitcases any day.

3. Practicality.

Focus in on what you will really need on a trip. It's part of the planning exercise, something to do while you're sketching out your route and scheduling your activities. If you know deep in your soul that you can't just throw all your stuff in the car, you will do a better job of planning the trip. Think about what you really need—and what you really don't. That will help you put back the three extra pairs of shoes and the unnecessary toys and accessories, not to mention the cosmetic and medication overkill.

Sadly, unless I am traveling alone (which I like to do, by the way; traveling light also extends to how many people I'm packing in the car), other people don't often go along with my ultra-minimalist approach. So I do find myself bringing more things along than I'd prefer. That does not mean I'm not right about this, because I definitely am!

The BMW 3 Series is the quintessential German performance sedan. It has earned its place on nearly every top-ten or best-in-class list in the past two decades, and if there was an award for winning awards, the BMW 3 Series would probably take that title home, too. All this is to say that with its much-lauded dynamics, comfort, and performance, BMW has set the benchmark for performance sedans, and every manufacturer has it in its crosshairs. But beating BMW at its own game will be tough, since buyers can basically configure their 3 Series any way they like it. Shoppers can choose the sedan, wagon, or long wheel base hatchback, select either the standard rear-wheel drive or xDrive, choose a manual or automatic transmission, and pick from six engine options including a diesel and a hybrid, or go with the M3. You will pay dearly for all of these models, and that’s before you add your driver assistance and comfort packages, like navigation, a color head-up display, app integration, heated front and rear seats and steering wheel, a rearview camera, or adaptive headlights. But with its premium price come premium finishes. The interior is decidedly refined and spacious; the Luxury, Sport, and M Sport trim lines set different style tones; and a host of optional packages can make it one of the most technically advanced sedans out there. But any way it’s kitted out, it remains an attainable daily driver that has the versatility to switch instantly to a track car with a few setting changes.

New for 2015

Revised package features, new leather and material options, Comfort Access now includes the hands-free trunk closing function, and the M3 model is all new.

Part of luxury is the option to choose, and buyers of BMW’s biggest luxury sedan have plenty of options to choose from. The 7-series is available with six engine choices, including the standard turbocharged in-line six, a massively powerful V-12, and the more frugal diesel or hybrid powertrains. All are paired with an automatic 8-speed transmission, and can be had in either rear- or all-wheel drive. The amount of room to stretch in the cavernous rear seats is up to you with 38.9 or 44.3 cubic inches of legroom in the standard and long wheelbase models, respectively. What remains consistent throughout this model line is the profoundly quiet and smooth ride thanks to the enhanced cabin soundproofing, self-leveling air suspension, and dynamic damping control. As you would expect from a top-of-the-line luxury sedan, the interior is well-appointed and beautifully crafted, and includes four-zone climate control, navigation system, touchpad, 12-speaker audio, park assist technology, and dynamic cruise control among many other features. But surprisingly, comforts you take for granted in high-end rides, such as a heated steering wheel and head-up display are optional.

New diesel engine option, revisions to standard and optional features and packages.

The BMW X4 is for the unique buyer who likes the fastback look of a coupe—and is willing to sacrifice cargo capacity to get it—and yet doesn’t want to give up driving around on an elevated platform. Shorter and longer than the X3, the X4 offers the same engine options: either a turbocharged 3.0-liter six-cylinder engine with an output of 300 horsepower or a turbocharged 2.0-liter four-cylinder that produces 240 horsepower. Both are paired with an eight-speed automatic transmission, and its only available with all-wheel drive. One of the ways that the X4 differentiates itself from the X3 is decidedly reduced cargo capacity and complete disregard for rear passenger comfort. Behind the rear seats it offers only 17.7 cubic feet of cargo space and up to almost 50 cubic feet with the seats folded flat, compared to the 27.6/63.3 cubic feet in the X3. Passengers may feel a bit snug with only 34.8 cubic inches of legroom and 37.4 cubic inches of headroom in the rear, but that’s part of the tradeoff with a coupe-like vehicle, even in a so-called “Sport Activity Vehicle.”

New for 2015

The X4 is an all-new model for 2015.

With three powerful engine options in the X5 (four if you count the M series), most buyers will be picking this mid-size SUV for its performance on the road rather than off. The diesel engine, which puts out 255 horsepower and 413 pound-feet of torque with the fuel economy of a mid-size sedan, will appeal to drivers who have towing in mind, but the gasoline engines, with a range of 300 to 567 horsepower are still crowd pleasers. All engine options are paired with the eight-speed automatic transmission with paddle shifters, a handy feature in the event you really do need to hold a gear for steep mountain climbs. The interior is well equipped, including standard navigation with touchpad and a large, 10.2-inch high-definition display. But you’ll pay extra for the surround-view camera system, and most of the latest safety features, such as lane departure warning, active pedestrian and collision warning systems, and adaptive cruise control. The second row is fairly roomy and comes standard with a 40/20/40 split to customize the SUV’s 23-cubic-foot cargo area. An optional third row hidden in the cargo floor is available for the occasional additional passenger or two, making the X5 a solid, yet hefty, investment for growing families.

New for 2015

Recalibrated eight-speed automatic transmission resulting in better efficiency and faster acceleration; and the sport leather steering wheel is now standard.

If you can get past the odd design of the BMW i3, there is a lot to love in this compact electric car. Engineering nerds will wax poetic about at the aluminum body and carbon fiber reinforced plastic (CFRP) that makes vehicle’s frame lightweight yet as strong as steel, and appreciate the two propulsion options to suit their lifestyle and driving needs. All i3s are equipped with a 22kWh lithium-ion battery pack that produces 170 horsepower and 184 lb-ft of torque, and can propel the compact four-seater more than 80 miles on a single charge and up to speeds of 93 mph. The i3 can also be equipped with a 2-cylinder gasoline range-extender range extender that acts as a generator to charge the battery when its capacity is depleted. The interior can be described as eco-chic and is outfitted with sustainably sourced textiles and woods, but its small rear seats are accessible only through carriage doors, which may turn away some families who plan to use the backseat frequently. A fast charge port is optional and can recharge a drained battery from zero to 80 percent capacity in less than 30 minutes.

New for 2015

DC fast charging, satellite radio, and heated front seats are now standard.

Ford is taking a page from Apple’s innovation book by expanding its MyFord Mobile app extension to smartwatches. For owners of the Ford C-Max Energi (shown here) and Fusion Energi plug-in hybrids and the Focus Electric, this adds more fun and convenience to the ownership experience. And let's face it, it's not just environmentalism that makes a person buy an alternative-fuel vehicle: there's an early adopter excitement to it, a sense of adventure and play.

Ford announced this at a presentation of several new-tech initiatives in Palo Alto, where the automaker has its Research and Innovation Center. Joining several of the world's auto companies that are going all in on autonomous driving, Ford has named a new self-driving-car czar, Randy Visintainer (whose title is Director of Autonomous Vehicle Development), which should intensify the Ford Smart Mobility program to bring more driver assistance technology to Fords across the lineup. That's all good news for anyone who wants a safer car.

But back to the smartwatch. Yes, pretty soon you'll be able to check your hybrid or plus-in electric vehicle’s battery charge status and driving range from a quick glance at your wrist, assuming you have an Apple Watch or Android Wear smartphone on that wrist. The watches will get it "soon," Ford said. Ford's Said Deep tweeted a photo of a "research" version of the app on an Apple Watch a few weeks ago.
Just from your smartwatch, you can also use this app to find a nearby charging station and even remotely start your car. The MyFord Mobile app is already on iOS and Android smartphones.
Expanding apps from the smartphone to the smartwatch looks a little geeky at the moment, but you can bet things are just going to get smaller and more mobile

Want to try this out? You can go to the My Ford Mobile website and sign in as a Guest, at which point you will become a fictional San Francisco resident named Dylan. That will let you try out the technology even if you don’t own one of the Fords it works for. And even if you don't, you can be you will be using ever smaller and more portable technology to help you with the car you do own, within a matter of a few years from now.

contributors.bio: When I turned sixteen, my dad brought home the very first-generation Ford Escort wagon, and it just so happened to have a manual transmission. Since—like every other sixteen-year-old—I knew everything, I was sure that I would just get behind the wheel and effortlessly shift gears. Visions of screeching into the school parking lot with my shiny red "world car" and impressing all the burnouts who hung out near their Detroit muscle cars danced in my head. All of those dreams were quickly extinguished in the first fifteen minutes of my driving lesson from my dad. Although he has a teaching certificate, patience is not his strongest skill. The subtle foot-hand coordination escaped me, and we were jerking around the subdivision like the contestants in a game of Red Light Green Light. I blamed my dad, and he blamed me. To my astonishment, he decided it was best to abandon ship and allow me to figure out how to get home. Somehow I managed to limp home without needing therapy for whiplash. After our wounds had healed I did end up learning to drive a manual on that trusty steed. I ended up driving my Escort to Northern Michigan University in Marquette, in Michigan’s frigid Upper Peninsula, where I obtained a BFA, with a concentration in Graphic Design, and a future husband. I joined Automobile Magazine at the tender age of twenty-eight and fell in love with the energy and passion for automobiles and the way they enhance our lives. Later, I took a five-year hiatus and boned up my design and web skills and am now turbocharged to be a part of the Jean Knows Cars team. Many years have passed, and now my sixteen-year-old only child is poised to learn to drive a manual, and I can’t help but be transported back to my teens. Unlike my parents, I am a helicopter mom. Riding in the passenger's seat with her behind the wheel is like waterboarding. I want to order her to pull over and allow me to drive and throw her in the back seat with airbags strapped directly on her. Many of her peers will not learn to drive a manual, but I believe that it is the building block for a good safe driver. It is a perfect synergy watching my daughter learn to drive and helping Jean Knows Cars celebrate and embrace the automobile and how it is woven into our lives.

pageElements.text: The 2016 Chevrolet Cruze will not be in showrooms until early 2016, but, like the plethora of presidential candidates we're already seeing, it has hit the campaign trail a little bit early. That gives General Motors plenty of time to trumpet the attributes of its number-one-selling vehicle worldwide. It is especially important to hit the ground running, since a new Honda Civic is making its debut later this year.
GM is touting 40 mpg highway, which beats the current segment leaders, the Toyota Corolla and the Honda Civic, and the manual will most likely get even better numbers.

The all-new Cruze is downright handsome. It is longer, lighter, and lower than its predecessor. Dropping 250 pounds and gaining 2.7 inches in length from the previous generation created a sportier, more aerodynamic silhouette. There will be four trim levels, including the top-of-the-line Premier. Two of the new inches are given to rear-seat legroom. Thank you, Chevrolet, because I found the back seat in the 2015 model unbearable for an adult passenger.

Speaking of the interior, it is not only roomy; it is good-looking, and the two-tone Premier package is near perfect, further proof that Chevrolet has cleaned up its interiors. The Cruze follows the same design direction of dual cockpits, clean dash, and upgraded materials that the Camaro, Spark, Volt, and Malibu ushered in earlier this year.

The all-new 1.4-liter Ecotec turbocharged engine, paired with a six-speed manual transmission, is standard. However, most buyers will opt for the six-speed automatic transmission. Stop/start technology will be standard. This fuel-efficient feature allows the engine to shut down when the car is at rest (such as at a stoplight) and magically start again when the accelerator is pressed. GM is touting 40 mpg highway, which beats the current segment leaders, the Toyota Corolla and the Honda Civic, and the manual will most likely get even better numbers. Diesel fans will have to wait until 2017, in the U.S. at least, when GM says it's bringing out a new clean diesel. Meanwhile, the 2015 Cruze does still come as a diesel.

Tech geeks will appreciate the new MyLink display. The standard 7.0-inch touchscreen will work with both Android Auto and Apple CarPlay, and there will be an optional eight-inch display available. Both systems work seamlessly to allow approved apps to display on the touchscreen. The apps are selected by the individual systems with an eye toward discouraging distracted driving.  Many Apple owners I know will now demand this on any car they will consider. Every Cruze will have 4G LTE Wi-Fi, becoming very common on GM products, which allows subscribers to connect up to seven wireless devices to the Internet while the car is on the road. This should be adequate for a five-passenger compact car!
There will also be an option for wireless charging. Now that is progress.
Since 34 percent of Cruze buyers are under thirty-five, GM understands that smartphone integration is essential. There will also be an option for wireless charging. Now that is progress.

Continuing the attention to technology, Chevrolet has stuffed optional advanced safety features into the Cruze, such as Side Blind Zone Alert, Rear Cross-Traffic Alert, Lane Keep Assist, and Forward Collision Alert. To attract the buyers in the colder climates, there will be optional front and rear heated seats and one of my favorite features, a heated steering wheel. Just a few years ago these technologies were only available on luxury vehicles, but they are now trickling down to the entry-level models.

The trunk will be huge. It will not only easily swallow up luggage for a family of four but also easily held automotive journalist David Zenlea. I believe he could have invited a friend in for a snuggle, but we were trying to keep it G rated. Now we just have to wait to get behind the wheel to predict whether the Cruze will get our vote.

Since then, she has written about cars for CNET.com, AutoUSA.com, Babble.com, and, oddly enough, Hustler. Residing in the Seattle area, she obviously drives a Subaru Outback.

pageElements.text:
2015 Volkswagen Beetle Convertible 1.8T

Type: Four-passenger, front-wheel-drive compact convertible
Base price: $26,415 (including destination charge)
Engine: Turbocharged 1.8-liter four-cylinder, 180 horsepower
Transmission: Six-speed automatic
Fuel economy: 24 mpg city/32 mpg highway
Models available: 1.8T, 1.8T with Technology, 1.8T with Sound and Navigation, R-Line, Convertible Classic, TDI (diesel)
A convertible is the hallmark of being footloose and fancy free, but can it also be family friendly?

Road noise, perceived rollover risk, smaller trunks and cabins, and let’s face it, sunburn are among the many reasons that a convertible often isn’t a family’s daily driver. But with advancements in cabin acoustics, increased safety regulations and one-touch power opening and closing, it’s never been easier to drop the top of a convertible, and occupants have never been more protected. Is it time for families to take a look at convertibles when shopping for a new car?
Before automatically dismissing this as a pipe dream that only starlets get to live out, consider this: convertibles are among the least expensive vehicles on the market to insure.

Russ Rader, senior vice-president of communications for the Insurance Institute for Highway Safety (IIHS), explained the reason for the better policy pricing: convertibles tend to have lower incidents of accidents and bodily injury losses than their hard-topped counterparts. That’s in part because they’re often the third or fourth vehicle a family owns, which means they may spend most of the time parked in suburban garages, and they tend to be driven only on nice days. But many models are also fleet vehicles for car rental companies that see more than their fair share of abuse and miles on the road, and yet losses on even the convertible Mustang are lower than those of a two-door Honda Accord, according to IIHS.
There’s this overwhelming belief that they’re just not practical. To find out if this is the case, I spent a week with a silver 2015 Volkswagen Beetle Convertible.

These lower premiums could help offset the higher price that droptop models fetch compared with their conventional models. But cost isn’t the only factor making car buyers shy away from these vehicles as family cars; there’s this overwhelming belief that they’re just not practical. To find out if this is the case, I spent a week with a silver 2015 Volkswagen Beetle Convertible.

The VW Beetle Convertible wasn’t even on my radar as a car that I would consider; too frivolous, too compact. But the uber-cute car won me over with its sporting handling and an ample 180 horsepower from the base 1.8-liter turbocharged four-cylinder engine. The trunk, at 7.1 cubic feet of cargo capacity, was still large and deep enough to fit my stroller even with the soft top tucked away. The vehicle seats only four, which is a drawback, but I can count on one hand the number of times I actually needed and used five seats in the three years I’ve owned my wagon.
With the top down, which lowers in an impressive 9.5 seconds, loading my tot in the car seat was never easier—no bumped heads!

The power one-touch open and close of the cloth droptop increased the compact’s versatility. I could start off a trip with the top down, and if the sun became too much or rain moved in, the top could be closed in just eleven seconds, and even while the vehicle is in motion (up to 31 mph, which I didn’t test). And with the top down, which lowers in an impressive 9.5 seconds, loading my tot in the car seat was never easier—no bumped heads!

But I never shook the discomfort of looking in the rear and noticing that there was no C-pillar to help protect her in side-impact crash or a rollover. Rather, there is an automatic rollover support system that would deploy high-strength steel bars that should protect the heads of all passengers in the event the system detects imminent rollover. There are other structural changes that VW made to the Beetle Convertible to offset its missing hard top, such as an A-pillar interior bar that is 0.5 mm thicker and made from ultra-high-strength hot-formed steel, and additional ultra-high-strength tubing between the B-pillars as well as a stronger heel plate.
Would this be enough to protect my toddler in the event of an accident?

The National Highway Traffic Safety Administration (NHTSA) gives the 2015 Volkswagen Beetle its top overall five-star safety rating, but the Beetle Convertible hasn’t been tested. Looking at injury losses for convertibles, Rader found that the Beetle Convertible tended to have lower collision losses than the hardtop model, but there isn’t enough data to determine if there are more or less injury losses because it hasn’t been available long enough. Over at the Insurance Institute for Highway Safety, only two 2015 model convertibles were subjected to safety testing: the Volkswagen Eos and the Ford Mustang. Both received Good ratings in several areas, although Roof Strength, for obvious reasons, wasn't rated.

VW spokesperson Darryl Harrison pointed out to me that structural reinforcements around the doors improve rigidity of the body structure to compensate for not having a roof, and there’s a system that shuts off the fuel pump, unlocks the doors, and switches on the hazard lights if the car is involved in certain types of collisions. Unfortunately, while the hardtop model offers side airbags for the rear passengers, the convertible model has airbags only in the front. But at least for now my daughter would be protected by her car seat, which was easy to install with the Beetle Convertible's exposed latches, and fit snugly with zero wiggle.
When I think family friendly I imagine ample storage, rear-seat entertainment, cupholders integrated into the rear doors, and power liftgates, none of which this car had.

But is a four-seater convertible truly family friendly? When I think about what this term traditionally means in cars, I imagine ample storage, rear-seat entertainment systems, cupholders integrated into the rear doors so kids have easy access, and power liftgates, none of which this car had. But all the vehicles that had those features tended to be sedate and practical as mom jeans. Isn’t fun part of being family friendly? Isn’t that how good memories are created? If so, then a convertible offers that in spades, and should at least warrant a test drive when shopping for a new car.

title: Cars' Child Safety LATCH: Big Fail
subTitle: They're too hard to use, Insurance Institute test shows. What parents need to know before car shopping.

promoTeaser: They're too hard to use, Insurance Institute test shows. What parents need to know before car shopping.

pageElements.text: If you have children using car seats, you are quite familiar with the LATCH system that makes it easy to correctly attach a child safety seat into the back seat of your vehicle. These pieces of hardware have been required in vehicles and on child seats since 2002. You’d think automakers would have perfected them by now.

But you’d be wrong. The Insurance Institute for Highway Safety issued the results of its first sweeping test of the LATCH systems in 100 2015 model cars, and the result was a big Fail. Only three vehicles got the top Good rating, and they’re not the ones you might have guessed. The Mercedes-Benz GLK-Class, the BMW 5 Series, and the Volkswagen Passat (pictured here) were the winners, while forty-four vehicles got a lower rating of Acceptable, forty-five were ranked Marginal, and ten were rated as Poor.
IIHS is not claiming that the LATCH hardware is going to break off or fail, just that it could be so frustrating to use that parents won't want to use it properly.

The ratings are based on ease of use for the owner. IIHS is not claiming that all those vehicles have hardware that is going to break off or fail, just that it could be so frustrating to use that parents will be at risk of not installing the seat safely.

Vehicles are required to have at least two rear seats with the full set of LATCH hardware and at least one tether anchor in a third spot. As someone who once had three car seats in her vehicle, I applaud that regulation. And I am well aware that two out of three car seats are not installed correctly, in part because it’s so #)$_*(#$) hard to get those seats in the car nice and tight.

The most commonly cited problem in the IIHS evaluation is that the lower anchors are too deeply embedded in the seat, making it hard to reach and use them. There are lower anchors where the seatback and bottom seat cushion meet. Then there’s a top tether that attaches the top of the car seat to an anchor, which can be on the rear shelf, the seatback, the floor, the cargo space, or even the ceiling of the vehicle.

IIHS marked vehicles down if it took too much force to attach a child seat to the lower anchors, if the anchors were too challenging to reach, work with, and maneuver around. To see how the ratings work, check out the ratings page for the Toyota Sienna—a family-oriented vehicle if there ever was one, and already named a IIHS Top Safety Pick Plus for its crashworthiness.

Inconvenient child seat tethers won’t be a deal breaker for a car shopper, but knowing this information is essential when you’re shopping for a new vehicle, if you plan to use child seats. Here’s a reminder to check IIHS data, but also to take your own child seat to the dealership and try to put it in the car. This report is sure to influence automakers to consider changes to how they fit LATCH hardware into future models, which is good for you, your kids, and your hands that may no longer have to struggle to get the seat installed properly.

title: Start/Stop: Mercedes-Benz GLA250
subTitle: The fuel-saving feature that shuts off the engine when you're idling: how does it feel? I tried it.
promoTeaserSmall: The fuel-saving feature that shuts off the engine when you're idling: how does it feel? I tried it.
promoTeaser: The fuel-saving feature that shuts off the engine when you're idling: how does it feel? I tried it.
metaDescription: The fuel-saving feature that shuts off the engine when you're idling: how does it feel? I tried it.

contributors.bio: Liane Yvkoff dipped her toe in the pool of automotive writing five years ago and fell directly into the deep end. Since then, she has written about cars for CNET.com, AutoUSA.com, Babble.com, and, oddly enough, Hustler. Residing in the Seattle area, she obviously drives a Subaru Outback.

pageElements.text: I know a woman who took her brand-new Audi A8 back to the dealer, irate that the engine kept shutting off every time she stopped at a red light. Imagine her surprise (and embarrassment) to learn that it was the fuel-saving auto stop/start technology at work. Was this her fault for not knowing? More likely it was the dealer's fault for not explaining it at the time of purchase.
As start/stop technology becomes more common in new cars, you'll want to understand what it is and why it's a good thing, and here's your explanation.

Automatic start/stop is a system that automatically shuts off the vehicle’s engine when the vehicle idles (or stops at a red light) and then restarts when it is re-engaged. This feature has been common for a long time on hybrids, and a growing number of car manufacturers are embracing this technology. It's an easy way to improve fuel economy by as much as seven percent in their vehicles with conventional internal-combustion engines, without adding expensive lithium-ion batteries and electric motors.

How it works is fairly simple: when your vehicle is in motion, the engine is always on, but when it comes to a complete stop, the engine automatically turns off without your doing anything to the ignition. When you then take your foot off the brake to prepare to accelerate, the engine automatically restarts. This toggling of the engine can save drivers approximately $179 annually in fuel savings, according to a AAA study.

To see what it was like driving around with this engine feature, I tested the 2015 Mercedes-Benz GLA250 4Matic for a week. The vehicle uses a turbocharged 2.0-liter four-cylinder engine, and like all 2015 models in the Mercedes-Benz lineup, it is equipped with Eco Start/Stop as a standard feature.
You don’t expect a gasoline engine to cut out at any time once you’ve left your driveway, but at nearly every light and stop sign, that's exactly what happened.

I’ve driven a fair number of hybrid vehicles, but the engine automatically turning off caught me by surprise during the first couple of days. In a conventional vehicle, you don’t expect a gasoline engine to cut out at any time once you’ve left your driveway, but at nearly every light, every stop sign, and sometimes in heavy traffic, that’s exactly what happened. If I changed pressure dramatically or took my foot off the brake to switch to the accelerator, it snapped back to life as intended.

This was all well and good for the environment, but a bit unnerving when the engine switched off as I paused in the middle of an intersection to turn left, and anxiety-inducing when I worried that it wouldn’t switch over before the yellow arrow became a glaring red. And I can’t tell you how many times I pulled into my garage, gathered my purse, and hopped out, only to hear the engine snap back to life as I exited the vehicle. I wasn’t keeping good count, but it was probably more than the number of times I turned the ignition off without first putting the transmission in Park.

Yes, it’s possible to turn this feature off by deselecting the Eco option on the Mercedes GLA, and I tried that for a couple of days to compare. It was a much smoother driving experience without automatic stop/start, but there were times when I was trapped in stopped traffic due to construction and wished the engine would turn off. Of course, I could have done that, but I might have also killed the air conditioning, navigation, and audio, and more important, I doubt my reflexes are as quick as the vehicle’s at restarting when traffic moved.

With this feature, the GLA250 achieves an estimated 24 mpg in the city. Subtracting seven percent from this data point, the fuel economy drops down to approximately 22 mpg. I imagine that I over time I would get used to turning off the ignition even if the engine wasn’t running. I guess 2 additional miles per gallon is worth the occasional less than graceful car exit even if I don’t.
