title: 5 Ways to Keep Kids Safe in the Car
subTitle: What you can do today, and every day, that will immediately help.
promoTitle: 5 Ways to Keep Kids Safe in the Car
promoTeaserSmall: What you can do today, and every day, that will immediately help.
promoTeaser: What you can do today, and every day, that will immediately help.
keywords: 5 Ways to Keep Kids Safe in the Car
metaTitle: 5 Ways to Keep Kids Safe in the Car - JeanKnowsCars.com
metaDescription: What you can do today, and every day, that will immediately help.

pageElements.text: 1. Get them used to a snug fit. Whether in a car seat, a booster seat, or with a seatbelt, all ages of kids should be firmly strapped in to the car. If you make a comfortable but close fit the default, that's what they will be used to, and it's far safer. Adjust the car seat's straps so they fit with no more than a finger's width of give between straps and child. Booster seats are called "belt-positioning boosters" for a reason, so use the positioning clips on the top edge to firmly attach the shoulder strap to the seat.

2. Never let kids tuck the shoulder strap behind them or under their arm. In an accident, that child has an unprotected upper body in the former case, and could sustain terrible internal injuries in the latter case. The proper use of the shoulder strap must be non-negotiable. If your child isn't tall enough to use the seatbelt comfortably, he or she belongs in a booster seat. The shoulder belt should sit across the middle of your child's chest and shoulder, and is off of the neck.

3. Ensure that car seats are used (and used correctly) no matter whose car they're in. Carpool or field trip drivers, relatives or grandparents? Make sure they take car seat use as seriously as you do. The nonprofit group Safe Kids says one in five parents admit to "bending the rules" by letting carpooling kids ride without the proper child or booster seat or even without seatbelts. Three times as many, 61 percent, tattled on other parents, saying they've seen it happen. Ensuring the proper number of car seats and seating positions is part of planning any trip, short or long.

4. Think of everything in your car as a possible projectile. Something as harmless as a toy car could do some serious damage if you get into a crash. Do you remember the Sippy Cup Incident of 2011, in which a little boy needed 400 stitches to the forehead when his plastic cup hit him in an accident? Enough said. It's easy to toss the sports equipment, book bags, and toys on the floor of the back seat next to your kids. But it's better to put it away in the trunk or secure it in the back. For little kids, encourage the use of soft, squishy toys in the car rather than hard-edged ones. It can't hurt.

5. Don't be in a hurry to take your kids out of booster seats. Safe Kids says they can cut the risk of injury in an accident by 45 percent compared with seatbelts alone. That same organization reports that 70 percent of parents don't know that a child has to be 4'9" tall before it's time to stop using a booster. For some kids, that's well into middle school age. Refer back to item #1, above; it's your job as the parent to make a snug, appropriately belted riding experience the norm, and the comfort zone, for your child and any other kids who ever ride with you; yes, even just down to the local store.

Use These Resources

Find the type of car seat that fits. Want to know what kind of car seat your child should be in? The National Highway Traffic Safety Administration's homepage has an interactive seat selector to find the right car seat. Enter your child's height, weight, and age, and the recommended seat type will pop up.

Get a picture of how your child should fit in the car. Safer Kids Worldwide offers a page of videos and images for babies to teens.

Arm yourself with information (and arguments) for older kids. NHTSA's Parents Central has a page, Never Give Up until They Buckle Up, with videos and information touching kids aged eight to fourteen.

pageElements.text:
2016 Mazda CX-3 Grand Touring AWD

Type: Five-passenger, front- or all-wheel-drive compact crossover
Base price: $20,840 (CX-3 Sport, front-wheel drive)
Price as tested: $27,060 (CX-3 Grand Touring, all-wheel drive)
Engine: 2.0-liter four-cylinder, 146 horsepower
Transmission: Six-speed automatic with paddle shifters
Fuel economy: 23 mpg city/32 mpg highway
My favorite standard feature: 18-inch aluminum alloy wheels
Option I can’t live without: Smart City Brake Support
Notable standard features on this model: 18-inch alloy wheels, LED lighting, heated side mirrors, power moonroof, leather seats with suede inserts, navigation system with voice command, seven-speaker Bose audio
You might also be considering: Buick Encore, Chevrolet Trax, Fiat 500X, Honda HR-V, Jeep Renegade, Kia Soul, Nissan Juke

CUV—Crossover Utility Vehicle—is a term that embraces a vast and growing flock of rides, responding to a growing interest in taller, more spacious alternatives to the compact sedan or hatchback. But people are still frugal; much of the growth is occurring at the subcompact end of the spectrum. Which is where this new Mazda offering will compete. It goes on sale in August.

Like essentially everything in this class, it is built on front-wheel-drive passenger car foundations, in this case the little Mazda 2, but bigger in the vertical scale, which translates as more cargo capacity, as well as a little more mass.
Like all its competitors, the CX-3 has a little more ground clearance (5.9 inches) than a conventional subcompact passenger car, and like all the others it offers the option of all-wheel drive.

But when the graded dirt road ends and the trackless outback begins, the CX-3 will be out of its depth. That's okay, since the CX-3 is designed for young adults, most of them with no kids, whose primary driving environment is urban. The only player in this class that’s truly off-road capable is the Jeep Renegade, provided it’s a Trail-Rated version, and it is likely to appeal to different buyers with different needs.

In its more citified milieu, the CX-3's dynamic virtues are nimble handling and acceleration that can be classified as brisk by the standards of this class—a wink or two over eight seconds from 0 to 60 mph.

Power is supplied by a 2.0-liter four-cylinder engine, sending a max of 146 horsepower to the front (or, optionally, all four) wheels via a six-speed automatic transmission. With front-wheel drive, the CX-3 is forecast by the EPA to deliver 29 mpg in the city, 35 mpg on the highway. With all-wheel drive, those numbers diminish to 27/32 mpg.

And of course, every element of the CX-3—chassis, body, engine, transmission—was developed with what Mazda calls Skyactiv Technology, which is essentially a holistic approach to design and engineering that targets optimum efficiency and minimum mass.
The suspension strikes a civilized balance between athletic response and pleasant ride. There’s little of the lifeboat rock and roll exhibited by some in this class.

Mazda claims that 63 percent of the structure is high-strength steel, which helps to keep weight down—most of the line will weigh in a bit under 3,000 pounds even with all-wheel drive—while yielding high chassis rigidity. A stiff chassis is desirable for several reasons: crashworthiness, interior noise reduction, and a solid platform for suspension tuning.

This is an area where all Mazda vehicles score high marks, and it’s a CX-3 strong suit. The suspension strikes a civilized balance between athletic response and pleasant ride. There’s little of the lifeboat rock and roll exhibited by some vehicles in this class, and the electric power steering has a more accurate and tactile feel than most systems of this type.

But the reality is that few subcompact CUV owners are likely to push their rides to the limits of adhesion, and for routine driving and emergency avoidance maneuvers, the CX-3 will feel more agile than most.

Braking seems to be another strong suit; the brakes don’t mind repeated hard stops, responding as well after twenty vigorous applications as they do to the first. If there are any dynamic demerits, they’re in the aural areas—a fair amount of road noise on some surfaces, and the engine sounds a little coarse when pressed to maximum output.

Sport-utility vehicles are all developed to the same general theme, called the basic two-box design. The smaller box shelters the engine, the larger one the passenger and cargo areas. However, designers have been doing their best to mitigate SUV boxiness, and the CX-3 disguises its fundamental elements of style better than most.

Subtle sculpting eliminates the slab-sided look that afflicts so many vehicles in this genre, a pair of creases lend character to the hood, which slopes down to a signature Mazda grille, and muscular rear haunches help to give the entire package a sporty look. Overhangs, the portions of the car extending beyond the axles, are limited, particularly at the rear, and the relatively low roofline—at 60.7 inches, it’s just 3.4 inches taller than the hatchback version of the Mazda 3—make the CX-3 look more like a car than a CUV.

Interior appointments are particularly upscale for a vehicle in this class, even in the basic Sport trim, and the top-of-the-line Grand Touring version—our ride for a California preview drive—is distinguished by leather upholstery with some very elegant stitchery.

The front seats have a sporty feel, with torso bolsters that provide better than average lateral support, and even though the CX-3’s ride height is low by class standards, a relatively high seating position provides that commanding view that SUV owners enjoy, with good forward sightlines. What you see is what you’re less likely to hit.

Mazda offers a comprehensive array of telematic features and connectivity (Mazda Connect) that’s become so important today, particularly with younger customers. The 7.0-inch display screen that’s home for the optional navigation system juts out of the top of the center dashboard, making it easier to see: a glance to the right is sufficient; no downward eye movement. An asterisk to this is that the radio volume control knob is at the rear of the center console, under the center armrest, and adjusting stations is a tricky business.

Speaking of radio, the CX-3 includes a Bose audio option, which of course enhances the auditory experience, but at the expense of rear cargo space. Cargo capacity isn’t a CX-3 strong suit anyway—just 12.4 cubic feet behind the rear seats—and opting for the Bose system reduces the space to 10.1 cubic feet.

On the same note, rear seat legroom is pretty snug, and as with so many subcompact vehicles the center rear seat isn’t tenable for anyone much over four feet tall. And power adjustable seats are conspicuous by their absence, even in the Grand Touring model.

Safety features (standard and optional) are contemporary, and the CX-3 offers the low-speed (up to 18 mph) traffic minder (Smart City Brake Support) that will stop the vehicle if it “sees” that traffic ahead has stopped and the driver isn’t paying attention. Of course, this would never apply to you, but then again, it’s a safety feature that’s becoming increasingly widespread and a big plus in urban traffic. A rearview camera is standard, and Mazda anticipates top safety ratings from both the Insurance Institute for Highway Safety and the National Highway Traffic Safety Administration.

Pricing is another factor that’s attracting buyers to the small-crossover segment. The CX-3 stacks up well in this respect, starting with the well equipped Sport model at $20,840. Base price for the mid-grade Touring version is $22,840, and the edge-of-luxury Grand Touring trim opens at $25,800. Add $1,260 for all-wheel drive.

We’d be remiss if we didn’t point out that the Mazda 3 hatchback overlaps this price ladder, and offers more power, more cargo capacity, and more rear seat space. But it doesn’t have that CUV persona, and it’s less inclined to thrive on leftover parking spaces.
The bottom line: The CX-3 is Mazda’s first foray into the burgeoning world of crossovers, and if fun to drive is a priority for you, it belongs at the top of your wish list.

title: Pro/Con: Climate Control Issues?
subTitle: Molly likes constant climate change; Laura sets it and forgets it. Whose control issues match yours?

contributors.displayName: Laura Sky Brown and Molly Jean

pageElements.text:
Laura Says: Just Chill Out about Getting the Right Temperature

When it comes to weather extremes—in or out of the car—I believe in patience. After all, I come from Michigan, a place where weather extremes are intense. I believe that it is possible to get to a level of comfort if you just take the time to trust your clothing choices and the heating or cooling technology around you. That extends not only to home and office but most especially to the car. Repeat after me: You don't need to freak out about being warm (or cold) for the ninety seconds it takes for the car's heating, ventilation, and air conditioning (HVAC) system to get you to the right temperature.
Repeat after me: You don't need to freak out about being warm (or cold) for the ninety seconds it takes for the car's HVAC system to get you to the right temperature.

At the moment, I am seeing temperature gauge readings in the 80s and 90s when I climb into a car and close the door. Six months from now, I expect to see 0 or -5 degrees on the same gauge. What is the constant? My reaction. I am OK about sitting in the heat of the car for a minute. I trust the car's modern HVAC system to achieve a mid-70s level of comfort quickly, and I am almost never wrong. So I don't do what a lot of people (like my colleague Molly Jean, for example) do and roll the windows down while also blasting the air conditioning on maximum. That is a waste of resources and energy, and besides, if it's that hot inside the car, it's also hot outside, so why encourage more hot air to enter the sanctum of the passenger compartment?

The same holds true when it's icy cold out. You do not need to start and run a car for ten minutes before driving unless the cold is really extreme. You certainly don't need to do it because you are too fragile to be chilly for a few minutes and need the car to be all toasty inside before you set foot in it. Molly may be a special snowflake, too delicate for this world, but I'm not. And I believe in confronting the weather we have, not freaking out about it.

Molly Says: I'll Do What Takes to Be Comfortable, Including Roll the Window Down

When it is eighty degrees outside, like right now, the interior of a car can hover in the 120-degree range. Keep in perspective that you can consume pork at 145 degrees. So it is literally like an oven. I would not consider climbing into my oven and thinking that blowing a bit of air inside would render me comfortable in a few minutes. Nope. I will roll down my window and welcome the breeze I create as I cruise down the road for five minutes, until my HVAC can lower the temperature to an acceptable level. Seriously, there are so many things in life I can’t control that the interior of a car does not have to be one of them.
I would not consider climbing into my oven, thinking that blowing a bit of air inside would render me comfortable in a few minutes. Nope. I will roll down my window.

As for winter, we Northerners should erect a shrine to American Motors, because that ill-fated company introduced the remote starter in 1983. I know it is not the best choice for the environment, but I will double up on my recycling to make up for it. If the car I am driving does not have remote start, I use the time it takes me to scrape the windows to warm up the car. Just like cooling a car, it takes a while to warm it up enough to make a car interior comfortable. I think most readers would agree that a driver who isn’t shivering or roasting is going to be a better driver.

Lastly, I am currently suffering from major temperature swings. Read: Hot flashes. Once the heat wave subsides, I am freezing. I equate it to being shoved in a pizza oven and then plunged into Lake Superior—every twenty minutes, all day long. So I think the very best place to be is in a car, where I can fluctuate the temperature quickly. In the winter, I roll down the window and stick my head out. I know it is difficult on my passengers, but if you were in a pizza oven, wouldn’t you open the door?

contributors.bio:
Jean Knows Cars is not just the name of this website; it's a true fact. I have been writing about cars and the car business for more than 30 years, having learned about cars at the kitchen table from my late father, Robert Lienert, who was the editor of Automotive News. At age eighteen, I bought a used car, painted it yellow, installed a toplight and a meter, and joined the Yellow Cab Company in Ann Arbor, Michigan, as an owner/operator. Five years later, I got a job at Chrysler’s test track as a test driver, welder, and mechanic in the impact lab. In 1980, I was hired as a writer at Car and Driver magazine after getting laid off at Chrysler, and in 1985 I left to establish Automobile Magazine with David E. Davis, Jr. I was the magazine’s first Executive Editor, became Editor in Chief in 2000, and added the title of President of Automobile Magazine in 2006.

I’ve been profiled in The New Yorker and have been a guest on the Tonight Show with Jay Leno. I was a guest on the Oprah Winfrey Show, teaching Oprah and her studio audience how to change a tire and to jump a battery. I was Good Morning America’s automotive correspondent from 1994 to 2000 and then did the same thing for the Oxygen network.

 I have won awards for feature writing, car reviews, and my monthly Automobile Magazine column, “Vile Gossip,” including the 2007 Ken Purdy Award for Excellence in Automotive Journalism.  I’m a regular on-air contributor to Fox Business Network; CNBC’s Closing Bell, Squawk Box, Behind the Wheel, and Power Lunch; MSNBC; CBS This Morning and Evening News; and CNN’s American Morning and Headline News. In fact, I would almost call myself a TV slut, but I’m proud to say that I turned Geraldo down.

All of this has taken place in a male-dominated automotive space, where I’m all too frequently the only woman in the room. I know the secret handshake, but JeanKnowsCars.com is going to be a place where you don’t have to. 

I live in the Michigan countryside with my husband, Tim, and the entire food chain. You’re going to get to know my driveway and my dogs really, really well. Just keep reading.

pageElements.text:
Type: Four-passenger, all-wheel-drive sport coupe
Base price: $34,850 (prices include destination charge)
This car: $41,375
Engine: Turbocharged 2.0-liter four-cylinder, 240 horsepower
Transmission: Eight-speed automatic
Fuel economy: 23 mpg city/35 mpg highway
Safety: National Highway Traffic Safety Administration: Not yet rated; Insurance Institute for Highway Safety (2015 BMW 2 Series): Top Safety Pick Plus
Competition (all prices include destination charges):
2015 Audi A3 2.0 TFSI ($34,095)
2015 Lexus IS250 AWD ($40,010)
2015 Mercedes-Benz CLA250 4Matic ($34,425)

Fun-o-Meter: 9

Why, do you ever wonder, do BMW drivers have a certain reputation? It’s because they are not necessarily doing what other people are doing when they are driving down the road. They are lucky enough to spend their time inside a vehicle that has been designed, with single-minded focus, for the purpose of driving.
Let’s not get too poetic about being one with the machine, but really, if that was ever true of any brand of car, it’s true of BMWs. Driving them IS the point.

So often, people sit inside their cars the way they’d sit on their sofa, using their steering wheel the way they use their remote control, just sort of surfing along. For many, a car gets you from point A to point B, and everything in between is a waste. That is not the experience of driving a BMW. And a member of the compact 2 Series family? Even less so. Let’s not get too poetic about being one with the machine, but really, if that was ever true of any brand of car, it’s true of BMWs. Driving them is the point.

I have a special fondness for this smart little BMW coupe—I owned a classic (and quite coveted) 1970 BMW 3.0 CSi, a car that put BMW on the map. When it ran (&%$*!), it was sublime. The new 2 Series is as close as BMW has come in recent times to my coupe.
 
Everything about the exterior appearance of the 2 Series, from the understated but chiseled, low-slung body to the eye-catching double-spoke eighteen-inch wheels and metallic brown paint color, is on point. Inside, everything, from the narrowly contoured  Oyster Dakota leather seats to the brushed aluminum dashboard and door trim, is focused and attractive. (And almost everything I just mentioned costs extra.)

And then you drive it. Because, I have to say, it is a riot to drive this little car. The twin-turbocharged 2.0-liter four-cylinder engine with its 240 horsepower and variable valve control makes sure of that. An eight-speed Sport automatic is the standard accompanying transmission, and it’s BMW worthy. We are talking about an automatic transmission here, folks.

There’s a choice of dynamic driving modes: Eco Pro, Comfort, Sport, and Sport Plus. I worked my way through all four. Eco Pro forces you to be more efficient. Comfort is probably more aggressive than your average sport coupe. That will make you want to see if Sport is even more dynamic. It is. Driving in Sport Plus mode was my personal invitation to be arrested and thrown in the slammer.
The controls are direct and personal, despite what some hypersensitive self-professed “car guys” claim about the electric power steering being artificial in feeling.

In any driving mode, the 228’s controls are direct and personal, despite what some hypersensitive self-professed “car guys” claim about the electric power steering being artificial in feeling. Really? Will you be racing your 228? Get back to me on that steering feel. (P.S. If you will be taking it to the track, you’ll want the $1,600 Track Handling package and BMW’s truly awesome—and free—track app that will let you email your lap times to your buddies, so you can overlay them to see who’s the hero driver.)

A lot of what we like about our test car proved to be extra-cost options. The first thing I would lose is the four-wheel drive. The car would be more nimble without it and would cost $1,800 less. Buy a good set of snow tires if you regularly encounter snow in your life. I would probably suck up the $2,200 for the Sport Line package for the desirable M Sport suspension calibration, the sport seats, and the higher limit on the top speed. I would also keep that $500 heated seat option, lose the metallic paint ($550), and probably buy the Driver Assistance package ($950) for the impressive rearview camera, but I’d hold a grudge that it isn’t standard equipment. After that, you’re on your own.

The Verdict:

The price of entry is not cheap, and you may have heard it on the word of your cousin the stockbroker that a lot of snotnoses own BMWs. The glory and joy of owning one of Munich’s ultimate driving machines, however, is worth every single one of those many dollars. And wouldn’t you love to prove that snotnose thing to be a total myth?

pageElements.text:
2016 Mazda MX-5 Miata Club

Type: Two-passenger, rear-wheel-drive convertible sports car
Base price of Club model: $29,420 (prices include destination charge)
Price as tested: $32,800
Engine: 2.0-liter four-cylinder, 155 horsepower
Transmission: Six-speed manual
Fuel economy: 27 mpg city/34 mpg highway
My favorite standard feature: Easy-open manual soft top
Options I can’t live without: Blind spot monitor, rear cross traffic alert (standard on Grand Touring model, unavailable on Sport and Club models)
Notable standard features on this model: Aluminum shock tower brace and limited slip rear differential (manual transmission only), 245/45-17 high performance tires, front air dam, rear deck-lid spoiler, cloth upholstery with red stitching, nine-speaker BOSE audio, seven-inch touchscreen with Mazda Connect infotainment
Notable options on this model: Club model performance package (Brembo front brakes, BBS forged alloy wheels, side sill extensions, $3,400)
You might also be considering: Scion FR-S, Subaru BRZ

Of course the Mazda MX-5 Miata is enticing at first glance: who wouldn't want one? But there's more behind it than pulchritude; there is history. It has the traits that made the old British roadsters—MG, Triumph, Austin Healey, Sunbeam Alpine—so appealing in the 1950s and 1960s were simplicity, light weight, agile responses, open-air motoring, and affordable pricing.

In 1990, Mazda revived these traits with the first Miata, fortifying them with concepts that were conspicuous by their absence in those old mid-century Brits: a soft top that actually sealed out the weather, roll-up windows, the absence of oil leaks, and contemporary reliability.

A quarter-century later, here’s the fourth generation, and it returns to the roots of the original. Smaller, lighter, and the most nimble Miata yet. Okay, not quite as light as the 1990 original. Safety features (e.g., rollover hoops) and added content make the 2016 Miata heavier than the first generation.

But at a little over 2,300 pounds it’s some 200-plus pounds lighter than the third-generation Miata—lighter, in fact, than any contemporary sports car you’d care to drive daily. That includes the carbon-fiber-intensive Alfa Romeo 4C, the current poster subject for sports car purity.

Reduced weight combined with structural rigidity add up to agility. The new Miata isn’t a track day tiger like the little 4C—it doesn’t have the Alfa’s power-to-weight ratio, and is not nearly as hard-edged. But it’s quick on its feet nevertheless.

And even though the new Miata’s 2.0-liter four-cylinder engine delivers just 155 horsepower (the third-generation Miata had 167 horsepower), it’s propelling a much lighter car, and 60 mph comes up in less than six seconds. Which makes this the quickest Miata ever. And with weight distribution at an ideal 50/50 percent, it’s the most responsive on a winding back road.
We’ll get back to dynamics. But first, the fundamentals.

The fourth generation is a bit smaller than its predecessor, but this seems not to have affected interior space. The seats are a little lower, the steering column tilts and telescopes (like the previous generation), and a slight increase in seatback reclinability makes the cockpit comfortable for pretty much anyone of sub-NBA dimensions.

It’s a convertible, of course, and the manual top is just as easy to operate as the original. More so, in fact. Depending on your manual dexterity, you can flip it open or pull it closed without leaving the driver seat, and a single windshield header latch secures it. Simple.

The previous generation had an excellent folding-hardtop option, but that’s not on the menu for the new car, at least not yet. Will there be a new version at some point? Mazda responds to that question with a terse no comment, so we’d bet yes, but probably not for a year or two.

The seats are supportive, with generous thigh and torso bolsters, but not race car snug; comfort is the priority. They also feature a new construction technique that eliminates traditional springs and foam. There’s no sacrifice in comfort, and the reduction in bulk enhances space for the occupants.
While the Miata is a civilized two-seat convertible that’s perfectly content purring along a country highway, it’s also a thoroughly capable sports car.

Storage is always a challenge in a sports car, and the Miata is no exception. There’s no space behind the seats, and the capacity of the trunk is just five cubic feet. If a lengthy trip is on your calendar—and the Miata is a wonderful companion for an unhurried excursion on America’s byways—think of that modest trunk space as an excuse to go shopping along the way. Discardable outfits. Carefree highway clothing
While the Miata is an amiable getaway vehicle for two—a civilized two-seat convertible that’s perfectly content purring along some country highway—it’s also a thoroughly capable sports car.

As Mazda never tires of pointing out, more Miatas are racing on any given weekend than all other makes combined, and the company doesn’t intend to allow that distinction to fade with the new generation.

However, it doesn’t require a racetrack to enjoy this car’s eager persona. Any back road with a kink or two will do. There’s enough suspension compliance to isolate occupants from gnarly pavement, even in the Club model, equipped with the $3,400 performance package (Brembo front brakes, BBS forged alloy wheels, side sill extensions, and rear bumper skirt, offered only with a manual transmission).

Yes, there’s an automatic transmission option for all three trim levels (Sport, Club, Grand Touring). Add $1,075. It’s a six-speed, and it actually enhances the Miata’s highway fuel economy rating—36 mpg, versus 34 for the manual version. But the precise engagements and short shift throws of the manual gearbox are far more satisfying in terms of optimizing the partnership between the car and its driver.

While there’s a bit of body roll in hard cornering and quick maneuvers, the Miata responds to commands without a hint of hesitation. The electric power steering is exceptionally precise, feeding tactile information to the driver; throttle response is right now; and the car’s 50/50 front/rear weight balance and unerring predictability build confidence from the first set of turns.
The idea of a sports car is transportation for the spirit, as well as the body—the car as an extension of the driver’s will—and the Miata delivers on both counts.
The idea of a sports car is transportation for the spirit, as well as the body—the car as an extension of the driver’s will—and the Miata delivers on both counts.

The Miata has looked good ever since its introduction at the 1989 Chicago Auto Show, and the fourth generation continues that tradition. Repositioning the engine a little lower and rearward in the chassis allowed the design team to give the car a sloping hood line that hints of shark ancestry and also improves forward sight lines for the driver.

Mazda moved the windshield rearward slightly, preserving the classic long hood/short rear deck sports-car look, and the wide rear stance—the design team enhanced this appearance by setting the taillights slightly inward—suggests athletic prowess. That suggestion is borne out by the car’s performance.

Our test sample was a Club model equipped with the performance package, and the red calipers of the Brembo brakes, plus the forged BBS wheels, add a racy touch to the Miata’s look. But even the basic Miata Sport is a head-turner, one of those rare cars that makes the owner happy every time he or she looks at it.

Speaking of the Club model (from $29,420), it’s the Miata of choice for anyone thinking of spending the occasional day at a track or competing on an autocross course. It’s standard performance goodies include a limited slip differential and Bilstein shock absorbers.

But the basic Sport version—from $25,735—is well equipped (sixteen-inch alloy wheels, gas-filled shock absorbers, LED lights, push-button starting, air conditioning, leather-wrapped steering wheel with audio and cruise control switches, six-speaker audio system, power locks and mirrors, and a glass rear window.

If max handling isn’t a priority, the top-of-the-line Grand Touring (from $30,885) offers luxury features (auto climate control, BOSE premium audio, Mazda Connect infotainment, color touch screen controls, navigation, leather seats), and an extensive list of safety features (although a rearview camera is conspicuous by its absence in all the Miatas).

The Verdict:

Practicality isn’t a strong suit for this or any other two-seat car. The idea is driving fun. The Miata has always delivered on this ethic, and the latest one delivers even more. Pricing has obviously crept up, although Mazda suggests that in terms of current dollars to 1990 dollars, the 2016 Miata is a little less expensive than the original. Be that as it may, there is simply no better sports car buy going today.

pageElements.text:
Mazda CX-3

Type: Five-passenger, front- or all-wheel-drive compact crossover
Price range: $19,960 - $24,990
Trim levels: Sport, Touring, Grand Touring
Engine: 2.0-liter four-cylinder, 146 horsepower
Transmissions: Six-speed automatic with paddle shifters
Fuel economy: Sport, Touring, Grand Touring: 29 mpg city/35 mpg highway; Sport AWD, Touring AWD, Grand Touring AWD: 27/32 mpg
Safety ratings: Not yet rated
Our favorite standard feature: 18-inch aluminum alloy wheels
Notable standard features on this model: 18-inch alloy wheels, LED lighting, heated side mirrors, power moonroof, leather seats with suede inserts, navigation system with voice command, seven-speaker Bose audio
Notable options on this model: Smart City Brake Support, all-weather floor mats, Mazda Mobile Start
You might also be considering: Buick Encore, Chevrolet Trax, Fiat 500X, Honda HR-V, Jeep Renegade, Kia Soul, Nissan Juke

The compact crossover game is one nearly every automaker is trying to get in on, and Mazda came onto the field at full sprint with the all-new CX-3. Attractive, sharp, and responsive, the CX-3 brings together classic Mazda handling and consumer-demanded space. You can take on twisting roads with full control and style while lugging camping supplies, new furniture, or friends and family. There is only one choice of engine – a 2.0-liter four-cylinder with 146 horsepower – and one transmission – six-speed automatic with paddle shifters. Don’t let the limited engine and transmission options get you down, though. The CX-3 comes with a whole slew of notable standard features, including LED lighting, power moonroof, leather seats with suede inserts, and best of all, navigation. The options aren’t quite as exciting. When searching for the best of both worlds in style and practicality, people now turn to the compact crossover. And thanks to its high-quality features and sharp design, the CX-3 will top the compact crossover list.

2016 Honda Accord Sport

Type: Five-passenger, front-wheel-drive mid-size sedan
Base price (base LX, six-speed manual transmission): $22,925 (prices include destination charge)
This car: $24,985
Engine: 2.4-liter four-cylinder, 189 horsepower
Transmission: Six-speed manual
Fuel economy: 23 mpg city/34 mpg highway
Safety: Not yet rated; 2015 model is an Insurance Institute for Highway Safety Top Safety Pick
My favorite standard feature: Multi-angle rearview camera
Options I can’t live without: Honda Sensing package (approximately $1,000; includes forward collision warning, collision mitigation braking, lane departure warning, lane keeping assist, road departure mitigation, adaptive cruise control)
Notable standard features on this model: Nineteen-inch alloy wheels, LED daytime running and fog lights, dual exhaust, side sills, body-color rear deck-lid spoiler, aluminum-clad foot pedals, leather wrapped steering wheel, ten-way power adjustable driver’s seat, 160-watt four-speaker audio
You might also be considering: Ford Fusion, Hyundai Sonata, Kia Optima, Mazda 6, Nissan Altima, Toyota Camry, Volkswagen Passat

The Accord is certainly no stranger to the U.S. mid-size sedan free-for-all, and through nearly four decades and nine generations, it has always ranked at or near the top of the charts in comparisons. That's especially impressive given the sheer number and quality of competitors in the mid-size sedan category.

The new Accord is the second edition of the ninth generation of the popular car. Although the tenth generation is still a couple of years away, this Honda is a good bet to sustain its position at the front of the pack. Its perennial virtues—quality assembly, all-day comfort, flawless road manners, a high fun-to-drive index, and top safety ratings—have been augmented by updates for the 2016 model year.
One of the most important changes is what you see. Honda hasn’t been noted for risk taking with Accord styling, but the new front end treatment is almost, well, bold.

Inside, the change in looks continues with new fabrics, more soft-touch surfaces (although a few hard plastics remain), and updates to the infotainment functions with the addition of Apple CarPlay and Android Auto. Honda persists with its commitment to a touchscreen secondary control system that’s devoid of buttons and/or knobs, which some might find annoying. But overall the impression is one of improved quality and comfort.

The engine choices are essentially unchanged: a 185-horsepower 2.4-liter four-cylinder, which is improved to 189 horsepower on the Sport model we tested, and an optional  278-horsepower 3.5-liter V-6. Transmission options are basically the same as well: a six-speed manual is standard. A continuously variable automatic transmission is optional with the four-cylinder and a six-speed automatic with the V-6.

While all of this is familiar, the powertrain engineers have made some adjustments to the continuously variable automatic transmission (CVT), programming artificial shift points into the control chip to make it feel more like a conventional automatic. This is a definite improvement, although there is no manual control function. On the other hand, the four-cylinder/CVT combination continues to be the fuel economy champ among the Accord’s conventional powertrains, with EPA ratings of 27 mpg city/37 mpg highway, better than you get with the manual transmission (23/34 mpg on the Sport).
The V-6 models are projected to deliver 21/34 mpg with the six-speed automatic transmission.

Hybrid versions of the Accord disappear for 2016, but Honda hasn't given up on the technology. They're slated for engineering updates and a return for the 2017 model year, with production scheduled to relocate from the U.S. back to Japan.
The 2016 updates continue with a stronger chassis, a retuned suspension for improved response, and changes to the electric power steering for improved accuracy and road feel.
On the fun-to-drive scale, the Sport versions of the Accord, with the four-cylinder engine and manual transmission, continue to be the way to go.

The Accord’s reflexes are at least as sharp as ever, and its responses as decisive as any car in this class, so if you're looking for a strong fun-to-drive index and confidence in emergency maneuvers, it's right there where you want it to be.

On the fun-to-drive scale, the Sport versions of the Accord, with the four-cylinder engine and manual transmission, continue to be the way to go. There’s obviously a lot more easy cruising power in the V-6, but the Sport model’s lower curb weight, better weight distribution, firmer suspension tuning, and nineteen-inch wheel/tire package (also found on the top Touring model) make this version of the Accord the line’s athlete. The base model gets sixteen-inch wheels and tires, while seventeen-inchers are found on the EX and EX-L.

Then again, while the V-6 Accords may not be quite as quick on their feet, power is smooth and plentiful, the function of the automatic transmission is close to seamless, ride quality is firmly compliant, and interior noise levels are noticeably lower than even the 2015 Accord, which was already quiet.

Safety features are another area of improvement. Noteworthy for 2016 is a package bundling adaptive cruise control, lane departure warning, lane keeping assist, road departure mitigation, forward collision warning, and forward collision mitigation. They're grouped in the new Honda Sensing suite of features. It’s standard on the top-of-the-line Touring trim level and an option at an estimated $1,000 on others.

The Accord is offered in coupe and sedan body styles, and the pricing ladder for 2016 is a little bewildering, with forty-four different distinctions: twenty-five for the sedan and nineteen for the coupe (pictured), some of them identical.

Here are base prices for the major trim levels:
Sedans:
LX (four-cylinder, six-speed manual transmission), $22,495, add $800 for CVT
Sport (four-cylinder, manual), $24,985
EX (four-cylinder, manual), $26,300
EX-L (CVT only), $29,93; EX-L (V-6, six-speed automatic), $31,465
Touring (V-6, automatic), $35,400

Coupes:
LX (four-cylinder, six-speed manual transmission), $24,595
EX (four-cylinder, manual), $26,720
EX-L (four-cylinder, continuously variable automatic transmission), $29,295
EX-L V-6 (manual), $31,745; EX-L V-6 (automatic), $31,745
Touring (V-6,automatic), $34,945

The Verdict:

There is no such thing as a real loser in today’s busy mid-size sedan market. But even so, if all are good, some are better than others, and some excel. The Accord fits into the latter category—exceptional quality, excellent road manners, all-day comfort, solid safety credentials, and high resale value. Add the 2016 updates, and Honda has yet another solid case for best in class.

metaKeywords: cleaning fabric seats in the car
how to get stains out of car upholstery
cleaning road salt out of car upholstery
baking soda as a car cleaner
metaDescription: Get out the common household products to make headway with these unpleasant car-upholstery messes.

pageElements.text:
Images courtesy of Dr. Beasley's

What is more annoying than seeing a cup of coffee flip upside down when you go around a curve in your beautifully upholstered new car? Or more discouraging than realizing your back seat carpeting has ground-in road salt that you may never get out?

A professional detailing job can go into the triple digits, so chances are you’ll be trying to get those stains out on your own before you hand over $100 and more to the pros.
If you want to keep your vehicle looking good inside—and keep the resale value—keep these tips in mind when you prepare to attack stains and dirt on the fabric inside your vehicle.

1. Coffee

Problem: Oils in coffee make it a persistent stain, and—with so many people drinking coffee while they commute—a common one.
Solution: A white vinegar and water solution, sprayed on the stain, will break it up; use that caffeine buzz and do it as soon after the spill as possible. One part vinegar to two parts warm water, sprayed from a bottle, will help lift the stain; then wipe with a microfiber cloth or sponge. Two other household products people swear by are raw egg yolks applied directly to the spot, then rinsed thoroughly with cold water, and club soda, especially if applied immediately. Use a fan or blow dryer to dry the area once it’s clean.

2. Milk

Problem: This one can “cook” into the upholstery if you’re using the wrong method to clean it up.
Solution: Clean it as quickly as possible. If you can’t, soak the stain using cold water, then clean with mild detergent.
Milk? In the car? You don’t have to ask about that if you’re a parent. At some point, your baby or toddler will be holding a bottle of milk or formula while riding in the car, and he or she will tip it or squirt it—or spit it up—into the back seat. Let that run down a seat a few times, and you have a Situation. A smelly situation.

The best way to clean it is to get it clean immediately. Failing that, soak the affected area with cold water (not warm; that will set the stain). Then clean using water and a small dollop of dish soap. You can also make a paste using water and baking soda, let it sit briefly, and then vacuum it up using a Shop-Vac or Dustbuster. The baking soda helps neutralize the odor, too.
For even more odor neutralizing, products such as Febreze or Neutra-Scent, a spray made by artisanal car-care company Dr. Beasley’s, can help.

3. Road salt

Problem: Almost unavoidable in winter, its streaky effect can last into the warm months if you don’t take action.
Solution: Get really good winter floor mats before next winter, and try vinegar and water as a spot cleanser.

Make a mix of half white vinegar and half warm water, put it in a spray bottle, and spray the places where salt stains have happened. Scrub with a toothbrush or nylon-bristled scrub brush, then vacuum or use a towel to soak up the salt. You can minimize the need to do this every spring if you get a sturdy set of winter floor mats made of rubber to put over (or replace) carpeted floor mats.

4. Ink

Problem: That upside-down pen the kids left in the back seat has left its mark.
Solution: Blot, don’t rub. There are several home remedies involving baking soda, vinegar, dish soap, even hairspray.

First, blot the stain with a paper towel or soft cloth so it won’t spread further than it already has. Then count on a vinegar-based solution to pull out the stain. Mix a squirt of dish soap and about a tablespoon of white vinegar with water, blot the area with a soft cloth, then rinse it clean with cold water. Some people swear by hairspray to break up the stain. Really? Hmmm. We haven’t tried that (and we’re not likely to), so you might want to check that out on a place that doesn’t show.

5. Dirt

Problem: Good old dirt, whether topsoil or minuscule cookie crumbs, will eventually make your car interior look crummy. (Or crumby. Hahaha.)
Solution: Vigilance in the form of regular surface cleaning.

Run a vacuum through your car regularly so dirt doesn’t get enough chance to settle in. A hot-water carpet shampooer (which you can rent from the local grocery or hardware store) and a nylon brush will let you give your seats and floors a full detail treatment for a reasonable price. Hint: Plan to shampoo the interior twice, just like the directions on shampoo bottles: lather, rinse, and repeat to get the layer of ground-in dirt that will surface after the first wash. It will be wet in there, no matter how much you vacuum after rinsing, so don’t just close the car doors and walk away. Set up a fan, keep windows open as long as you can, and let it get dry, or you’ll have mildew to worry about removing next.

For spot cleaning, a bucket of very hot water, some fabric stain remover, and a nylon brush work just about as well as a carpet shampooer does over smaller areas. Then vacuum the area and blot with a cloth to pick up any excess moisture.

contributors.bio:
Jean Knows Cars is not just the name of this website; it's a true fact. I have been writing about cars and the car business for more than 30 years, having learned about cars at the kitchen table from my late father, Robert Lienert, who was the editor of Automotive News. At age eighteen, I bought a used car, painted it yellow, installed a toplight and a meter, and joined the Yellow Cab Company in Ann Arbor, Michigan, as an owner/operator. Five years later, I got a job at Chrysler’s test track as a test driver, welder, and mechanic in the impact lab. In 1980, I was hired as a writer at Car and Driver magazine after getting laid off at Chrysler, and in 1985 I left to establish Automobile Magazine with David E. Davis, Jr. I was the magazine’s first Executive Editor, became Editor in Chief in 2000, and added the title of President of Automobile Magazine in 2006.

I’ve been profiled in The New Yorker and have been a guest on the Tonight Show with Jay Leno. I was a guest on the Oprah Winfrey Show, teaching Oprah and her studio audience how to change a tire and to jump a battery. I was Good Morning America’s automotive correspondent from 1994 to 2000 and then did the same thing for the Oxygen network.

 I have won awards for feature writing, car reviews, and my monthly Automobile Magazine column, “Vile Gossip,” including the 2007 Ken Purdy Award for Excellence in Automotive Journalism.  I’m a regular on-air contributor to Fox Business Network; CNBC’s Closing Bell, Squawk Box, Behind the Wheel, and Power Lunch; MSNBC; CBS This Morning and Evening News; and CNN’s American Morning and Headline News. In fact, I would almost call myself a TV slut, but I’m proud to say that I turned Geraldo down.

All of this has taken place in a male-dominated automotive space, where I’m all too frequently the only woman in the room. I know the secret handshake, but JeanKnowsCars.com is going to be a place where you don’t have to. 

I live in the Michigan countryside with my husband, Tim, and the entire food chain. You’re going to get to know my driveway and my dogs really, really well. Just keep reading.

pageElements.text:
2016 Hyundai Sonata Hybrid Limited

Type: Five-passenger, front-wheel-drive hybrid sedan
Trim levels: SE, Limited
Base price: $26,825 (SE); $30,925 (Limited) (prices include destination charge)
This car: $35,765
Engine: 2.0-liter four-cylinder plus lithium-polymer battery with electric motor; total 193 horsepower
Transmission: Six-speed automatic
Fuel economy: 39 mpg city/43 mpg highway
Safety: National Highway Traffic Safety Administration: 5/5 stars; Insurance Institute for Highway Safety: 2015 Top Safety Pick
Competition (all prices include destination charges):
2016 Ford Fusion Hybrid Titanium ($31,815)
2015 Honda Accord Hybrid EX-L ($32,875)
2016 Toyota Camry Hybrid XLE ($34,955)
Fun-O-Meter: 7

What would it take to get you to buy a hybrid car? It’s a question worth asking, because for many years people have thought they were too expensive, technologically a little scary, or just not worth the hassle for a few extra mpg. Some of them looked (ahem) weird, too.
And all of them were boring.

This is where I admit to my longtime prejudice against hybrids. It was based on solid anecdotal evidence. If you did the math, it made no financial sense to buy one, at least way back when the first Honda Insight and Toyota Prius came out in in the late 1990s. You couldn’t put enough miles on it to ever amortize the extra cost. But it wasn’t about the cost or even its fuel economy to the people who bought it. It was all about being green. And then there was the strident, proselytizing Ed Begley, Jr., factor, although I did love him in Best in Show.
For someone who gardened organically long before the first hybrid car and belonged to the Biodynamic Farming and Gardening Society, I was strangely antagonistic. Was.

For someone who gardened organically for twenty years before the first hybrid car and belonged to the Biodynamic Farming and Gardening Society (everyone else was eighty-two), I was strangely antagonistic toward the Prius people. Then again, I was also the person who belonged to The Nature Conservancy and went to an annual TNC meeting in northern Michigan driving a high-performance, twelve-cylinder AMG Mercedes-Benz coupe. A woman engulfed in a dense cloud of patchouli oil accosted me when I rolled up. “How do you justify driving that car here?!?” she shouted. “Too far to walk,” I said.

These days, even the most cautious shoppers can feel safe to put a toe into the water. 
The 2016 Hyundai Sonata Hybrid just might be the car to inspire you to do a cannonball.

So, what’s to like about this second-generation Sonata Hybrid? Start with a commendable 10 percent fuel economy improvement over the first-generation Sonata Hybrid, to 39 mpg in the city and 43 mpg on the highway. If that doesn’t impress you, compare it to the turbo 1.6-liter four-cylinder gasoline-fueled Sonata Limited, which gets 28 mpg city and 38 mpg on the highway.

The new Hybrid also boasts a 10 percent increase in cargo capacity, up to 13.3 cubic feet, over the last Sonata Hybrid. Competing hybrid brands are in the same ballpark for gas sipping, although the Sonata Hybrid can go a class-leading 24 miles on electricity alone, but the Sonata Hybrid is the class leader in cargo space.
For price comparison, the 2015 Sonata Limited (the top-end model) starts at $34,350, including destination charge, while the 2016 Sonata Hybrid Limited starts at $27,350.
This hybrid has one great advantage: It starts with a really solid foundation, the Sonata.

This hybrid has one great advantage: It starts with a really solid foundation, the Sonata, which was redesigned in 2015. It looks more sophisticated, with a very handsome, clean front and rear appearance.

The interior is beautiful and elegant, a blend of tasteful, neutral colors including taupe, gray, matte black, a high-gloss wood trim, and a splash of piano black. Multiple textures include perforated leather seat inserts in all positions. The (heated) steering wheel and shift knob are also wrapped in leather. The doors are trimmed in a reasonably attractive stitched leatherette. Keeps the cost down, don’t you know.

At the more expensive Limited level, both front and rear seats are heated, and the front seats are also ventilated, as in cooled. The steering wheel is also heated. Those of us in cold climates pause to praise the Hyundai product planner.

A gorgeous panorama roof is part of the $4,500 Ultimate package, which is more about the full suite of advanced 360-degree safety systems. This package also includes a colorful 8.0-inch touchscreen navigation unit. Below it is the climate control system with a really neat set of control buttons that seem to float in their space, not closed in by trim.

Aside from cosmetics, there are a few functional details to consider. First is a horrid buzzing noise when you move the shifter from Park into Drive. The first few times, I about jumped out of my skin. But then, hybrids can be very quiet, and I suppose this is a good way to ensure you know when your car is engaged. In a similar vein, the push-button start has an Off setting that lights up to prove you have shut off the engine. Again, with the silence of a hybrid, this is useful.

I felt a bit of heaviness in the suspension on rough patches, in the way that hybrids can feel heavy. The steering is passably connected, a bit like me in Catholic grade school.

The Verdict:

Overall, apart from the gauges that let you play “how fuel-efficient am I being?” there are not that many differences from a traditional car, at least not differences that you can feel—until you realize how infrequently you have to head to the gas station.

And that’s just the point with the Sonata Hybrid. There’s nothing holier-than-thou about owning or driving this kind of hybrid. It’s attractive, functional, comfortable, and affordable. Why wouldn’t you want to drive one?

Key Points:

• The iA is an all-new model and Scion's first sedan. It doesn't replace any existing vehicle in the lineup for this youth-oriented Toyota brand.

• And since I said "youth oriented," I brought my own Millennial, intern Annie Boniface, to do this short, sweet video review of the iA.
• Along with the new iM hatchback, it's an attempt to rev up Scion's product line, which has been in a bit of a drought with no new products since the FR-S in 2012.
• It's based on the Mazda 2 sedan, which is not currently sold in the United States, and it looks like a small Mazda inside and out.
• The model we tested had a six-speed manual transmission; a six-speed automatic transmission adds $1,100 to the price.

• The iA is a fuel-economy leader in this already frugal class. EPA fuel economy is 33 mpg city/42 mpg highway for the model with six-speed automatic transmission. Compare that with the Hyundai Accent's 26/37 mpg (1.6-liter four-cylinder engine, six-speed automatic transmission); the Chevrolet Sonic at 24/35 mpg (1.8-liter four-cylinder, six-speed automatic); and the Kia Rio at 27/37 mpg (1.6-liter four-cylinder, six-speed automatic).

• Safety equipment helps the iA stand out from the pack, especially the standard low-speed pre-collision safety system that uses a laser sensor to help the driver avoid collisions. Other standard items include six airbags, a brake-override system, and a rearview camera. This kind of technology is not seen in the subcompact car class, let alone as a standard feature.
• The company claims to offer a "no hassle" buying experience at Scion dealerships.
• The warranty also sets it apart from its rivals: scheduled maintenance is covered for two years or 25,000 miles.

• Manufacturers of “youth oriented” cars are missing their targets as Baby Boomers have co-opted many of the vehicles intended for entry-level buyers.
Will that happen here? The average age of a Scion driver is around thirty-seven, according to industry reports.

Cadillac's mid-size car, the CTS, goes after both performance and luxury buyers. For 2016, the addition of an eight-speed automatic transmission with paddle shifters, plus a brand-new 3.6-liter V-6 making 335 horsepower, should entice those in the former category. There's a twin-turbocharged Vsport edition and the ultra-sporting CTS-V as well. A choice of eight interior "environments" heavy on carbon fiber and wood trimmings, plus an optional hand-crafted semi-aniline leather interior, should help with the latter. That new V-6 has cylinder deactivation and stop/start to save fuel, as does the turbocharged 2.0-liter four-cylinder that carries over. Cadillac claims the CTS is lighter and more agile than its competitors in this segment, and the automaker does have formidable competition, particular from the German automakers. title: Learning to Shift
subTitle: Confessions of a girl and a manual transmission, in which I take intern Annie, age 19, for a lesson.
promoTeaserSmall: Confessions of a girl and a manual transmission, in which I take intern Annie, age 19, for a lesson.

pageElements.text:
Annie Boniface:

I lift my left foot off the pedal all too carefully, waiting for the correct moment, and slowly engage my right foot, pressing down with control until...griiiind, gurgle, stop. The car lurches to a halt. Press the ignition button, put both feet to the floor. I remove my left foot from the pedal a bit too quickly this time, and before I can even consider doing anything with my right foot, I hear griiiind, gurgle, stop. The car lurches to a halt.

Add Jean asking in the background, “Now what happened there?” or explaining how gears work, or telling me to pretend there’s an egg between my foot and the pedals as I carefully apply pressure, and you have my experience in learning to drive stick.

When it comes to simple tasks, I am a surprisingly slow learner. My dad, a car guy to the bone, cringed in horror when I was learning to drive automatic and couldn’t quite figure out which pedal operated the brake. At the ice cream store where I worked every summer, it took me two weeks before I could make a small cone without coils of vanilla soft serve falling to the floor. Don’t even get me started on basic math.
My inability thus far to maneuver those three pedals and remember when to put the clutch in is not a reflection of your teaching. Truly, it’s not you; it’s me.

What this all amounts to is a note of encouragement to my teacher in the stick shift endeavor. Jean, you are a fabulous instructor with absolute patience, a necessary sense of humor, and clear instructions. My inability thus far to maneuver those three pedals and remember when to put the clutch in is not a reflection of your teaching. Truly, it’s not you; it’s me.

Jean decided to hold this driving lesson in a cemetery, perhaps to totally freak me out. It’s still unclear. Anyway, the roads running through the graveyard were narrow, and only one was paved. One wrong move, and I would take out Grandma Sally’s headstone and Jean’s car's right tire. The  roads created the least of my problems, though, because I would have to successfully move the car forward without stalling to actually hit something.
As Jean put it, there is nothing masculine or feminine about using a drill, changing a tire, or driving manual. And besides, girls who drive stick are cooler.

Despite the resulting carsickness and frustration, learning to drive stick remains an important goal for me. As Jean put it, there is nothing masculine or feminine about using a drill, changing a tire, or driving manual. And besides, girls who drive stick are cooler.

Jean Jennings:

HAHAHAHAHAHA! I wondered what was going on in that head, Annie, as you were lurching along in the family Volkswagen. (Don’t tell my husband.) First off, I chose the cemetery because everyone in there is already dead, although in hindsight, those headstones can be pretty pricey. I admit that I didn’t expect the gravestones to be quite so close on both sides of the narrow lanes. Sorry for that.
All you need to do is slowly let the clutch out (good God, not that slowly) until the car actually starts moving. Then you feed in the gas. Simple. Easy.

So here’s the thing. As I showed you, you don’t even have to touch the gas in first to get the car going. All you need to do is slowly let the clutch out (good God, not that slowly) until the car actually starts moving. Then you feed in the gas. Simple. Easy.

How did you put it? “Griiiind, gurgle, stop." I couldn’t for the life of me figure out how you kept stalling it, but this isn’t a permanent situation. In fact, having gone at it for two long hours in that graveyard, you probably already have the correct procedure embedded in your busy brain’s putamen, ready to present itself the next time you find yourself behind the wheel of a car with three pedals and a stick. Like riding a bike, sis.

Or maybe it’s in your amygdala, which stores all of your most terrifying moments and shuts off the blood to your brain when encountering one of them. HAHAHAHA. Just kidding. Get ready for Round Two. I swear we will go to a big , open parking lot. You’re right, it’s totally worth it because girls who drive sticks are cooler. We can move on to the power tools after that
Love, Jean

contributors.bio:
Jean Knows Cars is not just the name of this website; it's a true fact. I have been writing about cars and the car business for more than 30 years, having learned about cars at the kitchen table from my late father, Robert Lienert, who was the editor of Automotive News. At age eighteen, I bought a used car, painted it yellow, installed a toplight and a meter, and joined the Yellow Cab Company in Ann Arbor, Michigan, as an owner/operator. Five years later, I got a job at Chrysler’s test track as a test driver, welder, and mechanic in the impact lab. In 1980, I was hired as a writer at Car and Driver magazine after getting laid off at Chrysler, and in 1985 I left to establish Automobile Magazine with David E. Davis, Jr. I was the magazine’s first Executive Editor, became Editor in Chief in 2000, and added the title of President of Automobile Magazine in 2006.

I’ve been profiled in The New Yorker and have been a guest on the Tonight Show with Jay Leno. I was a guest on the Oprah Winfrey Show, teaching Oprah and her studio audience how to change a tire and to jump a battery. I was Good Morning America’s automotive correspondent from 1994 to 2000 and then did the same thing for the Oxygen network.

 I have won awards for feature writing, car reviews, and my monthly Automobile Magazine column, “Vile Gossip,” including the 2007 Ken Purdy Award for Excellence in Automotive Journalism.  I’m a regular on-air contributor to Fox Business Network; CNBC’s Closing Bell, Squawk Box, Behind the Wheel, and Power Lunch; MSNBC; CBS This Morning and Evening News; and CNN’s American Morning and Headline News. In fact, I would almost call myself a TV slut, but I’m proud to say that I turned Geraldo down.

All of this has taken place in a male-dominated automotive space, where I’m all too frequently the only woman in the room. I know the secret handshake, but JeanKnowsCars.com is going to be a place where you don’t have to. 

I live in the Michigan countryside with my husband, Tim, and the entire food chain. You’re going to get to know my driveway and my dogs really, really well. Just keep reading.

“The segment of Altima is the second largest segment in the United States. We today occupy the second position in this segment behind Camry. We passed Accord, thanks to the product attributes and also to the energy of our dealers. Let’s not forget...this is the most sold car for us in the U.S. it’s very important in order to reach our goal of 10 percent market share in the U.S. market.” —Carlos Ghosn

Carlos Ghosn is a bit of a rock star in the automotive world, after reaching out from Renault in 1999 and snatching Nissan back from the brink of death. He became famous for his lack of sleep as he jetted between France, Japan, and the U.S. and for his diminutive stature, outsize ego, and lack of patience for anyone who couldn’t keep up.
This week, he rocked on through the morning news shows in New York City, showing off the new 2016 Nissan Altima, the bread and butter for Renault’s table.

Nissan is calling the Alima a “minor refresh”—actually a public relations spokesman told me it was a major minor refresh—to bring Nissan’s number-one seller here into line, design-wise, with the 2015 Murano and the 2016 Maxima. The revised Altima now bears the sensuous curves of Nissan’s “Energetic Flow” design language and bold Vee grille design. There’s a name for that, too—V-Motion, in Nissan-speak.

The biggest changes include the addition of new safety technologies to its portfolio of existing features, and an upgrade to the Altima’s Xtronic CVT’s performance and feel with the third-generation D-step Shift logic. We’ve tested this CVT on both the Murano and the Maxima and it’s really impressive. Instead of the usual nothingness you feel with most CVT’s the D-step feels like there are real gears in there—especially noticeable from a standing start and when you’re passing slowpokes.

New for 2016 is the SR model, a sportier version available with either four- or six-cylinder engine. It has a sport suspension tuning, a rear spoiler, sporty black-and-blue interior color scheme, a leather-wrapped steering wheel and gear lever, special eighteen-inch aluminum alloy wheels, and smoked headlights. LED lights will be optional on the 2.5 and standard on the 3.5, both coming later in the model year.

Buyers will be interested by the fuel economy of the 2.5-liter model, by far the most popular choice. Getting 39 mpg on the highway puts it at the top of the very competitive mid-size sedan segment. Did I say the Altima was overlooked? Perhaps not so much anymore, with sales up 60 percent since 2009.

The new Altima goes on sale in November.

contributors.bio: When I turned sixteen, my dad brought home the very first-generation Ford Escort wagon, and it just so happened to have a manual transmission. Since—like every other sixteen-year-old—I knew everything, I was sure that I would just get behind the wheel and effortlessly shift gears. Visions of screeching into the school parking lot with my shiny red "world car" and impressing all the burnouts who hung out near their Detroit muscle cars danced in my head. All of those dreams were quickly extinguished in the first fifteen minutes of my driving lesson from my dad. Although he has a teaching certificate, patience is not his strongest skill. The subtle foot-hand coordination escaped me, and we were jerking around the subdivision like the contestants in a game of Red Light Green Light. I blamed my dad, and he blamed me. To my astonishment, he decided it was best to abandon ship and allow me to figure out how to get home. Somehow I managed to limp home without needing therapy for whiplash. After our wounds had healed I did end up learning to drive a manual on that trusty steed. I ended up driving my Escort to Northern Michigan University in Marquette, in Michigan’s frigid Upper Peninsula, where I obtained a BFA, with a concentration in Graphic Design, and a future husband. I joined Automobile Magazine at the tender age of twenty-eight and fell in love with the energy and passion for automobiles and the way they enhance our lives. Later, I took a five-year hiatus and boned up my design and web skills and am now turbocharged to be a part of the Jean Knows Cars team. Many years have passed, and now my sixteen-year-old only child is poised to learn to drive a manual, and I can’t help but be transported back to my teens. Unlike my parents, I am a helicopter mom. Riding in the passenger's seat with her behind the wheel is like waterboarding. I want to order her to pull over and allow me to drive and throw her in the back seat with airbags strapped directly on her. Many of her peers will not learn to drive a manual, but I believe that it is the building block for a good safe driver. It is a perfect synergy watching my daughter learn to drive and helping Jean Knows Cars celebrate and embrace the automobile and how it is woven into our lives.

pageElements.text: School is in session. Yes, for your kids, but also for you. This lesson is for parents of young drivers. The cost of adding your child to your auto insurance policy can certainly dampen the excitement of the milestone of earning a driver’s license. We may not be as money savvy as Suze Orman, but we do have some tips to save some greenbacks on your insurance. The time to do your insurance homework is well before your child drives away from the DMV with his or her license. I personally was not so smart. The day my daughter was added to our auto insurance policy, our premium nearly doubled. So you should do as I say, not what I did.

1. Start early. When your student starts driver ed, begin exploring insurance for your young driver. Compile a list of questions to ask potential insurance companies. Get quotes from at least three suitors. It makes sense to begin with your current insurance company and see what programs they offer for young drivers. But be prepared to walk if another company can save you money.

2. Learn about good-student discounts. All of the nagging to get your kid to get good grades will not only get them into a good college, it may help to beef up their college fund at the same time. Just as an example, a co-worker gets $294.41 knocked off the State Farm premium on her college student’s car every six months because of a good-student discount. There are good statistical reasons why new drivers pay high premiums, but many companies let you reduce that a bit with a financial incentive for a good grade-point average. This usually applies to both high school and college students, including homeschoolers, but make sure to confirm. Each company has its own age restrictions—State Farm grants the discount until the twenty-fifth birthday, even after a student has earned a degree. Ask what magic GPA number is required to get (and maintain) the discount.
AAA, State Farm, and Liberty Mutual all offer some kind of “away” discount; all require the student’s school address to be at least 100 miles from home.

3. Find out about student-away savings. My daughter’s university is an eight-hour drive from home, so she qualifies for Liberty Mutual’s Student Away at School discount, saving us $125 per month. Ka-ching. Again, each company treats this discount differently, but AAA, State Farm, and Liberty Mutual all offer some kind of “away” discount; all require the student’s school address to be at least 100 miles from home. Check the age restrictions and find out if there are driving limitations when they are home. State Farm allows the student to drive the family car during breaks, including summer. AAA assured us that the student is still covered when driving a friend’s car at school, as well as when he or she is a passenger or a pedestrian.

4. Do the math before your child takes a car to college. Don’t miss exploring the financial implications of having your child take a car to college. You must inform your insurance company of the new address of the student. The premium may increase based on the location. Also, find out the coverage if friends drive the car. My daughter does not have a car at school, but she drives friends' cars. I often wonder if her friends' parents know they are providing a car to a bevy of young drivers.

5. Double check (and double back to check) your work. As your young driver progresses from age sixteen to twenty-five, remember to check back in with your company to see if any new programs apply to you. If your student was not eligible for the good-student discount when your coverage began but brings home a stellar report card later, or if he or she transfers to a college farther from home, make sure to let your company know. Most companies will not allow both the student away discount and good-student discount, so you may need to compare.

6. Share the information with your child. These discounts add up to thousands of dollars over the span of time your child may be covered under your family policy. So it is important to take this lesson seriously. Include your child in the research and help him or her understand more thoroughly your insurance policy and the whole cost of entry into the fabulous world of car ownership.
