When the Chevrolet Volt rolled onto the scene in 2010, we, along with most members of the automotive press corps, saw it as a game changer: an electric that could keep going when the battery was depleted. None of your waiting around for hours and hours with the car plugged into a wall socket.
In the world of alternate propulsion, it looked like a hands-down winner.
But it wasn’t.

Over the course of five years, Chevy sold a little under 80,000 Volts. Not all of Chevrolet’s U.S. dealers carried the Volt, but some 2,200 did. That works out to an average of just over thirty-six Volts per participating dealer, or about seven Volts per dealer per year.
Not exactly a landslide. And low fuel prices have sharply diminished America’s appetite for hybrids and electrics. So what will give this new Volt wider appeal than the first generation?
That’s a very good question. The short answer is: pretty much everything. Better looks, excellent road manners, improved performance, and substantial improvement to its innovative powertrain.

Let’s start with the element that’s set the Volt apart from others in the growing world of electro-hybrid vehicles: propulsion. Like the first generation, the new Volt employs an internal-combustion engine. Its primary role is to power the car’s battery pack, which in turn sends juice to electric motors that turn the front wheels.

Notice that word “motors.” In the original Volt there was one electric motor, which doubled as a generator. In the new one there are two, either of which—or both—can propel the car or generate electricity.

The battery pack, which resides under the floor down the center of the car, is a little bigger, storing about 20 percent more juice, and it’s about thirty pounds lighter than the original. The 1.5-liter gasoline engine, one of GM’s new family of ultra-efficient four-cylinders, produces more power and is also lighter, by about 100 pounds.

All told, the new Volt is some 200 pounds lighter than the original. Reduced mass and higher efficiency—the engineers claim a 12 percent improvement—add up to greater range operating on electric power, greater range overall, and of course higher fuel economy.

This new Volt can go fifty-three miles on electric power alone, according to Chevrolet, and 420 miles before the gas tank needs a refill. Chevrolet claimed a maximum of thirty-eight miles running on electric power for the original, and a total range of 380 miles with the gasoline engine powering the system.

EPA fuel economy ratings are 42 mpg combined city/highway, with an mpg equivalency rating—MPGe, the government’s formula for equating electrics and plug-in hybrids with conventional internal-combustion systems—of 106.
The styling is more contemporary than the first version, and the increase in size yields more room for rear-seat passengers, a point of complaint among first-gen owners.

This is a larger Volt, a little over three inches longer, on a wheelbase that’s been stretched by about a half inch. The styling is more contemporary than the first version, and the increase in size yields more room for rear-seat passengers, a point of complaint among first-gen owners. Also, the center rear is habitable by an adult, at least for short hauls, something that wasn’t true of the original.

The front seats are manually adjustable—this is fundamentally an electric car, remember—but are comfortable, with just enough bolstering to feel almost sporty. The dashboard is dominated by an 8.0-inch screen that displays function of the power system, as well as navigation (when so equipped) and other infotainment elements. There’s also a display in the instrument binnacle showing battery state and, of course, remaining fuel.

Interior materials are a cut above what you’d expect in a compact sedan, standard safety items are basic (although the Premier trim level we drove was equipped with several optional features), and the interior is quiet at all speeds—which of course you’d expect.

Speaking of speed, the new Volt is a little peppier than the original—19 percent quicker to 30 mph, according to Chevrolet, and 7 percent to 60 mph: just under eight seconds, about a second less than Volt I. The steering has better than average road feel by today’s electric rack-and-pinion standards, body motions are subdued—very little roll in cornering—ride quality is smooth, the chassis feels solid, throttle response is vigorous, the transmission has a single speed (keep in mind that electric motors make maximum torque from the first rev), and overall operation is seamless; borderline sporty, in fact.
It’s basically a pleasure to drive, and the transition from pure electric propulsion to the involvement of the gasoline engine is totally seamless.

It’s basically a pleasure to drive, and the transition from pure electric propulsion to the involvement of the gasoline engine is totally seamless. The driver’s only clue to the engine’s activation is the information on the dashboard readouts.

As noted, Chevrolet cites a maximum pure electric range of 53 miles. Presumably, that’s by driving with an eye toward maximizing the battery charge. We logged 48 before the engine came to life, not quite up to factory spec but certainly better than Gen I’s 38-mile max. And we weren’t driving conservatively.

Another new powertrain element is a steering wheel paddle switch that increases the Volt’s battery regeneration. Chevrolet calls it Regen on Demand. Depressing the switch creates a slight but noticeable drag, and can serve as an auxiliary brake in situations where the driver needs to slow only slightly. Using the regen switch and coasting when possible can bring the battery back on line during a trip, thus extending electric range.
The company says that many first-generation owners went as much as 900 miles between fillups, and the expectation is for 1,000 miles with the new generation.

We didn’t have enough time with the car to require a fuel fill, but Volt owners tend to maximize electric range, according to Chevrolet. The company says that many first-generation owners went as much as 900 miles between fills, and the expectation is for 1,000 miles with the new generation. It's hard not to be impressed.

Like other plug-in hybrids, recharging the Volt’s battery pack plugging into ordinary household current is time-consuming: half a day. Setting up the optional 240-volt system reduces that to 4.5 hours. But with this car, battery depletion needn’t precipitate a lot of sitting around waiting; you have options.

One of the elements that damped sales of the first-generation Volt was price. With a base MSRP close to $40,000, the Volt was a pretty expensive compact car, even after the $7,500 federal tax incentive and other state credits. Chevy has whittled the base price for the second generation down to $33,995, which, with tax credits, gets the Volt down closer to compact reality.

The top Premier model we tested has a base price of $38,345, and it added $990 for two packages of safety features—blind zone alert, lane departure warning, lane keeping assist, low speed automatic braking, forward collision alert—and $495 for Chevy’s MyLink radio with nav system, putting the as-tested price very close to $40,000.
As an aside, it’s interesting that Chevrolet does not offer an adaptive cruise control option.

At $39,830, the Volt’s virtues become a little more difficult to appreciate, tax breaks notwithstanding. But with a bit less luxury, this car rewards its owner financially, as well as in terms of driving pleasure—particularly owners whose primary driving is within or close to the Volt’s electric range.

There will be a "shortened model year" for the 2016 Volt, Chevrolet's Michelle Malcho told us. The 2017 Volt is coming next spring to the whole country, but the 2016 Volt is getting a limited rollout. About 45 percent of Volt sales to date have been in California, so it makes sense that GM will begin rolling Volts into California showrooms first, starting in the next two weeks. After that, the Volt will go on sale in traditionally strong alternative-energy vehicle markets: Oregon, Connecticut, Maine, Massachusetts, Maryland, New York, New Jersey, Rhode Island, Vermont, and New Hampshire.

contributors.bio:
Jean Knows Cars is not just the name of this website; it's a true fact. I have been writing about cars and the car business for more than 30 years, having learned about cars at the kitchen table from my late father, Robert Lienert, who was the editor of Automotive News. At age eighteen, I bought a used car, painted it yellow, installed a toplight and a meter, and joined the Yellow Cab Company in Ann Arbor, Michigan, as an owner/operator. Five years later, I got a job at Chrysler’s test track as a test driver, welder, and mechanic in the impact lab. In 1980, I was hired as a writer at Car and Driver magazine after getting laid off at Chrysler, and in 1985 I left to establish Automobile Magazine with David E. Davis, Jr. I was the magazine’s first Executive Editor, became Editor in Chief in 2000, and added the title of President of Automobile Magazine in 2006.

I’ve been profiled in The New Yorker and have been a guest on the Tonight Show with Jay Leno. I was a guest on the Oprah Winfrey Show, teaching Oprah and her studio audience how to change a tire and to jump a battery. I was Good Morning America’s automotive correspondent from 1994 to 2000 and then did the same thing for the Oxygen network.

 I have won awards for feature writing, car reviews, and my monthly Automobile Magazine column, “Vile Gossip,” including the 2007 Ken Purdy Award for Excellence in Automotive Journalism.  I’m a regular on-air contributor to Fox Business Network; CNBC’s Closing Bell, Squawk Box, Behind the Wheel, and Power Lunch; MSNBC; CBS This Morning and Evening News; and CNN’s American Morning and Headline News. In fact, I would almost call myself a TV slut, but I’m proud to say that I turned Geraldo down.

All of this has taken place in a male-dominated automotive space, where I’m all too frequently the only woman in the room. I know the secret handshake, but JeanKnowsCars.com is going to be a place where you don’t have to. 

I live in the Michigan countryside with my husband, Tim, and the entire food chain. You’re going to get to know my driveway and my dogs really, really well. Just keep reading.

2016 Honda Accord Touring V-6

Type: Five-passenger, front-wheel-drive compact sedan
Trim levels: LX, Sport, EX, EX-L, EX-L V-6, Touring V-6
Base price: $22,925 (LX Sedan with four-cylinder engine); $35,400 (Touring V-6) (prices include destination charge)
This car: $35,400
Engine: 3.5-liter V-6, 278 horsepower
Transmission: Six-speed automatic
Fuel economy: 21 mpg city/34 mpg highway
Safety: National Highway Traffic Safety Administration: 5/5 stars; Insurance Institute for Highway Safety: Top Safety Pick Plus
Competitors (prices include destination charge):
2016 Chevrolet Malibu LT Premier ($31,795)
2016 NIssan Altima 3.5SL ($33,175)
2016 Toyota Camry XLE V-6 ($32,205)

Fun-O-Meter: 8
Who would want to be the chief engineer and designer in charge of remaking the Honda Accord?

This is the only car, after all, that has been named to Car and Driver’s Ten Best list twenty-nine times, nearly every year since it made the first Ten Best list in 1983. It’s the car that sells up to 400,000 copies every year, that some 10 million people have bought. Who’d want to be the team that broke the streak?
Luckily, the well-earned hubris of Honda’s people has paid off, and we get a refreshed, technology-filled 2016 Accord that is a winner in every sense.
Not expecting to fall in love with the car—thinking of it more as a practical than an exciting choice—I am here to report that, in fact, I fell in love with the car.

Not expecting to fall in love with the car—thinking of it more as a practical than an exciting choice—I am here to report that, in fact, I fell in love with the car. It’s spectacularly smooth, with exceptional acceleration all the way to 80 mph (and--ahem--beyond). Its V-6, in the Accord Touring model we tested, is a magic engine. Its six-speed automatic transmission is superb.

After all, imagine a car that the rabid boy racers at Car and Driver would choose to award just about every year for decades, more often than any of the many other deserving cars out there. Is there any wonder its residual value is so high, and that it is such a coveted, top-selling car in the United States?

It is safe to say that everything about the 2016 Accord is better than ever. An updated version of the the ninth-generation Accord that made its debut in 2013, the new model continues to build on an attractive look that goes well beyond the bland appearance of many sedans. It’s stylish, especially in the crisply tailored and interestingly folded front end, with the hood now made of aluminum rather than steel. A new set of LED fog lights and taillights are found on all but the base model. It’s stronger, sharper, and more complex. The chrome trim on the exterior might be just a bit excessive—never mind my own somewhat excessive style and personality.

There is nothing soft about its appearance in any way.  That is an achievement, given how hard it is to make a front-wheel-drive car look exciting. Someone said to me that the Honda Accord is not a car you’d look out the window late at night and feel thrilled to see in your driveway. I disagree; I can’t say any Accord has made me as interested in it as this one did.

The interior is satisfying, with a great blend of materials, textures, and colors, and all perfectly screwed together. Just one indicator is the extra little cubby space in the inside door handle. An automaker that understands this knows how to waste no opportunities for clever use of space. There’s a spacious hidden compartment in the dash that I didn’t find until the end of the week, and when I did, it revealed an extra USB port. By the numbers, the Accord isn’t bigger or offer more inches of legroom, yet with Honda’s usual brilliant use of space, the back seat is more comfortable and usable than on some big crossovers I’ve driven recently.
More than most cars in this category, with the Accord you get a complete, all-around package of comfort, control, refinement, and great acceleration.

Over the nine generations of the Accord, Honda has managed to delete any hint of potential torque steer. The steering and brakes are everyday perfection, and the ride is magic-carpet-like. More than most cars in this category, with the Accord you get a complete, all-around package of comfort, control, refinement, and great acceleration.
Can you tell I fell for this car?

But it’s not just this Touring V-6 model, the new top of the line Accord for 2016. Even the base model, the four-cylinder LX, has much to recommend it, starting with the low ($22,925) price of entry to the Accord family. It is also available with either a six-speed manual or a continuously variable automatic transmission. The active safety features are all available as options on every model and were included on the Touring model as standard.

The active safety features on the 2016 Accord are adaptive cruise control (ACC), collision mitigation braking (CMBS), forward collision warning (FCW), lane departure warning (LDW), and road departure mitigation (RDM). I normally detest acronyms—they tend to add more confusion when people are already confused—but at least these are not made-up names. Remarkably, to get the whole suite of features on the LX, Sport, or EX four-cylinder Accord models costs only $1,000. Choose the model with the Honda Sensing package to get them all.

The reason to get the Touring model, in addition to the highly desirable V-6, is the inclusion of luxury features—heated front and rear seats, rain-sensing wipers, front and rear parking sensors, and automatic high beams, as well as larger front brakes and special high-performance suspension components.
There’s also an Accord Coupe, available in all the same trim levels as the sedan, but unlike in previous years, there is no hybrid model for 2016.

Technology is a big part of the story in the 2016 Accord, including both Apple CarPlay and Android Auto, a huge step forward that lets you use many of your smartphone’s apps through the car’s infotainment screen, keeping your eyes off the phone and on the road. I found the voice-activated navigation system easy to use and the dual-screen setup intuitive and helpful. The 7.7-inch upper screen shows you your audio settings and rearview camera images; you can also upload a personal photo to be the default image—sort of the Honda equivalent of the bud vase in the Volkswagen Beetle. The lower 7.0-inch touchscreen is where navigation, trip information, and Apple CarPlay or Android Auto icons live.

I can’t review any Honda without praising the excellent multi-angle rearview camera with its LaneWatch function, standard on all 2016 Accords. You get a choice of wide, normal, or top-down views with the rearview camera, and when you activate the right turn signal, you get a camera shot of what’s coming up behind you on the right. Don’t be tempted to just leave the blinker on permanently; you don’t have to. Simply press the end of the turn signal stalk to see that right-side image all the time.

Honda shoppers can learn all about this and other features on the Honda Owners website, which describes and illustrates the technology in an understandable way. I’ve said it often, but it bears repeating: connectivity and active safety tech are two good reasons to buy a new car now, and the Accord has plenty of both to tempt you.

contributors.bio: When I turned sixteen, my dad brought home the very first-generation Ford Escort wagon, and it just so happened to have a manual transmission. Since—like every other sixteen-year-old—I knew everything, I was sure that I would just get behind the wheel and effortlessly shift gears. Visions of screeching into the school parking lot with my shiny red "world car" and impressing all the burnouts who hung out near their Detroit muscle cars danced in my head. All of those dreams were quickly extinguished in the first fifteen minutes of my driving lesson from my dad. Although he has a teaching certificate, patience is not his strongest skill. The subtle foot-hand coordination escaped me, and we were jerking around the subdivision like the contestants in a game of Red Light Green Light. I blamed my dad, and he blamed me. To my astonishment, he decided it was best to abandon ship and allow me to figure out how to get home. Somehow I managed to limp home without needing therapy for whiplash. After our wounds had healed I did end up learning to drive a manual on that trusty steed. I ended up driving my Escort to Northern Michigan University in Marquette, in Michigan’s frigid Upper Peninsula, where I obtained a BFA, with a concentration in Graphic Design, and a future husband. I joined Automobile Magazine at the tender age of twenty-eight and fell in love with the energy and passion for automobiles and the way they enhance our lives. Later, I took a five-year hiatus and boned up my design and web skills and am now turbocharged to be a part of the Jean Knows Cars team. Many years have passed, and now my sixteen-year-old only child is poised to learn to drive a manual, and I can’t help but be transported back to my teens. Unlike my parents, I am a helicopter mom. Riding in the passenger's seat with her behind the wheel is like waterboarding. I want to order her to pull over and allow me to drive and throw her in the back seat with airbags strapped directly on her. Many of her peers will not learn to drive a manual, but I believe that it is the building block for a good safe driver. It is a perfect synergy watching my daughter learn to drive and helping Jean Knows Cars celebrate and embrace the automobile and how it is woven into our lives.

pageElements.text: Kia has a plan to help its Sedona thrive even as overall minivan sales continue to decline, faced with American's love affair with the sport-utility vehicle. It starts with the business-class comfort we found in the 2016 Kia Sedona SXL, the top-of-the-line model from Kia ($44,690 as tested, including destination charge). Kia refers to the Sedona as a multipurpose vehicle, or MPV, to try to distance it from the negative image of a minivan. Minivans are actually true utility vehicles anyway, and this one is angling to be synonymous with passenger comfort.

The Sedona received a complete redesign in 2015 that has been well received. The exterior design has moved toward the aesthetic of a crossover utility vehicle. From head on, it isn't immediately identifiable as a minivan, showcasing the smartly designed tiger-nose grille that defines the modern Kia lineup. The side profile pushes the crossover effect with shorter front and rear overhangs. The strategy seems to be working: Sedona sales have improved significantly since the 2015 model hit the showroom floor.

Thanks to these efforts by Kia, the Sedona is arguably the best-looking minivan in the segment, but it may lose its sash soon. The segment sales leaders—Toyota Sienna, Honda Odyssey, and Chrysler Town & Country—are all set to bring out completely redesigned models for 2017. But while the sun is still shining on it, here are five cool things about the 2016 Kia Sedona SXL.

1. Reclining seats. I spent some time over the long weekend lounging in the First Class Lounge Seating in the Sedona's second row, and I have never been as comfortable on a road trip before. Yes, I drove, too, but I was jonesing for the fully reclining center row captain's chairs the entire time. The seats are only found on the top SXL trim level. A leg rest flips out, fully supporting your legs, and the seat reclines waaaaay back. To afford more space for your legs to fully extend, the entire seat slides back and forth as well as from side to side. I brought along an eyeshade to get maximum comfort, but the SXL comes standard with built-in second- and third-row pull-down sunshades. One caveat: the lounge seats cannot have seat heating or cooling. Also, Kia has a disclaimer that traveling while fully reclined will compromise the effectiveness of the restraint system. So this might give pause to parents.

Warning to parents of large families who need to seat eight: you will have to forfeit the fully reclining second-row seats and go down a trim level to the SX. The eight-seat configuration has a center seat in the second row that folds down and becomes a console when not in use. It can also be completely removed from the vehicle. I personally would consider sending that eighth passenger to boarding school so I could keep the lounge seating. For those who draw the short straw and end up in the third row, it reclines slightly as well. It is split 60/40 and can be stowed in the floor. When storing the second row, the lounge seats take up a large amount of space compared with the standard seats,  which slide forward and fold against the front seats.

It also must be stated that the comfort level is definitely hampered by a rough ride, and to compete with the likes of Toyota and Honda, Kia needs to revisit the suspension before the 2017 models are on sale.

2. Illumination. I am a sucker for lighting, and the Sedona won me over even before I entered the cabin. As you near the car with the key in your pocket, an indented oval around the key pops to life with a lovely blue glow. I must admit that I also like to see the aftermarket lights that shine down under tuner cars. So dismiss my opinion if you are a curmudgeon.

3. Multiple USBs. Continuing the light show are three, yes three (2.1 amp) fast-charging USB ports. Each one glowed red in the dark, and if you listen closely you can hear the Hallelujah Chorus. Gone were the arguments about whose turn it is to charge their device. The auxiliary port also has the guiding red glow. Adding to the electric powerplant on wheels is the standard power plug along with two 115-volt power outlets, one in the center console and another in the cargo area. Who doesn’t want to straighten their hair while flying down the highway? The USB that was positioned behind the front console won praise from the second-row recliners and added to their business class experience. Just like consumer demand in the 1990s brought cupholders to the masses, our tech-driven lives now require USBs for all passengers.

4. Overhead camera. The Surround View Monitor’s series of cameras provides a bird’s-eye view of your vehicle. The overhead view style of monitor is popping up in more and more vehicles, and I cannot say loudly enough how much I love this feature. It automatically activates when the vehicle is in reverse, but there is also a button you can push to turn it on manually. I personally used it many times to make sure I was perfectly placed in a parking spot. No more getting out of the car and realizing that my car is straddling a yellow line. The first time I drove a car with an overhead camera, I was dumbstruck by the technology. It seems like there is a drone flying over your vehicle, but it is just four cameras working together to create the view. Genius.

5. Active safety: lane departure and forward collision warning. Both the lane departure and forward collision systems are part of the Technology package in the Kia Sedona SX and SXL ($2,800), but blind spot detection and cross-traffic alert are standard on the SX and SXL and an option on the EX. Yes, the lane departure warning audible alert is annoying, but it could also be a life saver. A minivan is the go-to vehicle for long road trips. And on road trips, drivers often remain behind the wheel for longer hours than common sense suggests is safe. Having your vehicle helicopter-mom your lane keeping is a really useful safety feature. When I was teaching my daughter to drive, reminding her to stay centered in her lane caused enough friction to set a forest on fire. The lane departure warning would have been a godsend. Then it would have been the car nannying her rather than me. It (unlike a helicopter mom) can also be toggled off when you desire.

The forward collision warning system entices me when I think about all the distracted drivers I see as I pilot my vehicle down the road. If every car could have an audible alert when in danger of a collision, it would obviously cut down on accidents. I especially think about texters, whose eyes are off the road for just a tad too long. A vehicle that is vying for families must cocoon the occupants in safety features. It is no longer enough to slap a baby on board sticker in the back window.
